chunks.original_text: 夫意行则神往，意止则神住。 可不澄定乎？ 反之於虚，即消燥灭息矣， 虚者神之宅也，反则刳心而任神，忘欲而能鉴矣。 是以阴阳水火不复牵变於己也。 此圣人之游也。 神与化游。 故治天下者，必达於性命之情而后可也。 夫有生之域，唯性与命。 情所同保，类所异者，非神而不可达，非大顺而不可治也。 守真 适形而安，则安而无佗； 适性而往，则所至非妄。 然大名大师，亦自此而生。 老子曰：夫所谓圣人者，适情而已，量腹而食，度形而衣，节乎己，而贪污之心无由生也。 生之不得已者，衣食也。 周身量腹，余为佗物矣。 但内外无污，谓之圣人也。 故能有天下者。 必无以天下为者也， 圣人不以天下奉己之嗜欲，而忘天下者也。 故有能治之，名寄於天下也。 能有名誉者，必不以越行求者也。 大名誉所求，不饰於妄，而区区之行皆妄。 诚达乎性命之情，仁义乃因附也。 通性命者，誉指自成仁义之行。 若夫神无所掩，心无所载，通同条达，澹然无事， 内无累，为虚通。 势利不能诱也， 无贪。 声色不能淫也， 无染。 辩者不能说也， 无惑。 智者不能动也， 无易。 勇者不能恐也， 无惧。 此真人之道也。 淳粹之至。 夫生生者不死，化化者不化。 夫道常存，能化於物，故顺天不可见，同道不可穷也。 不达此道者，虽智统天地，明照日月，辩解连环， 《庄子》云：惠施之辩，连环可解也。 辞润金石，犹无益於治天下。 夫冥顺於天，玄同於物，则变化之机可验，性命之理可通。 然后在家在邦，未尝不达。 若以智谋明察，辩说德泽，盖一曲之功，非全治之道也。 故圣人不失所守。 谓守生化之原，不用明察为治，故天下咸若，百姓谓我自然也。 守静 圣人安此，以为生根德本也。 老子曰：静漠恬淡，所以养生也， 尽其生分，始可为养。 和愉虚无，所以据德也。 受物以虚，接事以和，德居此而为成。 外不乱内，即性得其宜， 声色俱为弃物，性乃全也。 内不动和，即德安其位， 不以爱累亏接物之和，故德有所宁於位。 养生以经世，抱德以终年，可谓能体道矣。 夫性之未全，为欲所牵也，不可经纶世也。 德之将败，为物所累者，不可终天年也。 而外有物，伤中唯性变，虽欲勿困，其可得哉？ 故静漠保生，乃堪涉动，和愉然后保终。 体道之人，此之谓矣。 若然者，血脉无郁滞，五藏无积气， 形和性静，此患何施？ 夫血脉郁滞，在乎厚养。 五藏积气，由之喜怒也。 祸福不能矫滑，非誉不能尘埃， 挠性乱和，沽名求福者，伤生之士也。 非有其世，孰能济焉。 此圣人与道之辞也。
chunks.translated_text:
The mind moves where intent directs,
and stills where intent rests.
How could one not be serene and settled?

Returning to emptiness,
dryness and agitation dissolve.
Emptiness is the dwelling of the spirit—
returning to it, one hollows the heart and entrusts it to the spirit,
forgets desires, and attains discernment.

Thus, yin and yang, water and fire,
no longer drag or alter one’s self.
This is the play of the Sage.

The spirit plays with transformation.
Therefore, to govern the world,
one must first grasp the nature of life and fate.

Within the realm of life,
only nature (*xìng*) and fate (*mìng*) exist.
What all share in preserving,
yet differ in kind—
this cannot be reached without the spirit,
nor governed without the great harmony.

To abide in truth,
adjust the form, and find ease—
then ease is without excess;
to follow nature and proceed—
then all actions are genuine.

Yet great names and great masters arise from here.
Laozi said:
*"The so-called Sage adjusts their emotions alone.
They eat to fill their belly,
clothe themselves to suit their form,
moderate themselves—
and thus the hearts of greed and filth have no opportunity to arise.
What one cannot avoid in life is food and clothing.
Measuring the body, filling the belly—
the rest are superfluous things.
But if internally and externally there is no defilement,
they are called Sages.
Thus, those who can possess the world
must not covet the world.
The Sage does not use the world to indulge their desires,
but forgets the world.
Therefore, those who can govern it
are entrusted with its name.

Those who seek great fame and reputation
do not adorn themselves with deceit—
yet petty actions are all deceitful.
If one truly grasps the nature of life and fate,
then benevolence and righteousness follow naturally.
Those who understand life and fate
see their reputation spontaneously manifest as benevolent and righteous deeds.

When the spirit is unobstructed,
the heart carries nothing,
communing freely and effortlessly—
serene, without concern—
internally unburdened, they are empty and open.
Worldly gains cannot entice them—
no greed.
Sounds and colors cannot seduce them—
no attachment.
Persuasive speech cannot deceive them—
no confusion.
The wise cannot manipulate them—
no deception.
The bold cannot frighten them—
no fear.
This is the Way of the True Person,
the purest essence.

Life begets life and does not die,
transformation transforms and does not cease.
The Dao ever endures,
transforming all things—
thus, aligning with Heaven is unseen,
harmonizing with the Way is unfathomable.
Those who do not grasp this Dao,
though their wisdom encompasses Heaven and Earth,
their brilliance rivals the sun and moon,
their eloquence dissolves like gold and stone—
still, they cannot govern the world.
As *Zhuangzi* says:
*"Huizi’s arguments, though intricate, can be unraveled."*
Yet such talents profit nothing in ruling the world.

If one follows Heaven in obscurity,
harmonizes with things in mystery,
then the mechanisms of transformation can be verified,
and the principles of life and fate understood.
Only then, whether at home or in the realm,
does one never fail to act appropriately.

If one relies on clever schemes,
sharp perception,
eloquent persuasion, or moral influence—
these are but partial achievements,
not the complete path to governance.
Thus, the Sage does not abandon their foundation.
They guard the origin of life and transformation,
not relying on sharp perception for governance—
and so the world naturally aligns,
the people say, *"This is effortless."*

To guard stillness—
the Sage finds ease here,
as the root of life and the foundation of virtue.
Laozi said:
*"Serene, tranquil, and undisturbed—
this is how one nourishes life.
Fulfilling one’s natural span,
only then can it be called nourishment.
Harmonious, joyful, and empty—
this is how one establishes virtue.
Receiving things in emptiness,
meeting affairs with harmony—
virtue resides here and is complete.
Externally undisturbed within,
nature finds its proper place—
sounds and colors become discarded things,
nature remains whole.
Internally unmoved and harmonious,
virtue finds its rightful place—
not burdened by affection,
unimpaired in dealing with others—
thus virtue finds its rest in its place.
Nourishing life to sustain the world,
embracing virtue to complete one’s years—
this is to truly embody the Dao."*

When nature is not yet complete,
it is dragged by desires—
and thus cannot govern the world.
When virtue is about to fail,
it is weighed down by things—
and thus cannot complete one’s lifespan.
Yet externally, things assail,
injuring the center and altering nature—
even if one wishes to avoid distress,
how could it be possible?

Thus, serene stillness preserves life,
only then can one venture into action,
harmony and joy then secure the end.
Those who embody the Dao are such.

If so, then blood and vessels flow without obstruction,
the five viscera hold no stagnant *qi*—
form harmonious, nature still—
what ailments could afflict them?

When blood and vessels stagnate,
it is due to insufficient nourishment.
When the five viscera accumulate *qi*,
it stems from excessive joy and anger.
Fortune and misfortune cannot sway them,
praise cannot soil them—
those who disrupt nature and harmony,
who seek fame and fortune,
are those who harm life.
Without their age, who could save them?

This is the Sage’s discourse with the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 夫静圣之道，与治相符，与乱相反，故无明王，则自全之道未之能保矣。 有其才不遇其时，身犹不能脱，又况无道乎。 此圣人劝道之辞也。 且有堪任之才，未适权变之用，则多事之世未能脱离。 况非守静而践危机哉。 夫目察秋豪之末者，耳不闻雷霆之声，耳调玉石之音者，目不见太山之形，故小有所志者，大有所忘。 一淫声色，失性之远。 今万物之来，擢拔吾生，攓取吾精，若泉原也， 声色之类，左右不可尽，故至天生竭精也。 虽欲勿禀，其可得乎。 以在耳目之前。
chunks.translated_text:
The Way of serene stillness is the Sage’s path,
in accord with governance, opposed to chaos—
thus, without a wise ruler,
the self-preserving Way cannot be upheld.

Even if one has talent but lacks the right time,
one’s very life cannot escape peril—
how much less so without the Way!

This is the Sage’s exhortation toward the Way.

Moreover, those with the capacity for office,
yet unfit for the shifting demands of power,
cannot escape the troubles of an age.
How much less so those who do not uphold stillness
and tread upon perilous thresholds!

He who scrutinizes the tip of an autumn hair
cannot hear the thunder of the heavens;
he who attunes to the sound of jade and stone
cannot perceive the form of Tai Mountain—
thus, small things fixated upon,
great things are forgotten.

One indulgence in sensual pleasures,
and the distant reaches of true nature are lost.

Now, all things converge upon us,
plucking our vitality,
consuming our essence—
like springs and wells exhausted.
The allure of sound and color,
from every side, cannot be fully resisted—
thus, even Heaven’s own essence is drained.

Though one might wish to abstain,
how could it be possible?

For these are ever before the ears and eyes.

chunks.original_text: 今盆水若清之，经日乃能见眉睫，浊之不过一挠，即不能见方圆。 澄心之鉴唯有，静者能之。 故一至嗜欲，虽祸如丘山，亦未之见。 人之精神，难清而易浊，犹盆水也。 守法 法之上者，在乎法天。 法天之法，未有无所法，而同乎大顺者也。 老子曰：上圣法天， 上古圣君法象天道，不教而自化，弃智而成功。 盛德日新，故无得而称，玄功莫朕，是以不知帝力也。 其次上贤， 以贤德之道为上也。 其下任臣。 任臣者，危亡之道也， 谓独任致危也。 上贤者，痴惑之原也， 上贤则争，争为乱本。 法天者，治天地之道也。 法自然之道，则二仪通治。 虚静为主， 天之体也。 虚无不受，静无不持， 持犹制万物之纷挠。 知虚静之道，乃能终始。 未尝抑物，付之自极，如四时相谢无尽也。 故圣人以静为治，以动为乱， 静则各正性命。 故曰，勿挠勿缨，万物将自清，勿惊勿骇，万物将自理，天道然也。 缨谓多方，骇谓设苛政也。 守弱 居众所不敌之地，故成其大胜之道。
chunks.translated_text:
The water in a basin, if made clear,
takes a day to reveal the brows and lashes;
if muddied, even a moment’s disturbance
makes roundness and squareness invisible.

The mirror of a tranquil mind exists only for those who attain stillness.
Thus, when one is ensnared by desires,
even calamities as vast as mountains
remain unseen.

Human spirit is hard to purify but easily clouded—
like water in a basin.

To uphold the Dao beyond the Dao,
one must model Heaven.
The Dao of modeling Heaven
has no end to what it models,
yet aligns with the Great Harmony.

Laozi said:
*The Supreme Sage models Heaven,*
*The sages of antiquity modeled the patterns of Heaven’s Way,*
*Teaching nothing yet transforming all,*
*Abandoning cleverness yet achieving success.*
*Virtue renews daily,*
*Thus no name can be given to it,*
*Mysterious function leaves no trace—*
*Hence, the power of the Sovereign is unknown.*

The next rank are the superior worthies,
who uphold the Dao of virtue as supreme.
Below them are the appointed ministers—
the path of peril and ruin,
for it is the way of relying solely on one’s own strength.

The superior worthy is the root of delusion,
for the superior worthy brings contention,
and contention is the origin of chaos.

To model Heaven is the Way to govern Heaven and Earth.
To follow the Dao of Nature,
then the Two Principles harmonize in governance.

Emptiness and stillness are the essence—
Heaven’s substance.
Empty and receptive to all,
still and sustaining all,
holding back the tumult of myriad things.

Knowing the Dao of emptiness and stillness,
one can complete the beginning and end.
Never suppressing things,
yet letting them reach their own extremes—
like the seasons passing without end.

Thus, the Sage governs through stillness,
and governs through movement as chaos.
Stillness restores each to its true nature and life.

It is said:
*Do not disturb, do not entangle,*
*And all things will naturally clarify.*
*Do not alarm, do not terrify,*
*And all things will naturally order themselves—*
*Such is the Way of Heaven.*

*"Entangle"* means excessive schemes,
*"Terrify"* means imposing harsh decrees.

To uphold weakness,
to dwell in the position where none can rival you—
thus, the Way of great victory is fulfilled.

One indulgence in sensual pleasures,
and the distant reaches of true nature are lost.

Now, all things converge upon us,
plucking our vitality,
consuming our essence—

The allure of sound and color,

chunks.original_text: 老子曰：天子公侯，以天下一国为家，以万物为畜、怀天下之大，有万物之多，即气逸而志骄， 所谓贵不与骄，期而骄自至。 大者用兵侵小， 晋灭虞、楚、伐隋之类。 小者倨傲陵下， 曹共公、卫献公之类。 用心奢广，譬犹飘风暴雨，不可长久。 夫强盛之气，天地尚不能久，而况奢僭之君？ 是以圣人以道镇之， 非虚柔之道孰能安？ 执一无为，以损冲气， 冲中。 见小守柔，退而勿有； 见小自成其大，守柔能制其刚。 法於江海，江海不为，故功名自化， 夫处下众归，体谏物与，故不求而名遂，不争而功成。 弗强，故能成其王， 德归者宁，力制者叛。 为天下牝，故能神不死， 牝者，柔之谓也。 圣人法之以存神。 自爱，故能成其贵， 将欲贵位，在乎爱身。 故以道自胜、则身可长保，身存者，贵其亡乎？ 万乘之势，以万物为功名， 功名小大，随位而立。 权任至重，不可以自轻， 《庄子》曰：轻用吾身而亡吾国也。 自轻则功名不成。 未有身不洽而国治者也。 夫道大以小成、多以少生， 大之资者，一豪耳。 多之要者，一笄耳。 故圣人以道莅天下，柔弱微妙者，见小也，俭啬损缺者，见少也，见小故能成其大，见少故能成其美。 道以微妙为大，德以损缺为美。 天之道，抑高举下，损有余，奉不足， 其犹张弓乎？ 势之均也。 江海处地之不足，故天下归之奉之。 必故圣人卑谦守静辞让者，见下也，虚心无有者，见不足也。 法江海之故也。 见下故能致其高，见不足故能致其贤。 心之常下，德之弥高； 身之常退，行之弥进也。 矜者不立，奢者不长，。 强梁者死，满溢亡。 飘风骤雨不终日，小谷不能须臾盈。 小谷褊狭，若注之须臾，则至乎盈溢。 飘风骤雨行强梁之气，故不能久而灭，小谷处强梁之地，故不得不夺。 夺其归，奉之德。 是以圣人执雌牝，去骄奢，不敢行强梁之气， 遵天地之戒也。 执雌牝，故能立其雄牡，不敢奢泰，故能长久。 唯能雌者，故能有立健之德也。 老子曰：天道极即反，盈即损，日月是也。 日中则昊，月盈则亏。 故圣人日损，而冲气不敢自满，日进以牝，功德不衰，天道然也。 日进以牝者，推柔以御物也。 天道亏盈益谦，圣人能法。 故盛德日新而无所替。 人之情性，皆好高而恶下，好得而恶亡，好利而恶病，好尊而恶卑，好贵而恶贱，众人为之，故弗能成，执之，故弗能得。 夫物宜更变，理势大均，果且而有成。 果且而无得。 设使居其位者，亦素定分，岂好恶偏执而能得之者哉？ 是以圣人法天，弗为而成，弗执而得， 乘彼自然，则与时而成，与物而得也。 与人同情而异道，故能长久。 同所适之情，异所从之道，反其爱恶之私，乃成长久之德。 故三皇五帝有戒之器，命曰侑卮，其冲则正，其盈则覆。 事具《周与》。 夫物盛则衰，日中而移，月满则亏，乐极而悲。 是故聪明广智守以愚， 至察无徒，匿耀守众。 多闻博辩守以俭， 矜能有辱，持后无失。 武力勇毅守以畏， 轻敌多败，虞慎保胜。 富贵广大守以狭， 骄盈日危，谦损日福也。 德施天下守以让， 自伐乃丧，推物乃全。 此五者，先王所以守天下也。 夫有天下者，位之极也。 若以极欲而持极位，则倾覆矣。 非此五德，何以守之也？ 服此道者，不欲盈，
chunks.translated_text:
Laozi says:

When the Son of Heaven, the public lords, and the marquises treat the realm and the world as their own home, and all things as their livestock, harboring the vastness of the world, possessing the abundance of myriad things, then their *qi* becomes dissipated and their wills grow arrogant. This is what is meant by: *"Nobility without arrogance"*—yet arrogance will inevitably arise.

The great will invade the small—such as when Jin annihilated You, or Chu attacked Xing. The small will act haughty and domineer—such as Cao Gong and Wei Xian. Their hearts are extravagant and broad, like a sudden wind or violent rain, unable to endure long.

The *qi* of strength and might—even Heaven and Earth cannot sustain it long, let alone a king who indulges in excess and usurpation. Therefore, the Sage governs with the Dao to restrain them. What else but the Way of emptiness and softness could bring stability?

Holding to One and doing nothing, diminishing the clashing *qi*, balancing the extremes—
Seeing the small and guarding the soft, withdrawing without possession;
Seeing the small yet achieving the great, guarding the soft yet controlling the hard.

Modeling oneself after the rivers and seas—
The rivers and seas do not strive, yet their merit and name naturally manifest.
Those who dwell in lowliness are honored by the multitude;
Their bodies accept counsel, and things accord with them—
Thus, without seeking, their name is fulfilled;
Without contending, their deeds are accomplished.

Not forcing, they achieve kingship.
Those who rely on virtue are at peace; those who rely on force rebel.

As the mother of the world, they preserve their spirit undying—
For the mother is the essence of softness.
The Sage follows this to preserve the spirit.

Self-preservation ensures nobility—
To desire noble status, one must first love one’s body.
Thus, by conquering oneself with the Dao, one’s life may be long preserved.
If the body is preserved, how could nobility perish?

With the power of ten thousand chariots, treating all things as instruments for merit and name—
Merit and name, great or small, are established according to one’s station.
With authority so heavy, one cannot treat oneself lightly.
As *Zhuangzi* says: *"To treat one’s body lightly is to lose one’s state."*

To treat oneself lightly is to fail in merit and name.
There has never been a case where the body is not at ease yet the state is well-governed.

The Dao achieves the great through the small, the many through the few—
The resources of the great are but a single hair’s breadth.
The essence of the many is but a single hairpin’s length.

Thus, the Sage governs the world with the Dao:
The subtle and mysterious are seen as small,
The frugal and diminished are seen as few—
Seeing small, one achieves the great;
Seeing few, one achieves perfection.

The Dao achieves greatness through subtlety and mystery,
Virtue achieves beauty through diminishment and lack.

The Way of Heaven lowers the high and raises the low,
Diminishes the surplus and nourishes the deficient—
Like drawing a bow, where balance is key.
The rivers and seas occupy the world’s deficient places,
Thus all under Heaven return to them and honor them.

Therefore, the Sage maintains humility, modesty, stillness, and yielding—
This is to appear lowly,
To have an empty heart with nothing—
This is to appear deficient.
Following the example of the rivers and seas.

To appear lowly is to attain the high;
To appear deficient is to attract the virtuous.
The heart’s constant humility brings virtue’s ever-greater height;
The body’s constant retreat brings action’s ever-greater progress.

The proud cannot stand, the extravagant cannot endure.
The forceful perish, the overfull are destroyed.
Sudden winds and torrential rains do not last a day;
A shallow valley cannot fill in an instant.
The valley is narrow and confined—
If filled in an instant, it will overflow.
Sudden winds and torrential rains embody forceful *qi*,
Thus they cannot endure and are extinguished.
The shallow valley occupies forceful ground,
Thus it cannot avoid being seized.
Seize their return, honor their virtue.

Therefore, the Sage embraces the feminine and the yielding,
Abandons arrogance and excess,
Dares not act with forceful *qi*,
Following the warnings of Heaven and Earth.

Embracing the feminine, they establish the masculine;
Not daring to be extravagant, they endure long.
Only those who embrace the feminine
Can possess the virtue of standing firm.

Laozi says: *"The Way of Heaven reaches its extreme and reverses,
Fills and then diminishes—*
Like the sun and moon.
At noon, the sun declines;
When the moon is full, it wanes.

Thus, the Sage diminishes daily,
Daring not to be self-satisfied with clashing *qi*,
Advancing daily with the feminine,
Their merit and virtue never decay—
This is the Way of Heaven.

Advancing daily with the feminine means
Pushing softness to govern things.

The Way of Heaven diminishes the full and benefits the humble;
The Sage follows this law.
Thus, perfect virtue renews itself daily without replacement.

Human nature universally desires the high and rejects the low,
Desires gain and rejects loss,
Desires profit and rejects illness,
Desires honor and rejects disgrace,
Desires nobility and rejects lowliness—
All people act this way, yet cannot achieve it.
To grasp it tightly is to fail to obtain it.

Things naturally change and transform;
Their inherent patterns and forces are balanced.
If one waits for completion, success will come.
If one waits for completion, one will fail to obtain it.

Suppose those who hold such positions
Had already determined their proper measure—
Could they, through partial desires and rigid adherence, truly attain it?

Therefore, the Sage follows Heaven:
Achieving without action, obtaining without grasping,
Riding the natural course, thus succeeding with the times,
Gaining with things.

Aligning with people’s emotions yet differing in method,
They endure long.
Aligning in their desired ends,
Differing in their chosen paths,
Reversing their private loves and aversions,
Thus forming the virtue of enduring long.

Hence, the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors had warning vessels,
Called *yòuzhī*—
When empty, they stand upright;
When full, they overturn.
The details are recorded in *Zhōu Yǔ*.

Things flourish then decline,
The sun reaches its zenith and moves,
The moon is full then wanes,
Joy reaches its peak and sorrow follows.

Therefore, the keen and wise guard with stupidity,
The most discerning have no followers,
Hiding brilliance and blending with the multitude.
The well-read and eloquent guard with frugality,
Boasting of ability brings disgrace,
Holding back without loss.

The martial and courageous guard with caution,
Lightly treating enemies leads to defeat,
Cautiousness preserves victory.

The wealthy and expansive guard with restraint,
Arrogance and excess bring daily peril,
Humility and diminishment bring daily blessings.

Virtue bestowed upon the world is guarded with yielding,
Self-praise leads to ruin,
Promoting others ensures completeness—
These five virtues are how the ancient kings governed the world.

To hold the world is to reach the utmost.
If one clings to extreme desires while holding an extreme position,
Collapse will follow.
Without these five virtues, how could one guard it?

Those who follow this Dao
Do not desire fullness,

chunks.original_text: 盖顺中为常，如彼戒器者。 夫唯不盈，是以能弊不新成。 以谦虚之故弊，资道德之新成。 老子曰：圣人与阴俱闭，与阳俱开。 所谓大顺。 能至於无乐也，即无不乐也， 无可无不可，则常可矣。 无乐则常乐矣。 无乐，即至乐极矣。 言乐之所存，哀之所顺，唯忘所乐者，何待而不极焉。 是以内乐外，不以外乐内也， 内乐外者，我畅於物外； 乐内者，物变於我，故同於失者，失亦得之矣。 故有自乐也，即有自志，贵乎天下， 冥然万物之上，真自贵耳。 所以然者，因天下而为天下之要也，不在於彼，而在於我，不在於人，而在於身，身得则万物备矣。 自得者，天地万物莫不得？ 故达於心术之伦者，即嗜欲好憎外矣， 尽为弃物。 是故无所喜，无所怒，无所乐，无所苦，万物玄同，无非无是， 是非之伦生於爱恶，心既无矣，物自玄同，故不知所以遗，而是非都尽矣。 故士有一定之论，女有不易之行， 虽未忘所存，已得自安自道也。 不待势而尊，不须财而富，不须力而强，不利货财，不贪势名，不以贵为安，不以贱为危， 苟定其分，何所假待？ 形神气志，各居其宜。 四者同在，一安之道遂不至相反也。 且士女节操，尚能如是，而况圣人全德者乎？ 夫形者生之舍也， 居舍在形。 气者生之元也， 元本在气。 神者生之制也， 由制在神。 一失其位，则三者伤矣。 一失所养之位，则并伤之也。 故以神为主者，形从而利， 制之使不犯，故利也。 以形为制者，神从而害。 恣轻炀，充口腹则害。 贪叨多欲之人，颠冥乎势利，诱慕乎名位，几以过人之智位高於世，即精神日耗以远久，淫而不还，形闭中距，即无由入矣， 形以刚强为闭，中无和气为距。 是以时有盲忘自失之患。 夫外诱中募，久乃类冥。 往而不知归，资盲忘之患也。 夫精神志气者，静而日充以壮，躁而日耗以老。 神全则兼物，由其静也。 形困则支策，在其动也。 岂可失盛衰之节哉？ 是故圣人持养其神，和弱其气，平夷其形，而与道浮沉， 虽物之往来，莫不顺道也。 如此即万物之化，无不偶也，百事之变，无。 不应也。 与所化而合，与所变而通。 守朴 不加欲於性命之分，而浑乎变化之根，谓之朴也。 老子曰：所谓真人者，性合乎道也， 不自动用，与造化者为人。 故有而若无，实而若虚， 虽事物皆实，而真性不知所存也。 治其内不治其外， 未有内治而外欲者。 明白太素，无为而复朴， 夫无为之为亦朴矣，则体真之士静动亦出乎虚白之域。 体本抱神，以游天地之根， 体元气之本，抱变化之神，居物象之先也。 芒然仿佯尘垢之外，逍遥乎无事之业， 性离所污，直以无事为常。 机械智巧，弗载於心，审於无瑕，不与物迁， 审犹委也。 不载於心，复何瑕哉？ 则物之自迁，奚与同往耳？ 尝试论之，曰，且夫物也者，一时之所也。 向非今也，理不至迁矣。 而评世之士，定论之人，尚正彼形，不复随妄。 况乎性与道合，牵之遂流者哉？ 见事之化，而守其宗， 不与物迁之谓。 心意专於内，通达偶於一， 专气无杂，通而不异。 居不知所为，行不知所之， 无为无故。 弗学而知，弗视而见， 与物同和，与物自见。 弗为而成，弗治而辨。 顺天下而自成，随品类而自辨。 感而应，迫而动，不得已而往，
chunks.translated_text:
The essence lies in harmony within constancy—
Like the disciplined warrior’s tools.

Only by not being full
Does one endure without renewal.
Through humility and emptiness, decay occurs,
Yet this decay nurtures the renewal of virtue and power.

Laozi said:
*The Sage closes with the yin and opens with the yang—*
This is called the Great Harmony.

To reach the point of no delight
Is to attain the state of no discontent.
Neither approval nor disapproval,
Then constancy is achieved.

Without delight, there is eternal delight.
Without delight, the utmost delight is attained.
Where delight resides, sorrow follows—
Only those who forget their delight
Need no prompting to reach its peak.

Thus, inner delight transcends the external,
Not relying on external delight to fill the inner.
Inner delight transcends—
I am unrestrained beyond things;
Delight within—
Things conform to me,
And thus, even in loss, there is gain.

To possess self-delight is to possess self-will,
To be nobly above all things,
Unseen yet sovereign—
This is true nobility.

The reason for this is:
To govern the world by becoming its essential core,
Not in others, but in oneself,
Not in people, but in the body.
When the body is attained, all things are complete.

Those who attain themselves
Bring harmony to heaven, earth, and all things.
Thus, those who master the arts of the heart
Transcend external desires and aversions,
Abandoning all as discarded things.

Therefore, there is no joy, no anger,
No delight, no suffering—
All things merge in the Mysterious Unity,
Neither affirmation nor negation.
Judgment arises from love and hatred;
When the heart is empty, things naturally merge in the Mysterious Unity.
Thus, one does not know how to abandon,
And all distinctions are exhausted.

Therefore, the scholar has fixed principles,
The sage has unchanging conduct—
Though not forgetting their essence,
They attain self-contentment and self-Dao.

They do not rely on power to be honored,
Nor on wealth to be rich,
Nor on strength to prevail.
They do not covet goods or power,
Nor crave fame or status,
Nor take nobility as security,
Nor lowliness as peril.
If one’s place is fixed,
What need is there for external support?

Form, spirit, qi, and will
Each reside in their proper place.
The four coexist,
And the path of harmony
Thus avoids contradiction.

Even the scholar’s and sage’s moral integrity
Can be thus—
How much more so for the Sage of complete virtue?

The body is the dwelling of life,
Residing in the form.
Qi is the origin of life,
Rooted in essence.
The spirit is the governor of life,
By governance in the spirit.
If one loses its place,
The three are harmed.
If one loses the proper nourishment of its place,
All are harmed together.

Thus, those who take the spirit as master
Find the form benefiting accordingly—
Governed so as not to transgress,
Hence its benefit.
Those who take the form as governor
Harm the spirit.
Indulging in excess, overfeeding,
Harms the spirit.
The greedy, gluttonous, and desirous
Are blinded by power and wealth,
Tempted by fame and status—
Though their intelligence surpasses others,
Their spirit weakens with time,
Lost in excess without return.
The body becomes rigid, the center blocked—
No passage remains.

Rigidity of the form is closure,
Lack of harmonious qi is obstruction.
Thus, there are times of blindness and forgetfulness,
Self-loss.

External allure and internal depletion
Over time lead to obscurity.
Going forth without knowing the way back,
They suffer the affliction of blindness and forgetfulness.

Spirit and will—
When still, they grow daily stronger;
When agitated, they weaken daily, aging.
A full spirit encompasses all things—
This is due to stillness.
A constrained form falters—
This is due to movement.
How can one neglect the rhythms of flourishing and decline?

Thus, the Sage nurtures the spirit,
Harmonizes and weakens the qi,
Balances and levels the form,
And floats with the Dao.
Though things come and go,
All conform to the Dao.

Thus, the transformations of all things
Are without exception,
And all affairs
Are without resistance.
In harmony with what is transformed,
In accord with what changes.

To guard simplicity—
Not adding desire to the nature of life,
Yet encompassing the roots of transformation—
This is called simplicity.

Laozi said:
*The True Person*
Is one whose nature aligns with the Dao—
Not acting of oneself,
Yet in accord with the transformations of the world.

Thus, having yet appearing as nonexistent,
Substantial yet appearing as empty—
Though all things are real,
The true nature knows no abode.

Cultivating the inner without governing the outer—
There has never been one who governs the inner yet desires the outer.

Clarifying the Great Primordial,
Without action, returning to simplicity—
For without action, simplicity is achieved,
Then the virtuous in truth
Move and rest within the realm of emptiness and whiteness.

Embodying the origin, embracing the spirit,
Roaming the roots of heaven and earth—
Embodying the essence of primordial qi,
Embracing the spirit of transformation,
Residing before all things.

Vague and unassuming beyond dust and filth,
Adrift in the business of nothingness,
Separate from defilement,
Taking non-action as constancy.

Mechanical cleverness is not borne in mind,
Examined for flaws, unchanging with things—
*Examined* is also *abandoned*.
Not borne in mind, what flaws remain?
Then, as things move of themselves,
Why follow along?

Consider this:
Things are but a moment’s dwelling.
What was not is not now—
Logic prevents transformation.
Yet those who judge the world,
Who fixate on doctrine,
Still uphold their forms,
No longer following folly.
How much more so for those whose nature aligns with the Dao,
Drawn along effortlessly?

Seeing the transformations of things,
Yet guarding their origin—
This is called not conforming to things.

The heart and intention are focused inward,
Communing with the One through penetration—
Qi unified, unadulterated,
Penetrating yet unchanging.

Dwelling without knowing action,
Moving without knowing direction—
Without action, without cause.
Not learning yet knowing,
Not seeing yet perceiving—
In harmony with things, yet self-revealing.
Without doing, yet accomplished,
Without governing, yet discerning.
Following the world yet self-fulfilled,
Conforming to kinds yet self-distinguished.

Responding yet not compelled,
Acting yet not forced,
Moving only when unavoidable—

The Way/Dao is never first to begin.
Like light’s radiance, like shadow’s reflection,
A body of purity—clear yet illuminating,
Empty yet responsive.

Following the Dao as its measure,
Yet awaiting the natural unfolding—
To follow is to await;
This is but metaphorical speech.

Vast and empty within,
Clear and still without,
This is its true essence.

Taking myriad births as one transformation,
Countless differences as one origin—
To dwell in the origin is to align with it.

Qi refined yet unused,
Spirit potent yet not employed—
Unused yet aligned, this is called supreme refinement.
Unmoving yet penetrating, this is called supreme spirit.

Standing within the primordial Great Unity,
Firm in the center of supreme refinement—
Sleeping without dreams,
No fancies in mind.

Knowledge does not stir,
It does not precede things;
Movement is formless—
The traces of mysterious response are unseen.

Stillness is without substance,
Not resting upon something to establish stillness.
Existing yet as if nonexistent,
Living yet as if dead—
Not clinging to life or death,
Yet not without the marvelous use of spirit.

Entering and exiting without obstruction,
No hindrance to gold or stone.
Commanding ghosts and gods—
This is but the merging of spirit with emptiness.

Thus, the spirit can ascend to the Dao’s realm:
With virtue/power above, one may attain the supreme Dao?

To let the spirit flow freely,
Yet not stray from its source—
This is called recovering the essence of one’s nature.

Day and night without pause,
In harmony with things like spring’s breath,
Qi meeting all things without gap or breath.
This is the merging of times and life within the heart.

The heart does not generate itself;
It merges with times and thus generates.
Hence, form may fade while spirit never transforms—
Form aligns with things, so it transforms;
Spirit aligns with the Dao, so it endures.

With unchanging essence responding to change,
Endless transformations without cessation—
Fire and water’s functions cannot self-regulate,
Their kind is transformed yet cannot transform things;
The untransformed alone can transform.

With an unchanging essence transforming boundless things,
Thus it cannot be exhausted.

Transformation returns to the formless—
Things born each return to their root.
The untransformed arises with heaven and earth—
The Dao precedes the forms,
So the ever-arising never dies,
Its arising is death itself;
The transformer never transforms,
Its transformation is the thing itself.

The meaning has already been revealed above.
This is the true person’s play,
The pure Dao’s essence.

chunks.original_text: 宋宣义郎试大理寺主薄兼 括州缙云县合朱弁正仪注 符言篇 符者，契也。 言者，理也。 故因言契理之微，悟道忘言之妙，可谓与矣。 老子曰：道至高无上，至深无下， 上乎无上，下乎无下，故能高能深，能上能下也。 平乎准，直乎绳， 非衡能平，无处不夷。 非绳能直，无处不正。 圆乎规，方乎矩， 非圆能圆而无圆，非方能方而无方。 包裹天地，而无表里， 其大无外，其细无内。 洞同覆盖，而无所碍， 大圆无涯，大通无滞。 是故体道者，不怒不喜，其坐无虑，寝而不梦，见物而名，事至而应。 前已解。 老子曰：欲尸名者必生事，事生即舍公而就私， 尸主求名者必有事，事生即不和，故令去名而就公。 倍道而任已，见誉而为善，立名而为贤， 倍，背也。 背道祈誉，非善之善。 趋俗求名，非贤之贤也。 即治不顺理，而事不顺时，治不顺理则多责，事不顺时即无功， 顺理则用心寡，而成事大，逆时则用力多而见功鲜。 妄为要中，功成不足以塞责，事败足以灭身。 要誉立效，求合时君者，功未济物，败以及身也。 老子曰：无为名尸，无为谋府，无为事任，无为智主，藏於无形，行於无怠，不为福先，不为祸始， 动不为主则无形，无形故无将迎之福。 唱而方应则无怠，无怠故无未来之祸也。 始於无形，动於不得已，欲福先无祸，欲利先远害。 治未兆之事则为福，绝非常之利则无害也。 故无为而宁者，失其所宁即危，无为而治者，失其所治则乱。 失所宁者，谓舍内宁而外求宁，则固矣。 失所治者，谓遗身而求治人，则惑矣。 故不欲碌碌如玉，落落如石。 谓玉石分而争夺生。 其文好者皮必剎，其角美者身必杀，甘泉必竭，直木必伐。 物有美而见害，人晞名而召祸。 华荣之言后为愆， 先聘华词，后招身祸。 石有玉伤其山， 山不藏宝必见鉴，人不慎言必招祸。 默首之患固在言。 前黎民所以蒙祸、其妄议国家典法之言故也。 且君子攸戒，尚亦三缄，小人腾口，得不招祸也？ 老子曰：时之行，动以从，不知道者福为祸。 时之从，动以行，不知道者以福亡。 夫圣人治道，先知存亡，县料得失，故舒卷扉定，宠辱不惊，方获终吉以保其身。 至於昧者，多承福而作威，故福极而祸生。 非祸福相倾，乃动用之乖分耳。 天为盖，地为轸，善用道者，终无尽，地为轸，天为盖，善用道者终无害。 以天为盖覆无涯而皆善，以地为轸运无穷而莫害。 陈彼五行，必有胜， 金火相攻，衰王递作。 天之所覆无不称， 天道包弘各称。
chunks.translated_text:
**符言篇**

*符* is *contract*—*speech* is *principle*.
Thus, through speech’s subtle contract with principle,
One awakens to the Dao’s mystery beyond words—
This is the true accord.

Laozi says:
The Dao is supremely high, without surpassing;
Supremely deep, without descending.
Above, it transcends the highest;
Below, it descends to the lowest.
Thus it can be high and deep,
Ascend and descend.

Level as the plumb-line, straight as the square,
Not because the balance makes it level—
Everywhere it is even.
Not because the square makes it straight—
Everywhere it is true.

Round as the compass, square as the set-square,
Yet not round by being round—no roundness,
Not square by being square—no squareness.
It enfolds heaven and earth yet has no surface or depth,
Its vastness knows no outside, its subtlety no inside.
Piercing like a hollow dome, yet unimpeded,
Great circle without bounds, great passage without obstruction.

Thus those who embody the Dao:
Neither angry nor joyful,
Their sitting free of care, their sleep without dreams,
They name things as they see them, respond as events arise.
This was explained earlier.

Laozi says:
Those who crave fame as a corpse must create affairs,
And affairs, once born, abandon the public for the private.
Those who seek fame as lords must have affairs,
And affairs, once born, breed discord—
Thus one must abandon fame and return to the public.

To double the Dao and burden oneself,
To court praise and do good,
To establish a name and be deemed virtuous—
*Double* means *betray*.
Betraying the Dao to seek praise is not true goodness.
Chasing convention to gain a name is not true virtue.

Governance that defies principle brings many reproaches,
Actions that defy the times yield no merit.
To follow principle is to act with few concerns yet achieve great deeds;
To defy the times is to labor much yet see little fruit.
Falsely scheming for advantage—
When success fails to justify the effort,
When failure brings ruin—
Those who seek praise and immediate effect,
Who curry favor with the times—
Their unfinished works bring ruin upon themselves.

Laozi says:
Do not be a corpse for fame,
Do not be a treasury for schemes,
Do not be a burden for affairs,
Do not be a master of cleverness.
Hide in the formless, act without weariness,
Do not precede fortune, do not initiate calamity.
Move without being the master—then no form;
No form, then no fortune to welcome or ward off.
Respond as it is sung—then no weariness;
No weariness, then no future calamity.

Begin in the formless, act only when unavoidable.
To seek fortune first is to invite calamity;
To seek profit first is to court harm.
To govern before signs appear is to ensure fortune;
To cut off extraordinary gain is to avoid harm.

Thus those who act without doing—
If they lose their tranquility, they are in peril;
Those who govern without doing—
If they lose their order, they bring chaos.
To lose tranquility means to abandon inner peace for outer seeking—
Then rigidity ensues.
To lose order means to forsake self to govern others—
Then confusion follows.

Thus one should not be polished like jade,
Nor rigid like stone.
For jade and stone, once divided, spawn contention.
The finer the carving, the sharper the blade;
The finer the horn, the deadlier the strike.
Sweet springs run dry, straight trees are felled.
Things of beauty invite harm,
Men who court fame invite disaster.
Flowery words bring later regret—
First to flatter with eloquence,
Then to invite ruin upon oneself.
Stone may wound the mountain that hides it—
Mountains that do not conceal treasure are soon stripped bare,
Men who do not guard their words soon invite calamity.
The peril of silence lies in speech itself.

Earlier, the common folk suffered calamity
Because of their reckless debates on state laws and rites.

Moreover, the virtuous are warned thrice to hold their tongues,
While the petty chatter—
How could they avoid disaster?

Laozi says:
To act in accord with the times,
Move by following—
The unknowing turn fortune to calamity.
To follow the times,
Move by acting—
The unknowing lose fortune through it.

The sage’s governance:
Knowing beforehand life and death,
Measuring gains and losses,
Thus opening and closing doors with precision,
Unshaken by honor or disgrace,
Only then does one attain enduring safety and preserve the self.

As for the ignorant,
They often enjoy fortune then wield power,
Thus when fortune peaks, calamity arises.
It is not that fortune and calamity oppose each other—
Rather, their use is misaligned.

Heaven as a canopy, earth as a pivot—
Those who wield the Dao skillfully
Are never exhausted.
Earth as pivot, heaven as canopy—
Those who wield the Dao skillfully
Are never harmed.
To employ the five phases is to know their victories—
Metal and fire attack each other,
And declining kings rise in succession.

What heaven covers is never unsuited—
The Dao’s embrace is all-encompassing.

chunks.original_text: 故知不知，上； 不知知，病也。 知无知者善，不知强知者病也。 老子曰：山生金，石生玉，反相剥，木生虫，还自食，人生事，还自贼。 名显道丧，事起害生。 夫好事者未尝不中，争利者未尝不穷， 未有涉水不濡其足，蒙尘不垢其身。 善游者溺，善骑者堕，各以所好，反自为祸。 矜其能，丧厥功。 骋其伎，丧厥身也。 得在时，不在争，治在道，不在圣。 时会自得，不假力争。 道在自尊，何烦矜圣？ 土处下不争高，故安而不危，水流下不争疾，故去而不迟。 道之所贵，德之所尚，不争而高，不疾而速。 是以圣人无执故无失，无为故无败。 道无形状，不可把握，故执之则失。 又非形体，难以雕刻，故为之则败也。 老子曰：一言不可穷也，二言天下宗也，三言诸侯雄也，四言天下双也。 贞信则不可穷，道德则天下宗，举贤德，诸侯雄，恶少爱众，天下双。 兼得四句者，上为皇为帝，偏得一言，则下为霸为佐也。 老子曰：人有三死，非命亡焉。 言非命，人自取之也。 饮食不节，简贱其身，病共杀之； 乐得无已，好求不止，刑共杀之； 以寡犯众，以弱陵强，兵共杀之。 故死生在我，祸福无门。 匪降自天，职竞由人也。 老子曰：其施厚者其报美，其怨大者其祸深。 薄施而厚望，畜怨而无患者，未之有也。 察其所以往者，即知其所以来矣。 功高则报厚，怨深则息大。 随其轻重，遗之恩怨也。 老子曰：原天命，治心术，理好憎，适情性，即治道通矣。 原天命，即不惑祸福，治心术，即不妄喜怒，理好憎，即不贪无用，适情性，即欲不过节，不惑祸福，即动静顺理，不妄喜怒，即赏罚不阿，不贪无用，即不以欲害性，欲不过节，即养生知足。 凡此四者，不求於外，不假於人，反己而得矣。 明此四者，可谓大通。 不因於人，省己而已。 老子曰：不求可非之行，不憎人之非己， 无谲诈之行，人何非我？ 怀仁恕之情，我无尤人也。 修足誉之德，不求人之誉己， 自修己德，不求人誉。 不能使祸无至，信己之不迎也，不能使福必来，信己之不让也， 不能防不测之祸，信命不遗。 不能要必至之福，来者当受也。 祸之至，非己之所生，故穷而不忧，福之来，非己之所成，故通而不矜。 祸生非己，虽祸而何忧？ 福至非我，虽福而何恃也？ 是故闲居而心乐，无为而治。 恬泊优游而已。 老子曰：道者守其所已有，不求其所未得。 求其所未得，即所有者止，循其所有即所欲者至。 已有者一身之精神，未有者多方之伎术。 今废已有之精神，祈未得之方术，未得者夫至，所得者已忘。 不保得一之由，难追两失之悔。 故至人守其本，不寻其末； 贵得於内，不制於外也。 治未固於不乱，而事为治者必危； 行未免於无非，而急於名者必挫。 本固邦宁，周行不辱。 故福莫大於无祸，利莫大於不丧。 无祸之福，福之厚矣。 无丧之利，利之大矣。 故物或益之而损，损之而益。 唯无祸福，则无损益。 夫道不可劝就利者，而可以安神避害。 道者不可诱以利，无利则无害。 故神自安，道自来也。 故尝无祸不尝有福，尝无罪不尝有功。 无祸无福，无罪无功，是谓大通。 道曰芒芒昧昧，从天之威，与天同气，无思虑也，无设储也， 道曰，道君也，芒昧谓道窈冥不可得见。

「Thus, the knowing of the unknown is virtue; the knowing of the known is a flaw.
The knowing of the unknowing is beneficial, the knowing of the strong knowing is flawed.
Laozi says: Mountains produce gold, stones produce jade—
Yet they destroy each other in return;
Wood breeds insects that devour it,
Humans create affairs that betray them.
When fame is sought, the Dao is lost;
When schemes arise, harm is born.

Those who delight in matters never fail to be entangled,
Those who vie for profit never fail to be exhausted.
There is no crossing water without wetting one’s feet,
No passing through dust without staining one’s body.
Skilled swimmers drown, skilled riders fall—
Each meets ruin through their own pursuits.

Boast of one’s abilities and lose one’s merit,
Exploit one’s talents and lose one’s life.
Success lies in timing, not in strife,
Governance lies in the Dao, not in the sage.
Timing brings success without forced contention,
The Dao thrives in self-respect—why seek the sage’s praise?

Earth rests low yet does not contend for height,
So it remains secure without peril.
Water flows downward yet does not vie for speed,
So it departs without delay.
What the Dao values, what virtue esteems,
Is height without contention, speed without haste.

Thus, the sage holds nothing and loses nothing,
Acts without contrivance and meets no defeat.
The Dao is formless, elusive—
To grasp it is to lose it.
It is not a physical body,
Difficult to carve or shape—
Yet to force it is to invite ruin.

Laozi says: One word cannot be exhausted,
Two words make the world follow,
Three words command the feudal lords,
Four words sway the world.
Fidelity brings exhaustion’s end,
Virtue makes the world submit,
Promoting worthy virtue—
The feudal lords rise in power,
Loving the few while cherishing the many—
The world unites in harmony.
He who masters all four words
Ascends to emperorship,
He who gains but one
Descends to conquest or aid.

Laozi says: Humans have three deaths,
Not by fate alone.
Excess in eating and drinking
Diminishes the body—
Illness claims it;
Unchecked joy in gain
Pursues it endlessly—
Punishment claims it;
With few opposing many,
With weak defying the strong—
War claims it.
Thus, life and death depend on oneself,
Calamity and fortune have no fixed gate.
They do not descend from heaven,
But arise from human competition.

Laozi says: The greater the giving, the fairer the return,
The greater the grudge, the deeper the ruin.
Sparse giving yet high expectations,
Nurturing resentment yet hoping for no harm—
Such things do not exist.
Observe how one proceeds,
And one knows how they will return.
High merit brings rich reward,
Deep grudge invites great retribution.
Follow their weight—
Leave behind both debt and grace.

Laozi says: Trace the heavenly command,
Refine the heart’s art,
Balance likes and dislikes,
Align with nature’s flow—
And the Dao’s governance is complete.
Trace the heavenly command,
And one is undisturbed by fortune’s shift.
Refine the heart’s art,
And one does not err in joy or wrath.
Balance likes and dislikes,
And one does not greedily grasp the vain.
Align with nature’s flow,
And one’s desires do not exceed their bounds.
Undisturbed by fortune’s shift,
And one’s actions follow the natural order.
No erring in joy or wrath,
And one’s rewards and punishments are impartial.
Not greedily grasping the vain,
And one’s desires do not harm one’s nature.
Desires not exceeding their bounds,
And one knows how to nurture life with contentment.

These four principles,
Seek not from others, nor borrow from men,
But return within oneself to find.
Understanding these four,
One may call it great harmony.
Not relying on others,
Only self-refinement suffices.

Laozi says: Do not seek the blame of others,
Nor hate those who blame you.
Avoid deceitful actions,
And why would others blame you?
Hold within you compassion and forgiveness,
And you will have no cause to reproach others.
Cultivate the virtue of good reputation,
And do not seek others’ praise for yourself.
Refine your own virtue,
And do not seek others’ praise.
If you cannot prevent calamity from coming,
Trust in your own non-invitation of it.
If you cannot ensure fortune will arrive,
Trust in your own non-rejection of it.
If you cannot guard against unforeseen calamity,
Trust in fate’s unerring course.
If you cannot demand that certain fortune will come,
Receive what comes as it should.
When calamity arrives, it is not your own creation—
So even in ruin, why lament?
When fortune comes, it is not your own doing—
So even in gain, why rely?

Thus, dwell in ease and find joy in the heart,
Govern without contrivance.
Serene, content, and at leisure—
This is all.

Laozi says: The Daoist guards what they already possess,
And does not seek what they have not obtained.
Seeking what they have not obtained,
They lose what they already possess;
Clinging to what they possess,
They gain what they truly desire.
What they already possess is the spirit of their body,
What they lack are myriad external skills.
Now, abandoning the spirit of their body,
They pray for skills they have not yet attained.
The unattained may come,
But the spirit they once held is already forgotten.
Not safeguarding the path to one gain,
It is hard to regret the loss of two.
Thus, the perfect one guards their root,
And does not chase after superficial ends;
They value what is within,
And do not control what is without.

If governance is not yet firmly established in avoiding chaos,
Then those who strive for governance will surely perish.
If conduct cannot yet escape blame,
Then those who rush for fame will surely falter.
Root firm, the state is at peace,
Actions aligned, no shame is incurred.

Thus, no fortune is greater than avoiding calamity,
No profit is greater than not losing.
Fortune without calamity—
Fortune is indeed great.
Profit without loss—
Profit is indeed vast.

Thus, things may bring gain through loss,
Or loss through gain.
Only without calamity or fortune,
Is there no loss or gain.

The Dao cannot be coerced for profit,
Yet it can bring tranquility and avoid harm.
The Daoist cannot be lured by profit,
For without profit, there is no harm.
Thus, the spirit finds peace,
And the Dao comes naturally.
Thus, one who does not taste calamity will not taste fortune,
One who does not commit wrong will not earn merit.
Without calamity or fortune,
Without wrong or merit—
This is called great harmony.

The Dao says: Vague and obscure,
Following heaven’s majesty,
Harmonizing with heaven’s *qi*,
Without thought or planning,
The Dao says: The Dao is sovereign,
Vague and obscure—
The Dao’s depths are unfathomable, unseen.»

chunks.original_text: 今但法天以虚，为身以无，为心不虑而成，不劳而物积也。 来者不迎，去者不将， 任其自得。 人虽东西南北，独立中央， 身应物而无穷，道居中而独运。 故处众枉不失其直， 曲全故大。 与天下并流不离其域， 至气流转，真精常存。 不为善，不避丑，遵天之道，不为始，不专己，循天之理，不豫谋，不弃时，与天为期，不求得，不辞福，从天之则。 天无心，不言而万物生； 人无为，不谋而百事遂。 内无奇福，外无奇祸，故祸福不生，焉有人贼。 凡有福即有祸，今祸福已冥，孰为人贼害。 故至德，言同路，事同福，上下一心，无岐道，旁见者进退章之於邪，开道之於善，而民向方矣。 偏见不足以化俗，正道而可以诱民。 老子曰：为善即劝，为不善即观，劝即生责，观即生患。 劝，勉也。 观，察也。 夫人为善，当日自勉之。 有不善者，察见己过，则向方矣，是不勉其为善矣。 若以己为善，察求人之不善而责之者，则有患矣。 故劝为善而不善矣。 故道不可以进而求名，可以退而修身。 故圣人不以行求名，不以知见求誉，治随自然，己无所与。 进不饰智以求名，退而修身以自治，推之自然，岂晞人誉也？ 为者有不成，求者有不得，人有穷而道无通。 人有求而不得，道无为而自周。 有智而无为，与无智同功，有能而无事，与无能同功，有智若无智，有能若无能，道理达而人才灭矣。 夫志德内充，人才外灭者，故有若无，实若虚也。 人与道不两明，人爱名即不用道，道胜人则名息，道息人名章，即危亡。 道须一致，事不两全。 老子曰：使信士分财，不知定分而探筹，何则，有心者之於平，不如无心者； 使廉士守财，不如闭户而全封，以为有欲者之於廉，不如无欲者也。 探筹绝疑於无心，廉士见猜於有欲。 人举其疵则怨，鉴见其丑即自喜。 贤者举过而思改，愚者自媒而为善。 人能接物而不与己，即免於累矣。 先人后己，终身无咎。 老子曰：凡事人者，非以宝弊，必以卑辞，弊单而欲不厌。 君子不重宝，币服以谦敬，人能行一之，久而无厌也。 卑体免辞论，说而交不结。 约束誓盟，约定而反先日， 君子之交，不假结约，一言而定，终身不易。 小人之交，要以誓盟，未盈旬时，以违旧要也。 是以君子不外饰仁义而内修道术， 内秉真淳，外无虚饰。 修其境内之事，尽其地方之广，厉其民死，坚其城郭，上下一心，与之守社稷。 即为名者不伐无罪，为利者不攻难得，此必全之道，必利之理。 与民同利，民乐死之。 与民同心，民共守之。 求名者不贪滥，为利者不垂分。 此必全之道，即社稷共守、郊境同固也。 老子曰：圣人不胜其心，众人不胜其欲。 心胜则道全，欲胜则身危。 君子行正气，小人行邪气，内便於性，外合於义，循理而动，不击於物者，正一气也。 推於滋味，淫於声色，发於喜怒，不顾后患者，邪气也。 邪与正相伤，欲与性相害，不可两立，一起一废，故圣人损欲而从性。 目好色，耳好声，鼻好香，口好味，合而说之，不离利害嗜欲也。 耳目鼻口，不知所欲，皆心为之制，各得其所，由此观之，欲不可胜亦明矣。 六情所欲，一心为制。 气正於中，则欲不害性。 心衰於外，则伪己惑真。 故知衰正在我，与夺因心。
chunks.translated_text:
The present merely follows Heaven’s Way with emptiness,
For the body with non-action,
For the mind with no deliberation, thus complete—
Without labor, things accumulate naturally.

What comes is not welcomed,
What departs is not detained—
Let it be as it finds itself.
Though people move east, west, south, or north,
They stand alone at the center,
Their bodies respond to things yet endless,
The Dao abides within yet moves alone.

Thus, amid crookedness, they do not lose their straightness,
Their fullness lies in their bending.
Flowing with the world yet never straying from their domain,
The vital *qi* circulates and the true essence remains.

They do not seek virtue,
Nor shun ugliness—
They follow Heaven’s Dao,
Not initiating, not clinging to self,
They follow Heaven’s principle,
Not premeditating, not neglecting the moment,
They align with Heaven’s timing—
Not seeking gain, not rejecting fortune,
They conform to Heaven’s natural order.

Heaven has no mind,
Yet speaks not and all things arise;
Humans act without contrivance,
Yet plan not and all affairs succeed.
Within, no strange fortune,
Without, no strange calamity—
Thus, calamity and fortune do not arise,
And who would be a thief to others?

All who have fortune also have calamity,
Now that calamity and fortune are merged in obscurity,
Who would harm others?
Thus, supreme virtue:
Words align with the Way,
Actions align with fortune,
Hearts unite above and below,
No divergent paths—
Those with partial views advance or retreat in error,
Yet open the Way to virtue,
And the people turn toward it.

Partial views are insufficient to transform customs,
Yet the right Way can guide the people.
Laozi says:
To do good is to exhort,
To do evil is to observe—
Exhorting breeds blame,
Observing breeds affliction.
Exhortation is encouragement,
Observation is scrutiny.
When humans do good,
They should daily encourage themselves.
When there are evils,
They see their own faults and correct them,
Thus turning toward the right—
This is not encouraging others to do good.
If one takes themselves as good,
And scrutinizes others’ evils to blame them,
Then affliction arises.
Thus, exhorting to do good is itself not good.
Hence, the Way cannot be advanced to seek fame,
Nor can it be retreated to cultivate the self.

Thus, the Sage does not act to seek fame,
Nor does they use knowledge to seek praise—
Governance follows nature,
They contribute nothing of their own.
Advancing without embellishing wisdom to seek fame,
Retreating to cultivate the self to govern themselves,
Pushing through naturally—
How could they exhaust others’ praise?

The doer has what may not be completed,
The seeker has what may not be obtained—
Humans have limits, yet the Dao is unobstructed.
Humans seek yet do not obtain,
The Dao acts not yet encompasses all.
Wisdom without action,
Like lack of wisdom, yields equal results—
Ability without exertion,
Like lack of ability, yields equal merit.
Wisdom as if without wisdom,
Ability as if without ability—
The Way is realized while human talents fade.

When *virtue/power* fills within,
Human talents fade externally—
Thus, they have as if they lack,
And reality as if it were void.
Humans and the Dao cannot both be clear,
Humans who love fame cannot use the Dao,
The Dao surpassing humans, fame ceases—
Fame flourishes with humans, yet perishes with them.

The Dao must be unified,
Affairs cannot be fully dual.
Laozi says:
To make the faithful divide wealth,
Not knowing their fixed share yet probing the tally—
Why so?
The scheming mind of the faithful,
Is not as good as the mindless.
To make the virtuous guard wealth,
Is not as good as sealing the doors and keeping it whole—
For the desiring mind of the virtuous,
Is not as good as the desireless.
Probing the tally ends doubt with the mindless,
The virtuous see suspicion in the desiring.
Humans highlight their flaws, then harbor resentment,
Yet mirrors reveal their ugliness and they take pride in it.
The wise point out faults to prompt change,
The foolish adorn themselves and claim virtue.
Humans can receive things without appropriating them,
Thus free from burdens.
Prioritize others, then yourself—
A lifetime without fault.

Laozi says:
All who deal with others,
Either use treasures to corrupt,
Or humble words to ensnare—
Corruption is single, yet desires are insatiable.
The noble do not hoard treasures,
But use gifts and attire with humility and respect—
If others can act in accordance with one principle,
Long-term, they will not grow weary.
Humble bearing avoids reproach,
Persuasion without binding oaths—
Yet alliances and pacts,
Made with fixed terms yet broken before their time,
Are the way of the petty.
The noble’s exchange,
Requires no oaths or agreements—
A single word suffices,
A lifetime unaltered.

Thus, the noble do not externally adorn *virtue/power* and righteousness,
Nor internally cultivate false Daoist arts—
Internally, they hold true sincerity,
Externally, they display no hollow pretense.
They govern affairs within their domain,
Expand their territory’s breadth,
Strengthen their people’s loyalty unto death,
Fortify their cities and walls—
Hearts united above and below,
They defend the state together.
Thus, those who seek fame do not boast of meritless deeds,
Those who seek profit do not attack what is hard to obtain—
This is the Way that must be preserved whole,
The principle that must be advantageous.
Sharing profit with the people,
They gladly die for them.
Uniting hearts with the people,
They guard the state together.
Seekers of fame do not greedily overreach,
Seekers of profit do not arbitrarily divide—
This is the Way that must be preserved whole,
Thus the state is jointly defended,
And borders are firmly secured.

Laozi says:
The Sage does not conquer their own mind,
The common people do not conquer their own desires.
The mind conquers, the Way is whole,
Desires conquer, the body is in peril.
The noble act with upright *qi*,
The petty act with corrupt *qi*—
Internally, it suits their nature,
Externally, it aligns with righteousness—
They move according to principle,
And do not clash with things—
This is the harmony of one *qi*.
Indulging in flavors,
Excess in sounds and colors,
Outbursts of joy and anger,
Without regard for future consequences—
This is corrupt *qi*.
Corrupt and upright injure each other,
Desires and nature harm each other—
They cannot coexist,
One arises, the other declines—
Thus, the Sage diminishes desires and follows nature.

The eyes love colors,
The ears love sounds,
The nose loves fragrances,
The mouth loves flavors—
Alluring them together,
They never stray from desires for profit and harm.
Eyes, ears, nose, and mouth,
Ignoring what they truly desire,
All are controlled by the mind—
Each finds its place—
From this, it is clear that desires cannot be conquered.

The six senses’ desires,
Are all governed by one mind.
*Qi* upright within,
Then desires do not harm nature.
The mind weakened externally,
Then falsehood deceives the true self.

Thus, one knows that weakening and uprightness lie within,
And gain or loss depend on the mind.

chunks.original_text: 且一心自正，群物何累也？ 老子曰：治身养性者，节寝处，适饮食，和喜怒，便动静，内在己者得， 言不外求。 而邪气无由入，饰其外伤其内，扶其情者害其神，见其文者蔽其真。 夫须臾忘为贤者，必困其性， 言人贤不可暂忘，若须臾离之，必受困辱。 百步之中忘其为容者，必累其形。 夫辅身御性，必宜节饮全和，使必气内平而神明可保。 君子慎微，不在於远，虽十步之内，必虑朽株之患； 须臾之间，卒过非意之事。 安可怠哉？ 故羽翼美者，伤其骸骨，枝叶茂者，害其根荄，能两美者天下无之。 翡翠以文彩见害，春华以芳菲见折。 物有双美，事能兼济，未之有也。 老子曰：天有明，不忧民之晦也，地有财，不忧民之贫也。 天之道，明照大闳，至幽能察； 地之利，有於万物，广济无边也。 至德道者若丘山块然不动，行者以为期，直己而足物，不为人赐，用之者亦不受其德，故安而能久，天地无与也，故无夺也，无德也，故无怨也。 至人者，势名不能动，欲害不能倾，块然独处，岿然山峙，以其常足，不受赐与，脱其所取，辄亦无让。 故与之不得，夺之无怨，故能长久也。 善怒者必多怨，善与者必善夺，唯随天地之自然而能胜理。 超喜怒之域，忘与夺之情，任之自得，以全天理也。 故誉见即毁随之，善见即恶从之，利为害始，福为祸先，不求利即无害，不求福即无祸，身以全为常，富贵其寄也。 誉者，人之所美善者，人之所慕。 但不欲显，显则有毁有怨。 非待绝善，誉将无怨。 若不矜不伐，自然无祸无福，道德自全。 全身为常，富贵若寄也。 老子曰：圣人无屈奇之服，诡异之行，服不杂，行不观， 服不惊众，行不异人。 通而不华，穷而不慑，荣而不显，隐而不穷，异而不乖， 穷通，命也，故不华不慑。 荣隐，时也，故不显不辱。 虽异於人，何足怪也？ 同用无以名之，是谓大通。 用无则无滞，是为大通也。 老子曰：道者直己而待命，时之至，不可迎而返也，时之去，不可追而援也，故圣人不进而求，不退而让。 正身俟命，直道从时，不将不迎也。 随时三年，时去我走，去时三年，时在我后，无去无就，中立其所。 此言先之大过，后之不及，唯迎之无前，随之无后，独立其中，而安其所也。 天道无亲，唯德是与。 福之至，非己之所求，故不伐其功，祸之来，非己之所生，故不悔其行。 前已释也。 中心其恬，不累其德， 非誉不能垢，宠辱不能惊 狗吠不惊，自信其情，诚无非分。 自明无非，故不惊惧。 故通道者不惑，知命者不忧。 知道知命，何忧何惧？ 帝王之崩，藏骸於野，其祭也祀之於明堂，神贵於形也， 言古帝王归骸於野，不封不树，示民有终； 祀神明堂，不谄不滥，示民知严也。 故神制形则从，形胜神则穷，聪明虽用，必反诸神，谓之大通。 依神形全，纵欲神逝，自非明达，莫能保之。 老子曰：古之存己者，乐德而忘贱，故名不动志，乐道而忘贫，故利不动心，是以谦而能乐，静而能澹。 道德备身，贫贱无耻，心志不亏，名利不惑。 故能谦之乐矣，静而澹然也。 以数集之寿，忧天下之乱，犹忧河水之涸，泣而益之也。 故不忧天下之乱，而乐其身治者，可与言道矣。 谕人不忧寿之将尽，而忧天下之不治，是犹泣数滴之泪，欲增洪河之流，无益之谓也。
chunks.translated_text:
「Yet when the heart itself remains upright,
Why should the myriad things weigh upon it?

Laozi says:
*"Those who govern the body and nurture their nature*
*restrict their sleep and dwellings,*
*moderate their food and drink,*
*harmonize their joys and angers,*
*adapt to movement and stillness,*
*find fulfillment within themselves,*
*and speak without external seeking.*
*Thus, perverse qi finds no entry,*
*but adornment of the exterior harms the interior,*
*and bolstering one’s emotions damages one’s spirit.*
*Those who see its form are blinded to its truth.*

*He who forgets his virtue for even a moment,*
*will surely constrain his nature.*
*Laozi says: "A virtuous person cannot forget his virtue,*
*for even a moment’s departure*
*will bring suffering and humiliation."*

*He who forgets his beauty within a hundred paces,*
*will surely burden his form.*

*"To support the body and command the nature,*
*one must properly moderate consumption*
*and preserve harmony,*
*so that inner qi may remain balanced*
*and the spirit may be preserved.*

*The gentleman guards the subtle—*
*not in distant things,*
*but even within ten steps,*
*he considers the peril of decaying logs;*
*in the blink of an eye,*
*an unintended misstep may occur.*
*How can one afford such negligence?*

*Thus, those whose feathers and wings are splendid*
*risk harm to their bones and flesh,*
*and those whose branches and leaves flourish*
*endanger their roots and stems.*
*None in the world can possess both beauties.*

*The jade phoenix is harmed by its very colors,*
*and the spring blossom is broken by its very fragrance.*
*Things may have dual beauties,*
*but affairs cannot be fully reconciled—*
*such is not found.

Laozi says:
*"Heaven has brightness,*
*yet does not worry over the people’s darkness,*
*Earth has wealth,*
*yet does not worry over the people’s poverty.*
*The Dao of Heaven,*
*illuminates the vast and the obscure,*
*penetrating even the deepest depths.*
*The Earth’s abundance,*
*permeates all things,*
*extending boundless aid to all."*

*One who embodies the utmost virtue and the Dao*
*stands firm as a mountain,*
*unmoved—*
*the acting take him as their model,*
*he remains true to himself,*
*sufficient unto all things,*
*yet does not accept gifts from others,*
*nor do those who use him claim his virtue,*
*thus he remains stable and enduring,*
*Heaven and Earth cannot surpass him,*
*thus he suffers no loss,*
*no virtue is claimed,*
*thus no resentment arises.*

*The supreme person*
*is unaffected by external influence,*
*cannot be toppled by desires and harm,*
*stands alone like a mountain,*
*unshaken—*
*with his constant sufficiency,*
*he does not accept gifts or favors,*
*and when he takes what is his,*
*he does not apologize.*

*Thus, if one gives to him, it cannot be retained,*
*and if one takes from him, there is no grievance,*
*so he is able to endure forever.*

*Those skilled in anger invite many resentments,*
*those skilled in giving invite taking.*
*Only by following Heaven and Earth’s natural spontaneity*
*can one master the principles of life.*

*Beyond the realm of joy and anger,*
*forgetting the emotions of giving and taking,*
*letting things unfold naturally,*
*one preserves the fullness of Heaven’s Dao.*

*Thus, praise appears, and blame follows,*
*kindness appears, and cruelty follows,*
*benefit becomes harm,*
*and fortune becomes disaster—*
*if one does not seek benefit,*
*then there is no harm,*
*if one does not seek fortune,*
*then there is no disaster.*
*Preserve the body whole as one’s constant,*
*for wealth and honor are but transient lodgings.*

*Praise is what others admire and covet.*
*Yet if one does not wish to display it,*
*display invites both blame and resentment.*
*It is not that one must utterly abandon virtue,*
*but rather that without arrogance or self-aggrandizement,*
*one naturally avoids both misfortune and fortune,*
*and virtue and the Dao remain intact.*
*Preserve the body whole as one’s constant,*
*for wealth and honor are but transient lodgings.*

Laozi says:
*"The Sage wears no strange or ostentatious garments,*
*nor performs eccentric or bizarre actions.*
*His attire is simple, his conduct unadorned,*
*his garments do not startle the masses,*
*his actions do not deviate from the common way.*
*He is open yet not showy,*
*humble yet not intimidated,*
*honored yet not ostentatious,*
*obscure yet not confined,*
*unique yet not contrary.*
*Open and humble are his fate,*
*thus he is neither showy nor intimidated.*
*Honored and obscure are the times,*
*thus he is neither flaunted nor humiliated.*
*Though he differs from others,*
*what is there to find strange in that?*
*His use is universal,*
*yet cannot be named—*
*this is called the Great Harmony.*

*When there is no use,*
*there is no obstruction—*
*this is the Great Harmony.*

Laozi says:
*"The Dao is to be true to oneself*
*and await one’s fate.*
*When time arrives,*
*one cannot force it forward,*
*when time departs,*
*one cannot chase it backward.*
*Thus the Sage does not advance to seek,*
*nor retreat to yield.*

*Upright in body, awaiting fate,*
*following the Dao in truth,*
*not leading nor following—*
*within three years, time arrives,*
*and I go with it;*
*within three years, time departs,*
*and I remain behind.*
*No going, no coming,*
*balanced in its place.*

*This speaks of the excess of hastening forward*
*and the deficiency of lagging behind—*
*only by meeting time can one have no past,*
*and by following it can one have no future,*
*standing independent within,*
*and finding peace in one’s place.*

*The Dao of Heaven favors none,*
*it bestows only upon virtue.*
*When fortune comes,*
*it is not what one sought,*
*so one does not claim its merit.*
*When disaster arrives,*
*it is not what one created,*
*so one does not regret one’s actions.*
*This has already been explained.*

*Let the heart be serene,*
*and do not burden one’s virtue,*
*for then neither praise nor blame can soil it,*
*nor can honor or humiliation disturb it.*
*Dogs bark, yet it does not startle—*
*self-trusting in one’s nature,*
*truly without transgression.*
*Self-illuminating, without fault,*
*thus no fear nor dread.*

*Thus, those who understand the Dao are not confused,*
*and those who know fate are not anxious.*
*To know the Dao and know fate,*
*what anxiety or fear remains?*

*When the sovereign dies,*
*his remains are buried in the wild,*
*yet his spirit is enshrined in the Hall of Light—*
*the spirit is nobler than the form.*
*It is said that ancient sovereigns*
*returned their remains to the wild,*
*neither sealed nor planted,*
*to show the people that all must end;*
*enshrining the spirit in the Hall of Light,*
*without flattery nor excess,*
*to show the people that reverence must be known.*

*Thus, when the spirit governs the form,*
*it prospers,*
*but when the form overpowers the spirit,*
*it falters.*
*Though wisdom and insight are employed,*
*they must ultimately return to the spirit—*
*this is called the Great Harmony.*

*Rely on the spirit to preserve the form,*
*indulge desire and the spirit will fade,*
*yet none but the enlightened*
*can guard it thus.*

Laozi says:
*"The ancients who preserved themselves*
*rejoiced in virtue and forgot disgrace,*
*thus their names did not sway their resolve,*
*rejoiced in the Dao and forgot poverty,*
*thus benefit did not sway their hearts.*
*Hence they could be humble and yet joyful,*
*quiet and yet unperturbed.*

*Virtue and the Dao complete the body,*
*poverty and disgrace bring no shame,*
*the heart and resolve remain unbroken,*
*names and benefits cause no confusion.*
*Thus they could find joy in humility,*
*and remain tranquil in stillness.*

*With few concerns, they gathered their years,*
*yet they worried over the world’s disorder,*
*as one might worry over the drying of the Yellow River,*
*weeping to increase its flow.*
*Thus, they did not worry over the world’s disorder,*
*but rejoiced in the harmony of their own lives—*
*such can speak of the Dao.*

*It is folly to teach others*
*not to fear the end of their years,*
*yet to fear the world’s disorder,*
*as if one could add but a few drops of tears*
*to swell the vast river’s current—*
*useless indeed.»

chunks.original_text: 唯忘治人而治其身，可与言乎道。 老子曰：人有三怨，爵高者人妬之，官大者主恶之，禄厚者人怨之。 高而能卑，厚而能散，自保元吉也。 夫爵益高者意益下，官益大者心益小，禄益厚者施益博，修此三者怨不作。 故贵以贱为本，高以下为基。 二者不修，殃及己身。 老子曰：言者所以通己於人也，闻者所以通人於己也。 言己情以达人情，得人意以通己意。 既暗且聋，人道不通，故有暗聋之病者，莫知事通，岂独形骸有暗聋哉，心亦有之塞也， 目不睹太山，耳不闻雷霆，此形骸之暗聋。 有鉴疑鹿马，智昏菽麦，此人之暗聋也。 即事不辩，况大道哉？ 莫知所通，此暗聋之类也。 夫道之为宗也，有形者皆生焉，其为亲也亦戚矣，飨谷食气者皆寿焉，其为君也亦惠矣，诸智者学焉，其为师也亦明矣。 生以道为亲，无形而形焉，其为亲也大矣。 谷与气为君，非寿而寿焉，其为惠也厚矣。 智以学为师，非师而师焉，其明至矣。 人皆以无用害有用， 勤无用之事，伤有涯之情。 故知不博而日不足， 君子常以所知未远，渴日不足以自勉励也。 以博奕之日问道，闻见深矣。 移博奕之功，而专道德，可致深妙矣。 问与不问，犹暗聋之比於人也。 不闻不问，是谓暗聋之人也。 老子曰：人之情，必服於德，不服於力， 可以德制，不可以力争也。 德在与不在来。 德施於人，不望来报。 是以圣人之欲贵於人者，先贵人，欲尊於人者，先尊人，欲胜人者先自胜，卑人者先自卑，故贵贱尊卑，道以制之。 夫古之圣王，以其言下人，以其身后人，即天下乐推而不厌，戴而不重，此德重有余而气顺也，故知与之为取，后之为先，即几於道矣。 尊人者非尊其人，而取尊，先人者非先其人而取先，是气顺於道，德归诸己，故推而不厌，戴而不重也。 老子曰：德少而宠多者讥，才下而位高者危，无大功而有厚禄者微，故物或益之而损，或损之而益。 才藏不称讥危，必至损益相随，祸福斯验者也。 众人皆知利利，而不知病病，唯圣人知病之为利，利之为病。 众人知利为利，不知以利为病。 圣人知利是病，以不病为利也。 故再实之木，其根必伤，掘藏之家，后必有殃。 夫大利者反为害，天之道也。 木之再成者必伤其根，家藏宝货者必殃其身。 谓非意而得者，先利后害，天之道也。 老子曰：小人从事日苟得，君子日苟义。 为善者非求名者也，而名从之，名不与利期，而利归之，所求者同，所极者异。 小人从事，以苟得为利，利从而害之。 君子直道，不以利为期而名归之。 故受利同而遇害异也。 故动有益则损随之。 言无常是，得无常宜者，小人也。 不恒其德，或承之羞。 察於一事，通於一能，中人也。 所见不周，拘於一域。 兼覆而并有之，技能而才使之者，圣人也。 默奸去哀，任贤使能，此圣人也。 老子曰：生所假也，死所归也，故世治即以义卫身，世乱即以身卫义，死之日，行之终也。 世治即以义保身，世乱即以身死义。 故君子有益於人，虽杀身不恨。 故视死若归，犹生之年也。 故君子慎一用之而已矣。 依道而行，动不乖正。 故生受於天也，命遭於时也，有其才不遇其世，天也，求之有道，得之在命。 遇时也，不遇天也，得之不喜，失之不怨也。

「Only those who forget the governance of others and focus on governing themselves can truly speak of the Dao.

Laozi said: *"People have three grievances: those with high rank are envied by others, those with great office are despised by their lord, and those with abundant wealth are resented by the people."* Yet, if one can be humble despite high rank, generous despite great wealth, they preserve their innate good fortune. For when rank grows ever higher, their intentions become ever lower; when office expands ever greater, their heart grows ever smaller; when wealth thickens ever more, their giving becomes ever broader. Cultivating these three virtues, resentment will not arise.

Thus, nobility finds its foundation in humility, and height finds its base in lowliness. If these two are not cultivated, calamity will fall upon oneself.

Laozi said: *"Speech is the means by which one conveys themselves to others, and hearing is the means by which others convey themselves to one."* Expressing one’s own sentiments to reach others’ hearts, and grasping others’ intentions to align with one’s own. If one is both deaf and blind, the Dao cannot pass through them. Therefore, those afflicted with deafness and blindness—whether of body or of mind—cannot know the way of harmony. The eyes that fail to see the great mountains, the ears that do not hear the thunderous peals, are the deafness and blindness of the flesh. But those who mistake a mirror for a deer or a horse, whose wisdom is clouded by beans and grains, are the deafness and blindness of the mind. If one cannot discern even ordinary matters, how much less can they grasp the great Dao? Those who do not know what to convey are of the kind afflicted with deafness and blindness.

The Dao is the ultimate principle: all things with form arise from it, yet it remains their closest kin—nourished by the Dao, they take form. Those who eat of the grains and breathe the *qi* live long, yet the Dao is their true sovereign—granting life without form. All who learn wisdom draw from it, yet the Dao is their ultimate teacher—bestowing knowledge without instruction. The Dao is their parent, their lord, and their master.

People generally harm what is useful by clinging to what is useless. They labor at vain pursuits, injuring the emotions that have bounds. Thus, knowledge that is not broadened leaves one perpetually wanting. The noble one often reflects that their understanding is yet insufficient, and they strive daily to better themselves. If one spends their days on games of chance yet seeks the Dao, their insights will be profound. But if one shifts the labor of games of chance to focus solely on *virtue* and the Dao, they may attain even greater depths.

Asking and not asking differ as much as deafness and blindness separate one from others. Those who neither hear nor ask are truly the deaf and blind of the world.

Laozi said: *"Human nature must submit to virtue, not to force. One can be governed by virtue, not by coercion."* Virtue comes or does not come from without. Virtue given to others does not await their return. Therefore, the sage who wishes to be honored by others first honors others; who wishes to be revered by others first reveres others; who wishes to overcome others first overcomes themselves. The lowly one who humbles others first humbles themselves. Thus, nobility and humility, reverence and lowliness—all are governed by the Dao.

The ancient sage-kings spoke to others in humility, yet they led by example. Even if all under heaven joyfully followed them without tiring, and revered them without wearying, it was because their virtue was abundant and their *qi* aligned with the Dao. Hence, they knew that giving is taking, and following is leading—thus approaching the Dao itself.

To honor others is not to honor their persons, but to take honor; to lead others is not to lead their persons, but to take precedence. This is the *qi* aligning with the Dao, and virtue returning to oneself. Thus, they are followed without weariness, and revered without burden.

Laozi said: *"Those with little virtue yet much favor are scorned; those with inferior talent yet high position are in peril; those with no great deeds yet abundant wealth are despised."* Thus, things may sometimes bring gain yet cause loss, or loss yet bring gain. Talent hidden without proper display invites scorn and danger, and such must inevitably follow loss and gain in turn—this is the verification of fate.

The common folk all know what is profitable as profit, yet they do not know that what is harmful can be profit, and what is profitable can be harm. The common folk know profit as profit, yet they do not know that profit can be harm. The sage knows that profit is harm, and that what is not harm is true profit.

Thus, the twice-cut tree will surely wound its roots, and the hoarding family will surely face ruin. Great profit often turns to harm—that is the Way of Heaven. The tree that is felled twice will be wounded at its roots, and the family that buries treasure will face calamity upon itself. These are things gained not by intention—first profit, then harm—that is the Way of Heaven.

Laozi said: *"The petty man acts daily for mere gain, the noble man acts daily for righteousness."* Those who do good are not seeking fame, yet fame follows them; fame does not align with profit, yet profit returns to them. Their aims are the same, but their ends differ. The petty man acts for gain, and profit brings them harm. The noble one follows the Dao, not seeking profit, yet fame comes to them. Thus, they receive the same profit yet face different harms.

Therefore, beneficial action is inevitably followed by loss. Speech that lacks constancy brings no lasting truth, and those who gain without constancy are petty men. They do not uphold their virtue steadfastly, and may later suffer shame for it. To excel in one matter and master one skill is mediocrity. Their vision is not comprehensive, and they are confined to one domain. To cover all and possess all, to employ all abilities and talents—that is the sage. Silent of deceit, free of sorrow, they entrust virtue to the worthy and employ ability to the capable.

Laozi said: *"Life is borrowed, death is returned. Thus, in times of order, one protects righteousness with their life; in times of chaos, one protects their life with righteousness. On the day of death, the way is fulfilled. In times of order, one safeguards their life with righteousness; in times of chaos, one sacrifices their life for righteousness."* Therefore, the noble one benefits others, and even death does not bring regret.

Thus, they regard death as returning home—no different from the years of life. Therefore, the noble one is cautious only in their singular use of this life.

To act in accordance with the Dao is to move without deviating from the right path. Hence, life is received from Heaven, and fate is met with time. One may have talent yet not encounter the age, which is Heaven’s doing. To seek it has a method, and to attain it lies in fate. To meet the time is fortune; to not meet Heaven is misfortune. When they gain, they do not rejoice; when they lose, they do not resent.

chunks.original_text: 君子能为善，不必得其福，不忍而为非，未必免於祸。 君子为善未必要福，去非未能远祸，终不舍义以求福。 易行而脱祸，何则？ 如是性不可草，心苟无二故也。 故君子逢时即进，得之以义，何幸之有； 不时即退，让之以礼，何不幸之有。 故虽处贫贱而犹不悔者，得其所贵也。 君子进不以为幸，义得之也。 不遇不以为耻，悔何有焉？ 所存道义，岂苦贫贱哉？ 老子曰：人有顺逆之气，顺逆之气生於心，心治则气顺，心乱则气逆，心之治乱在於道德。 得道则心治，失道即心乱。 心治即交让，心乱即交争，让即有德，争即生贼。 有德即气顺，贼生即气逆。 一其心则顺而正，二其气即逆而邪。 正则道隆，邪则害生。 道存则神清，清则和治，贼生则气浊，浊则争乱。 既浊且乱，亡无日矣 气顺则自损以奉人，气逆则损人以自奉。 二气者可以道而制也。 难以事消，可以道制。 天之道其犹响之报声也，德积则福至，祸积则怨至。 人能行之，天能鉴之，善恶心臻，有如影响。 官败於官茂，孝衰於妻子，患生於忧解，病甚於且愈，故慎终如始，即无败事也。 官败失於正法，孝衰匿於私房。 忧虽暂解，犹虑患生，病虽且愈，仍宜节欲。 故慎终如始，则无败事也。 老子曰：举枉与直，如何不得。 举直与枉，勿与遂往，所谓同污而异泥者。 知人不易，举人必明。 今举枉为直，以愚为贤，岂有同污而异泥也？ 老子曰：圣人同死生，愚人亦同死生。 圣人之同死生，明於分理，愚人之同死生，不知利害之所在。 圣人一死生，不利彼此，故无死生。 愚人异死生，利在得失，故沦死生。 道县天，物布地，和在人，人主不和，即天气不下，地气不上，阴阳不调，风雨不时，人民疾饥。 道系於天，物产於地，中和在人。 人者，天之精也，地之灵。 故为人之主，必和洽其气，安抚万物，则风雨不愆，灾害不作也。 老子曰：得万人之兵，不如闻一言之当，得隋侯之珠，不如得事之所由，得和氏之璧，不如得事之所适。 一言有益，万兵非贵。 一事可尊，和璧非宝。 天下虽大，好用兵者亡，国虽安，忘战者危。 故小国寡民虽有什伯之器而勿用。 大国莫若修德，小国莫若事人，则征伐不兴，上下安泰也。 老子曰：能成霸王者，必胜者也； 非道不御。 能胜敌者，必德者也， 非德不胜。 能用人力者，必得人心者也， 用贤者之力，得众人之心也。 能得人心者，必自得者也，自得者，必柔弱者也，能胜不如己者，至於若己者而格，柔胜出於若己者，其事不可度，故能以众不胜成大胜者，唯圣人能之。 唯保谦柔众不能胜，故能成其胜也。 通玄真经卷之四竟 通玄真经卷之五

「The noble one may act in virtue without necessarily receiving blessings, nor avoid wickedness to escape misfortune. To do good does not always bring fortune, nor does abstaining from evil always prevent calamity—yet they never abandon righteousness to seek blessings. Why? Because their nature cannot be reckless, and their heart remains undivided.

Thus, the noble one advances when the time is right, attaining blessings through virtue—what greater fortune could there be? When the time is not ripe, they retreat, yielding with propriety—what greater misfortune could there be? Therefore, though they dwell in poverty and low estate, they still regret nothing, for they hold what is truly precious.

To advance is not to rejoice in fortune, for virtue is their gain. To fail is not to feel shame, for what cause is there to repent? Their devotion lies in the Dao and righteousness—how could they suffer from mere poverty?

Laozi said: *"One has the qi of compliance and resistance, which arises from the heart. When the heart is orderly, the qi flows in compliance; when the heart is disordered, the qi resists. The heart’s order or chaos lies in virtue/power (德). To gain the Dao is to order the heart; to lose the Dao is to disorder the heart. An ordered heart brings mutual yielding; a disordered heart brings mutual contention. Yielding is virtue/power; contention breeds thievery. Virtue/power brings compliant qi; thievery spawns resistant qi. To unify the heart is to comply and remain upright; to split the qi is to resist and become perverse. Uprightness elevates the Dao; perversity invites harm.

When the Dao endures, the spirit is clear, and clarity brings harmony. When thievery arises, the qi becomes turbid, and turbidity brings contention and chaos. Once turbid and chaotic, destruction comes without delay.

Compliant qi leads one to self-sacrifice for others; resistant qi leads one to harm others for self. The two qi can be governed by the Dao. What cannot be resolved by deeds can be regulated by the Dao. Heaven’s Dao is like the echo that answers sound—virtue accumulated brings blessings, and misdeeds accumulated bring resentment. If humans act in accordance, Heaven can discern it; good and evil intentions are revealed as clearly as reflections in water.

Corruption arises from flourishing corruption; filial piety wanes when children and wives are neglected. Troubles stem from easing worries too soon; illness worsens when desires are unchecked. Thus, one must be as cautious at the end as at the beginning, lest affairs fail.

Corruption fails due to deviation from proper law; filial piety declines when hidden in private matters. Though worries may temporarily ease, one must still fear their recurrence; though illness may briefly abate, restraint of desires remains essential. Therefore, to be as cautious at the end as at the beginning ensures no failure in affairs.

Laozi said: *"To lift the crooked and make it straight—how could one not gain? To lift the straight and make it crooked, do not comply, lest you share their filth yet differ in your mud."* To know others is difficult; to judge them must be clear. Now, if one lifts the crooked as if it were straight and takes the foolish for the wise, how could they share filth while differing in mud?

Laozi said: *"The sage and the fool share death and life. The sage’s sharing of death and life lies in their understanding of distinctions; the fool’s lies in their ignorance of gain and harm. The sage unifies death and life, neither favoring nor harming either, so they transcend death and life. The fool separates death and life, fixated on gain and loss, thus falling into death and life.

The Dao originates from Heaven, things are produced by Earth, and harmony resides in humans. Heaven’s qi does not descend, Earth’s qi does not ascend, yin and yang are unbalanced, winds and rains come untimely, and the people suffer from sickness and famine when the ruler is not harmonious.

The Dao is rooted in Heaven, things are born from Earth, and harmony lies in humans. Humans are Heaven’s essence and Earth’s spirit. Therefore, to rule as a sovereign, one must harmonize the qi, settle all things, and then winds and rains will not err, and calamities will not arise.

Laozi said: *"To command a hundred thousand soldiers is not as valuable as to hear a single fitting word; to possess the Lord of Hui’s pearl is not as precious as to know the reason for its acquisition; to hold the Heirloom Jade is not as prized as to know the proper use of it. A single beneficial word outweighs a hundred thousand soldiers; a single fitting action surpasses the Heirloom Jade and Lord of Hui’s pearl. Though the world be vast, those who delight in warfare perish; though a nation be secure, those who forget war are in danger. Therefore, small states with few people, though they possess myriad implements, do not use them. Great states do no better than to cultivate virtue/power; small states do no better than to serve their people—then conquest and warfare do not arise, and all ranks dwell in peace.

Laozi said: *"Those who can become hegemons or kings must be victors; yet they do not oppose without the Dao. Those who can defeat enemies must possess virtue/power; yet without virtue/power, they cannot prevail. Those who can use others’ strength must win their hearts—employing the wise to gain the people’s loyalty. Those who win others’ hearts must also attain self-mastery; self-mastery comes from yielding to those stronger than oneself, yet overcoming those equal or weaker. The victory of yielding surpasses the strength of those equal or weaker—this cannot be measured by ordinary means. Thus, only the sage can use the many’s inability to achieve great victory by preserving humility and yielding.

Only by preserving humility and yielding can one overcome what the many cannot. Thus, they achieve their great victory.

*End of Volume Four*
*End of Volume Five of the *Tongxuan Zhenjing* [通玄真经]*」
