「The *Master of Literature* from the Song dynasty, **Zhu Bian**, who held the posts of **Chief Clerk of the Grand Court of Justice** and **Magistrate of Jinyun County, Kuizhou**, now annotates the *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* chapter.

The **Dao/Way** is the inherent principle that pervades all things; **virtue/power** is the comprehensive name for all that is acquired. Moreover, the *Wenzzi* [《文子》] has a total of twelve distinct chapters, yet only the *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* is repeated—why is this so?

The **Dao/Way of virtue/power** is the same as the **Dao/Way that can be applied to things**; the virtue/power that arises from what can be spoken of is also the virtue/power that can be relied upon. But this is not the **Ultimate Dao/Way** or the **Mystic Virtue/Power**. Therefore, the first chapter is titled *Dao/Way’s Origin* [《道原》], and the latter *Supreme Virtue/Power* [《上德》]. The former refers to the **root of the Dao/Way**, while the latter denotes the **peak of virtue/power**—this chapter serves as the bridge between the two.

The essence of **Dao/Way and virtue/power** lies in returning to their natural origins. In the human world, to practice the **Dao/Way**, establish virtue/power, cultivate one’s self, and refine one’s reputation—while living with purpose and dying without decay—there is none like this chapter.

The *Wenzzi* inquires about the **Dao/Way**. The **Dao/Way** transcends learning; the ultimate principle cannot be questioned. What is queried here is the **Dao/Way of analogical reasoning**.

Laozi said: *"If one does not master learning and inquiry, one cannot deeply grasp the Dao/Way."* Those who study seek to restore their innate nature. By indulging in inquiry, one becomes receptive to answers; by cultivating learning, one reaches the state of *wu xue* [无学, "beyond learning"]. If one does not master this, how can they fathom the profound essence?

For those who listen, the aim is to attain **enlightened wisdom**—the wisdom of the **sage-philosopher**. To cultivate **conduct**—the practice of **benevolence and righteousness**. To achieve **merit and reputation**—the merit of a **worthy minister**. If one does not refine their learning, they will not understand; if they do not delve deeply, they will not grasp. Refined learning leads to clarity; deep inquiry leads to comprehension. Thus, the **superior scholar** listens with **spirit**, the **middle scholar** with **mind**, and the **inferior scholar** with **ear**.

The **superior scholar** comprehends the **Dao/Way** to attain **enlightened wisdom**; the **middle scholar** appreciates the **Dao/Way** to cultivate **conduct**; the **inferior scholar** wanders in the **Dao/Way** to gain **reputation**. Listening with the **ear** means learning is superficial; listening with the **mind** means learning penetrates to the muscles; listening with the **spirit** means learning reaches the marrow. Shallow and deep are relative.

Thus, if one does not listen deeply, their understanding will not be clear; if their understanding is unclear, they cannot exhaust its precision; if they cannot exhaust its precision, their actions will not be sincere. If one does not listen deeply, they lack present clarity—this is the unexcelled state.

He who does not comprehend within yet acts sincerely without has never been heard of. The principle of listening is to maintain a **vacant and tranquil mind**, diminish one’s **qi** without excess, meaning to **subdue one’s passions to align with the Dao/Way**. To have **no thought, no deliberation**, to **avoid random sight**, and to **avoid indiscriminate hearing**—to restrain both inner and outer faculties and uphold its intent.

To focus and accumulate with precision, to merge one’s inner intentions fully—once obtained, one must **steadfastly preserve** it and **sustain it enduringly**. To concentrate on what is gained, to have **no divided or wandering thoughts**, then the **nature of clarity** will naturally encompass all principles, exhausting their subtleties. Things cannot alter it; it will always be in harmony with the times.

The **Dao/Way** is the **origin of all things**, giving rise to what has **beginning** and **form**. It begins with **softness and weakness**, yet culminates in **firmness and strength**. It begins as the **Mother of the Dao/Way**, all **qi** being soft and weak; it manifests in **substance and quality**, where nature becomes firm and strong. It begins with **fewness and brevity**, yet becomes **abundance and length**.

Thus, **eternal generation** is not few, making it **abundant**; **sustaining life** is not brief, making it **enduring**. A hundred-foot tree begins as a sapling; a thousand-step terrace starts with its foundation. This is the **Dao/Way of Heaven**.

The **sage** follows it. The **Dao/Way** encompasses the small to make it great; Heaven pairs the lowly to make them high. Observing its **beginning** and its **completion**, one can **revere the subtle origin**. Therefore, the **sage** follows it.

The **humble** lowers themselves to **gain elevation**; they **honor the lowly** to **attain reverence**. The **retiring** step back to **lead ahead**; they **avoid conflict** to **secure precedence**. The **frugal** embrace **smallness** to **achieve breadth**; their **modest use** leads to **abundance**. The **self-restrained** desire **less** to **attain greatness**; their **cultivation of virtue/power** makes them **vast**.

This is the **Dao/Way of Heaven** fulfilled. The **Dao/Way of Heaven** diminishes excess and benefits humility; the **sage** conforms to it, naturally achieving **universal benefit**.

The **Dao/Way** is the **precedent of virtue/power**; from the **substance of the Dao/Way**, virtue/power is realized. It is the **root of greatness**, the **origin of the Two Polarities** [《两仪》]. It is the **gateway to fortune**, the **means of tranquility**. All things await it to **generate**, await it to **complete**, await it to **rest**.

They all rely on **nothingness** for this. The **Dao/Way** is **non-action** and **formless**; it does not precede things or leave traces in phenomena. Internally, it cultivates the self; externally, it governs others. When **achievement and conduct** are established, it becomes **neighboring with Heaven**.

He who practices the **Dao/Way** can **act without doing** yet **accomplish all things**—this meaning has already appeared in the *Dao/Way’s Origin* chapter. Few know its precision; its precision is most true, and within it lies **faith**. It responds to **sensations** and arrives naturally—is this not **faith**?

When the **Son of Heaven** [天子] possesses the **Dao/Way**, the **world submits**, and his **reign endures**. The **Dao/Way** is to **adapt to one’s station** and **harmonize accordingly**. Thus, **Emperor Yao** and **Emperor Shun** [尧舜] had it, and their **supreme virtue/power** could be praised. **King Tang** and **King Wu** [汤武] had it, and their **divine achievements** were immortal.

This is the **Dao/Way that can be spoken of**—is it not so? When the **feudal lords** [诸侯] possess the **Dao/Way**, their **people live in harmony**, and they **do not lose their states**. In ancient times, the **feudal lords** had their **states**.

When the **scholar-officials and commoners** [士庶] possess the **Dao/Way**, they **preserve their lives** and **protect their kin**. The **strong and mighty** with the **Dao/Way** **conquer without war**; the **type of Jin and Chu** [晋楚], who possessed the **Dao/Way**, became **hegemons**—not through **outmaneuvering enemies** to **achieve victory**.

The **weak and small** with the **Dao/Way** **gain without contention**; the **type of Cao and Wei** [曹卫], who possessed the **Dao/Way**, found **allies**—not through **taking the lead** to **secure their position**.

When undertaking **actions** with the **Dao/Way**, **achievement is realized**, and **fortune is attained**. Those who **conform to the times** will see their **achievements**; those who **cultivate what is upright** will receive their **fortune**.

Between **ruler and minister**, the **Dao/Way** manifests as **loyalty and benevolence**—」

chunks.original_text: 君惠臣忠。 父子有道即慈孝， 父慈子孝。 士庶有道即相爱， 无相夺伦，理自容爱。 故有道即和，无道即苛。 夫各正性命，则异俗可和。 苟踰位分，则骨肉自虐。 而有家有国不本道者，不其殆哉？ 由是观之，道之於人，无所不宜也。 小大之用皆可。 夫道者，小行之小德福，大行之大德福，尽行之天下服，服即怀之。 随器而受酌焉不竭。 夫能尽是道者，天下执不归之也。 故帝者，天下适之也，王者，天下往之也。 适往一也，皆归德之辞。 然适者通谓性命之所安，往者不得已就耳。 取其会理，优劣乃殊。 天下不适不往，不可谓帝王。 有位而无德，非此宜也。 故帝王者不得人不能成，得人失道，亦不能守。 既因兆人以成其位，则独任於己，其可守乎？ 夫失道者，奢泰骄佚，慢倨矜傲，见余自显，执雄坚强作难结怨为兵，主为辞首， 此举失道之状。 小人行之，身受大殃， 以至於刑戮耳。 大人行之，家国灭亡， 侯伯失国，卿大夫即亡家也。 浅及其身，深及子孙。 故罪莫大於无道，怨莫深於无德，天道然也。 无道者逆于天，无德者暴於物。 理为罪怨之首耳。 老子曰：夫行道者，使人虽勇，刺之不入，虽巧，击之不中。 夫能制彼气敌，善应机端，道者之中，盖有此小术之用。 夫刺之不入，击之不中，而犹辱也， 虽不我伤，而能攻辱，亦皆已显矣。 未若使人虽勇不敢刺，虽巧不敢击。 谦柔自守，则勇所未陵。 出处无机，则巧者不及。 夫不敢者，非无其意也， 未能使彼之无意。 未若使人本无其意。 将无屈奇之服，诡异之行，浩然无得，与彼同波，则天下之人何意加此也。 夫无其意者，未有爱利之心也。 未能使彼之心，而反爱利於我。 不若使天下丈夫女子，莫不欢然皆欲爱利之， 夫道者之功极，则天下攸归，物得而利。 故虽县解外患，亦未足称。 为以反同众流，游杂庶类，以我为利爱之主，待我於性命之场，我无所存，将自化妙，可言其至矣。 若然者，无地而为君，无官而为长，天下莫不愿安利之， 自昆虫已上，莫非愿就利者，故不待位地而可君长天下。 故勇於敢即杀，勇於不敢即活也。 勇於击刺者，心杀於彼。 勇於柔弱者，道活於物矣。 文子问德，老子曰：畜之养之，遂之长之，兼利无择，与天地合，此谓之德。 夫人之生也，形与物接，心与事交，固不可暂无损益於外矣。 唯内忘爱恶，迹绝利害，则能御群物而不抑，涉万方而成化。 苟非此道，利不兼焉。 能使乎物，得以宜。 夫加暴，则各失全性之惠，岂合德於一仪也。 何谓仁？ 曰：为上不矜其功，为下不羞其病， 未能退。 於大不矜，於小不偷，兼爱无私，久而不衰，此之谓仁。 非夫至性，安可久而不衰？ 故贤圣难之以称五教之首也。 何谓义？ 曰：为上即辅弱，为下即守节，达不肆意，穷不易操，一度顺理，不私枉挠，此之谓义。 理正也。 一，常也。 顺正以为常度，不容私挠，乃可存终矣。 何谓礼？ 曰：为上即恭严，为下即卑敬，退让守柔，为天下雌，立於不敢，设於不能，此之为礼。 所谓内和外饰，非止揖让登降也。 故修其德即下从令，修其仁即下不争，修其义即下平正，修其礼即下尊敬，四者即修，国家安定。 故物生者道也，长者德也，爱者仁也，正者义也，敬者礼也。

The ruler shows benevolence, the minister displays loyalty. Between father and son, the **Dao/Way** manifests as **filial piety and parental kindness**—the father is kind, the son is filial.

For the common folk, the **Dao/Way** means mutual love, without transgressing proper order, and harmony arises naturally. Thus, the **Dao/Way** brings harmony; its absence brings harshness.

When each upholds their **nature and vital essence (xìngmìng)**, even differing customs can be harmonized. If one oversteps their proper station, even kin will turn cruel. How then can families or states without the **Dao/Way** avoid ruin?

From this, it is clear that the **Dao/Way** is universally applicable—whether in small or great matters, it is always fitting.

The **Dao/Way** brings small virtue and small blessings to those who practice it slightly, great virtue and great blessings to those who practice it greatly, and universal submission when practiced fully. Submission leads to affection. Adapt to circumstances and draw from it without exhaustion.

Those who fully embody the **Dao/Way** will have all under Heaven willingly submit to them. Thus, the **Son of Heaven (Emperor)** is what all under Heaven naturally turn toward, while the **King** is what all under Heaven willingly follow. Though "turn toward" and "follow" may seem similar, they differ in essence—one is the natural alignment of **nature and vital essence**, the other is compelled necessity. Examining their principles, their superiority or inferiority becomes clear.

Without natural alignment or willing submission, one cannot be called an **Emperor** or **King**. To hold a position without virtue is unfit.

Thus, **Emperors and Kings** cannot succeed without the people, nor can they endure if they lose the **Dao/Way**. Having relied on the masses to establish their rule, they must then depend solely on themselves—how can this be sustained?

Those who abandon the **Dao/Way** indulge in extravagance, arrogance, and insolence. They flaunt their excesses, cling to rigid strength, provoke enmity, and lead armies. They take the blame while others reap the credit—this is the state of one who has strayed from the **Dao/Way**.

When the common folk act thus, they bring ruin upon themselves—even to execution. When the great act thus, their families and states perish, and nobles lose their domains, while ministers lose their households. The harm may begin with themselves but extends to their descendants.

Thus, no crime is greater than abandoning the **Dao/Way**, and no resentment is deeper than lacking virtue—this is the **Way of Heaven**.

Those without the **Dao/Way** defy Heaven; those without virtue oppress all things. Logic dictates that crime and resentment stem from this.

**Laozi** said: *"The practitioner of the **Dao/Way** makes even the boldest hesitate to strike, and the most skilled fail to hit their mark. They can restrain hostile **qi**, skillfully respond to circumstances, and master the subtle arts of the **Dao/Way**."*

Even if one does not strike or hit, if they still suffer humiliation—though unharmed, they are attacked with insults—this is already evident. It is better to make even the boldest dare not strike, the most skilled dare not hit. Through humility and gentleness in self-preservation, boldness cannot overstep. Without provoking conflict, even the cunning cannot prevail.

If they do not dare, it is not that they lack intent, but that they cannot make others lack intent. It is better to make others naturally lack such intent.

If one abandons eccentric displays and strange conduct, embracing boundless naturalness and blending with others like waves, then who under Heaven would harbor ill intentions toward them?

If others lack such intent, it is because they have no desire for gain or harm. It is not that one can make others’ hearts turn toward themselves, but rather that all under Heaven—men and women alike—willingly embrace them with affection and benefit.

The ultimate function of the **Dao/Way** is to make all under Heaven willingly submit, and all things find their benefit. Thus, even if external threats are repelled, this is still insufficient.

True mastery lies in blending with the masses, mingling with the common folk, making oneself the source of their love and benefit, and standing in the realm of **nature and vital essence**—without personal ambition, yet naturally transforming into the wondrous. This is the pinnacle of the **Dao/Way**.

Such a one needs no title to rule, no office to lead—all under Heaven, from insects upward, naturally seek what benefits them. Thus, without position or authority, they can govern all under Heaven.

Boldness in daring leads to killing; boldness in restraint leads to life. Boldness in striking and piercing kills in the heart; boldness in gentleness and weakness preserves all things through the **Dao/Way**.

**Wénzǐ** asked about **virtue (dé)**, and **Laozi** replied: *"Nurture and nourish, guide and grow—comprehensively benefiting without partiality, aligning with Heaven and Earth. This is called **virtue**."*

Human life inherently interacts with things externally and engages with affairs internally—harmony with the outside world is unavoidable. Only by internally abandoning love and hatred, and externally transcending gain and loss, can one govern all things without suppression, and transform the myriad realms without obstruction. Without this **Dao/Way**, comprehensive benefit is unattainable.

To act violently is to lose the inherent harmony of **virtue**—how can one align with **virtue** in a single act?

What is **rén (仁, benevolence)**?
*"For the ruler, not to boast of achievements; for the subjects, not to shame their flaws—this is not yet complete. Toward the great, not boastful; toward the small, not stingy. Universally loving without partiality, enduring without decay—this is **rén**."*

Only the most refined **nature** can sustain this without decay. Thus, the wise and sagely find it difficult to rank as the foremost of the Five Teachings.

What is **yì (义, righteousness)**?
*"For the ruler, to assist the weak; for the subjects, to uphold principle. In prosperity, not to overstep; in adversity, not to abandon resolve. Aligning with the **Dao/Way** and principle, without private deviation or perversion—this is **yì**."*

**Principle** is correctness. **Unity** is constancy. To make correctness and constancy the standard, without allowing private deviation, is the only way to endure.

What is **lǐ (礼, ritual/propriety)**?
*"For the ruler, to be reverent and dignified; for the subjects, to be humble and respectful. Retreating, yielding, and maintaining gentleness—being the feminine complement to Heaven under Heaven. Standing firm in what one does not dare, establishing what one cannot—this is **lǐ**."*

This is not merely bowing and ascending in rank. It is inner harmony and outer decorum.

Thus, cultivating **virtue** makes the subjects obey; cultivating **rén** makes the subjects not contend; cultivating **yì** makes the subjects fair; cultivating **lǐ** makes the subjects respectful. When all four are cultivated, the state is stable.

**Life** is the **Dao/Way**; **growth** is **virtue**; **love** is **rén**; **correctness** is **yì**; **respect** is **lǐ**.

「If one does not nurture and provide, one cannot fulfill the growth of all.
If one lacks kindness and love, one cannot achieve completion.
If one does not uphold correctness and rectify, one cannot endure long.
If one does not show respect and honor, one cannot attain nobility and worth.

Thus, **virtue** is what the people hold dear—
when **virtue** can secure them, none under Heaven do not cherish their safety.
**Rén** is what the people cherish—
all things and emotions naturally gravitate toward its benevolent love.
**Correctness (Yì)** is what the people fear—
when there is no private gain, none do not fear what is upright.
**Ritual/Propriety (Lǐ)** is what the people revere—
when dignity and order are observed, none do not respect and honor it.

These four are the harmonious principles of civilization,
the means by which the **Sage** governs all things.
If one does not align with the proper order of civilization,
then myriad emotions arise chaotically,
and governance becomes impossible.

A **gentleman** without **virtue** invites resentment from his subjects—
for suppressing their nature, resentment arises.
Without **rén**, contention arises among the subjects—
for lacking benevolent care, they contend.
Without **correctness**, brutality arises among the subjects—
for overstepping their proper boundaries, they become violent.
Without **ritual/propriety**, disorder arises among the subjects—
for losing the proper sequence of conduct, they rebel.

When these four principles are not established,
it is called having no **Dao/Way**.
Not perishing is rare indeed.

**Laozi** said:
In the age of **ultimate virtue (至德)**, merchants find profit in trade,
farmers take joy in the fields,
great officials fulfill their duties with ease,
scholars cultivate their **Dao/Way**,
and common people delight in their occupations.

Thus, winds and rains do not destroy or break,
plants and trees do not wither and die—
**virtue** extends to all things,
so **Heaven (天)** and **Earth (地)** harmonize,
and all living beings fulfill their natural growth.

The **Yellow River** gave rise to the *Tuguan* (河图),
the **Lu River** to the *Shushu* (洛书).
But as the age declined,
taxes and levies became excessive,
slaughters and punishments knew no end,
and those who offered counsel were killed—
the **Sage** and the worthy were slain.
Thus, mountains crumbled and rivers dried up,
creatures moved restlessly without cease,
the wilds lacked even a hundred stalks of grain.
Poisonous vapors seeped into the people,
and resentment festered below—
when **qi** rebels against **Heaven** and defies the natural order,
disasters and famines emerge.

Thus, when the age is well-ordered, even the foolish cannot act alone in disorder,
and when the age is chaotic, even the wise cannot govern alone.
The efficacy of the **Sage** and the worthy cannot override the **Dao/Way** of the times.

Therefore, the **Sage** maintains harmony, pleasure, and tranquility—
this is **life**.
They never grow anxious or restless to the detriment of their natural **virtue/power**.

When one’s **aspirations (志)** align with **Dao/Way** and action,
this is **fate (命)**.
Because they understand **fate**, they find peace in both adversity and prosperity.
Thus, **life** encounters **fate**, and only then can one act,
**fate** meets with the right **time (时)**, and only then can one discern its meaning.
When **fate** aligns with **Dao/Way** and proper action,
and the **time** is favorable,
then success is achieved.

There must be the right age,
before there can be the right person.
If the **time** lacks a **clear-minded ruler (明王)**,
then the **Sage** and the worthy have no place to stand.

Thus, the *Chapter on the Nine Guardians (九守篇)* states:
Without the right age, who could succeed?

**Wénzǐ** asked about **Sage**ly wisdom,
and **Laozi** replied:
To hear and know is **Sage**ly;
to see and know is wise.
The **Sage** knows through the **heart (心)**,
the wise know through the **eyes (目)**.

Thus, the **Sage** always observes where misfortune and blessing originate,
and chooses their **Dao/Way** accordingly—
by selecting the **Dao/Way** of tranquility and guarding it,
they avoid becoming the cause of calamity.

The wise always perceive misfortune and blessing in their formed states,
and choose their actions accordingly—
by selecting the **Dao/Way** of uprightness and caution and cultivating it,
they can preemptively block the seeds of disorder.

The **Sage** understands the **Dao/Way** of **Heaven** and its auspicious and inauspicious signs,
and thus knows where misfortune and blessing originate—
the **Sage** knows that **lack (不足)** brings auspiciousness,
while **excess (有余)** brings inauspiciousness,
for these are the sources of misfortune and blessing.

Thus, to guard tranquility is not to act first—
the **Sage** does not initiate disturbance.
The wise perceive the signs of misfortune and blessing in advance,
and thus know the gates through which they arise.
The wise are not confused by their initial growth,
and so they avoid sudden and irreversible calamity.

To hear before it arises is **Sage**ly,
to see before it forms is wise,
and to have neither hearing nor seeing is foolish.

**Laozi** said:
If a ruler loves knowledge,
they will trust the **time** and rely on themselves,
abandoning **fixed principles (数)** in favor of thought alone.
This means trusting the age that confounds them,
using it as their own understanding;
discarding the inevitable **fixed principles**,
and employing only what thought can grasp.

Knowledge is vast, yet wisdom is shallow—
to govern the vast with shallow wisdom is impossible.
Relying solely on one’s knowledge,
one will often fail in what is certain.

The **Dao/Way** of things has many proper courses,
but wisdom has limits—
thus, one cannot govern all,
and many failures ensue.
Loving knowledge is the **Dao/Way** of exhausting one’s arts,
loving courage is the **Dao/Way** of peril and ruin.
The **Dao/Way** that exhausts one’s arts
is the **Dao/Way** that leads to ruin.

To love giving is to have no fixed boundaries—
because they love giving, they lack constancy.
If the ruler’s boundaries are not fixed,
then the subjects’ expectations know no end—
when the ruler bestows gifts without measure,
the subjects hope endlessly in vain.
If taxes and levies are excessive,
then the ruler becomes the enemy of the people,
and heavy burdens invert the **Dao/Way** of joy in distribution,
thus resentment begins as enmity.

To take little and give much—
this is impossible in practice.
A tax of one-tenth (十一而税)
would still fail to meet the unending demands of the state.

Thus, to love giving is the **Dao/Way** that invites resentment.
To distribute wealth unevenly among the people
causes resentment among the officials,
and to impose heavy taxes on the people
causes resentment among the soldiers.
From this, it is clear:
When wealth is insufficient to fulfill its duties,
the **Dao/Way** and principles can be illuminated by reflection.

**Wénzǐ** asked:
How did the ancient **rulers** govern the world with the **Dao/Way**?

**Laozi** replied:
Hold to **Oneness (一)**, do nothing—
follow the transformations of **Heaven** and **Earth**.

To hold to **Oneness** means to hold to nothing.
To do nothing means to dare not act.
If one remains thus unassumingly,
then they follow the natural disposition of things and govern accordingly,
and what could be more fitting than to align with **Heaven** and **Earth**,
sharing in their transformations?

The world is a great instrument—
it cannot be seized, nor can it be forced.
To seize is to lose it,
to force is to ruin it.
To be able to manage one thing well,
one must fail in managing myriad things.
To hold to one disposition,
one must lose the myriad dispositions of all things.

To hold to **Oneness** is to see the small—
not to bear even the weight of a blade of grass,
is this not humility and modesty?
To see the small is to achieve the great.
And when one does not bear the weight of anything,
yet relies on others to succeed,
then they achieve even greater governance.
To do nothing is to guard stillness—
meaning they do not initiate action.
By guarding stillness, they can set the world aright.

Those who love action
injure the natural disposition of things.
Thus, to follow the great **Dao/Way** of the world,
and move with the transformations of the **Way**,
then all things find their proper place,
and their nature is naturally rectified.»

Thus, cultivating **virtue** makes the subjects obey; cultivating **rén** makes the subjects not contend; cultivating **yì** makes the subjects fair; cultivating **lǐ** makes the subjects respectful. When all four are cultivated, the state is stable.

chunks.original_text: 处大满而无溢，居高贵而无骄。 见小守静，故无骄溢。 处大不溢，盈而不亏，居上不骄，高而不危。 夫道然也。 盈而不亏，所以长守富也； 高而不危，所以长守贵也。 富贵不离其身，禄及子孙，古之王道，期於此矣。 唯上此道，可立天下也。 老子曰：民有道所同行，有法所同守， 皆慕义道而惧典法。 义不能相固，威不能相必，故立君以一之。 民不能永固所义，专必所畏，故立君以齐一之也。 君执一即治，无常即乱。 乱生於无恒之政也。 君道者，非所以有为也，所以无为也。 治道贵静，岂先物为？ 因民为而化之，亦非以为也。 智者不以德为事， 以政治之德为己之能事者，非君上之智也。 勇者不以力为暴， 以威势之力而为暴雷者，非人君之勇也。 仁者不以位为惠， 以露天个之位而为己惠者，非王者之仁也。 可谓一矣。 备此三者乃谓执一。 一也者，无适之道也，万物之本也。 清静守一，动而不知。 万物宗本，不出於是。 君数易法，国数易君， 数易法度，民不堪命。 国之无本，君能久乎？ 人以其位，达其好憎，下之径衢，不可胜理。 天子恃尊以位，不约所欲，任达好憎之性，因成取舍之私。 法令滋彰，下多岐路，不可胜理也。 故君失一，其乱甚於无君， 夫无君之时，犹义以相扶，咸以相服。 以其不能固乃立主之。 今君反为乱阶，则不如无君矣。 君必执一，而后能群矣。 文子问曰：王道有几？ 老子曰：一而已矣。 得一而已。 文子曰：古有以道王者，有以兵王者，何其一也？ 曰：以道王者，德也； 以兵王者，亦德也。 上以道得，下以义得。 用兵有五； 有义兵，有应兵，有忿兵，有贪兵，有骄兵。 诛暴拯弱，谓之义； 敌来加己，不得己而用之，谓之应； 争小故 故事。
chunks.translated_text:
To dwell in fullness yet overflow not,
to reside in nobility yet be free from arrogance.
To see the small and guard stillness,
thus there is no arrogance or overflow.

To dwell in fullness without spilling,
abundant yet never deficient;
to reside above without arrogance,
elevated yet never perilous.
For the **Dao/Way** is thus.

Abundant yet never deficient,
this is how one endures lasting wealth;
elevated yet never perilous,
this is how one endures lasting nobility.

Wealth and nobility do not depart from their person,
blessings extend to descendants.
The ancient **Way** of kings,
aspired to this alone.

Only by attaining this **Way**,
can one establish the world.

**Laozi** said:
"The people have the **Dao/Way** they follow in common,
and laws they uphold in common,
all revering the **Way** of righteousness,
yet fearing the **Way** of statutes and punishments.

Righteousness cannot secure them,
nor can awe compel them,
thus a ruler is established to unify them.

The people cannot forever uphold what is righteous,
nor can they concentrate on what they fear,
thus a ruler is established to standardize and unify them.

A ruler who holds to **Oneness** is ordered,
who deviates from constancy is in chaos.
Chaos arises from governance without constancy.

The **Way** of the ruler is not to act,
but to act without acting.

Governance values stillness—
why act before things?
To guide the people by their nature and transform them,
this too is not to act.

The wise do not use **virtue/power** for personal gain,
but those who use the **virtue/power** of governance
as their own true capacity,
these are not the wisdom of a sovereign.

The brave do not use force for violence,
but those who wield coercive might
as violent thunder,
these are not the courage of a ruler.

The benevolent do not use rank as favor,
but those who grant the **Way** of Heaven
as personal benefit,
these are not the kindness of a king.

This may be called **Oneness**.
To embody these three is to hold to **Oneness**.

**Oneness** is the **Way** without partiality,
the root of all things.
Pure and still, guarding **Oneness**,
they move yet remain unaware.
All things trace back to their root,
and do not depart from this.

A ruler who frequently alters laws,
a nation that frequently replaces rulers—
frequent changes in laws and measures,
the people cannot endure.
A nation without roots,
how long can a ruler endure?

By their rank, people express their likes and dislikes,
the common path of the lower orders,
too numerous to govern.
The Son of Heaven relies on his eminence
to grant rank without restriction,
indulging the nature of likes and dislikes,
and thus fostering private inclinations.

Laws and edicts proliferate,
the lower orders follow many divergent paths,
too numerous to govern.

Thus, when a ruler loses **Oneness**,
his chaos exceeds that of a nation without rulers.
For when there is no ruler,
the people still uphold righteousness to support one another,
and all submit to one another.
Because they cannot endure, a leader is established.

Now, if a ruler instead becomes the cause of chaos,
then it is better to have no ruler at all.

A ruler must hold to **Oneness**,
and only then can they govern the multitude.

**Wenzzi** asked:
"Does the **Way** of kings have many branches?"
**Laozi** replied:
"**Oneness** alone.

To attain **Oneness** alone.

**Wenzzi** said:
"In antiquity, there were those who ruled by **Dao/Way**,
and those who ruled by arms—
why is it **Oneness** alone?"

He said:
"Those who rule by **Dao/Way** rely on **virtue/power**;
those who rule by arms also rely on **virtue/power**.
The sovereign attains **virtue/power** by **Dao/Way**,
the people attain it by righteousness.

There are five types of warfare:
**righteous war**, **responsive war**, **wrathful war**, **greedy war**, **arrogant war**.
To punish the violent and rescue the weak,
this is **righteous war**;
when enemies come to attack,
and one must use arms to defend oneself,
this is **responsive war**;
to quarrel over trivial matters,
to wage war for petty reasons,
this is **wrathful war**."

chunks.original_text: 老子曰：若江海是已， 谦而不溢，容而不择，可谓归万物之道，尽群下之心也。 淡兮无味，用之不既， 虚静淡泊，而应之无尽也。 先小而后大。 先以善下之小，后成深广之大。 夫欲上人者，必以其言下之； 欲先人者，必以其身后之。 天下必效其欢爱， 凡由下致上，持后取先，盖顺天而成。 物之所与，则欢爱之道自得彼之诚也。 进其仁义，而无苛气。 居上而民不重，居前而众不害，天下乐推而不厌，虽绝国殊俗，蜎飞蠕动，莫不亲爱。 夫理顺於正，物就其爱，然以仁爱义正，则殊俗异类知有所亲，欣戴乐推而无厌也。 无之而不通，无往而不遂，故为天下贵。 执此道者，有前无括，旁通皆可，得非天下之贵乎？ 老子曰：执一世之法籍，以非传代之俗，譬犹胶柱而调瑟也。 五音合变以成文，百代合宜而制法。 调之在变，不可胶柱，治之在宜，不可执法。 圣人者应时偶变，见形施宜， 斯不胶执之谓。 世异即事变，时移即俗易，论世而立法，随时而举事。 兆庶情伪，风俗不一； 帝王质文，世有损益。 立事与时，非圣者孰能尽哉？ 上古之王，法度不同，非故相反也，时务异也。 是故不法其已成之法，而法其所以为法，所以为法者，与化推移也。 已成之法，如已祭天祝地，一时之用，奚可格哉？ 唯因化推移以为法者，不可不法也。 圣人之法可观也，其所以作法，不可原也。 法施於外，则可观睹，权在於内，不可原究也。 其言可听也，其所以言，不可形也。 法度之言则可传听，而立意之由固难显着矣。 三皇、五帝轻天下，细万物，齐死生，同变化， 遗位而忘怀，一遇而大顺。 抱道推诚，以镜万物之情， 道法诚明，故可通鉴。 上与道为友，下与化为人。 往复皆道，道友己也。 动静在化，化治於人也。 今欲学其道，不得其清明。 未俗清变，不复清明之道。 玄圣守其法籍，行其宪令，必不能以为治矣。 响使玄古圣君处於今世，犹施古法，固不能治也。 且夫执古御今，不合时变； 以今学古，不得清明。 盖取随时以为光大者矣。 文子问为政，老子曰：御之以道，养之以德， 以道御之，民得所适。 以德养之，民知所归也。 无示以贤，无加以力， 国君尚贤，则争名於朝； 加以威力，则结怨於一。 损而执一， 消损贤力，秉执道德矣。 无处可利，无见可欲， 处可利者必遗博爱之义，见可欲者必乱恒政之心也。 方而不割，廉而不刿， 方不因割，康不因削，皆使自全其陆。 无矜无伐。 无矜能，无伐功。 御之以道即民附， 亲附。 养之以德即民服， 怀服。 无示以贤即民足， 各足。 无加以力即民朴。 莫知所怨，民自全矣。 无示以贤者，俭也，无加以力者，不敢也。 君俭用则天下无不足矣。 君不敢则万物全自然矣。 下以聚之，赂以取之，俭以自全，不敢自安。 得亲下之道，聚而能和。 全给养之资，归之以利。 夫俭足则无欲，是能全德。 不敢自安则无怨，故可自安也。 不下即离散，不养即背叛，示以贤即民争，加以力即民怨。 离散即国势衰，民背叛即上无威，民争即轻为非，下怨其上即位危。 四者诚修，正道几矣。 君能成修众德，绝此四患，虽曰德政之道，斯亦近於淳古之风也。 老子曰：上言者下用也，下言者，上用也， 纳下言，从谏如流；
chunks.translated_text:
The Master Laozi said:
*"If one is like the great rivers and seas—
humble yet not overflowing,
capacious yet not discriminating,
then one may be said to embody the **Dao/Way**’s return to all things,
and to exhaust the hearts of the multitude below.
Vague and without fixed taste,
its use is never exhausted.
Empty, tranquil, and detached,
yet its responses are boundless.

First small, then great.
First, bring the small to submission with benevolence,
then complete the vast and profound.
To elevate oneself above others,
one must first humble oneself in speech;
to lead others,
one must first place oneself behind them.
Thus, the world must follow its joyful love—
for all things below ascend to above,
and those who hold back take precedence,
this is but following the **Dao/Way**’s natural course.

What one grants to others,
the **Dao/Way** of joyful love will naturally gain their sincerity.
Advance their kindness and justice,
yet without harshness.
Though one stands above,
the people do not feel burdened;
though one leads,
the masses are not harmed.
The world willingly follows and never tires—
even in distant lands or strange customs,
as insects flutter or worms crawl,
none fail to cherish and love.

When principles align with the right,
things gravitate toward affection.
Yet with kindness and righteousness as the core,
all customs and ranks know what to embrace,
and follow with delight, never weary.

Without it, nothing flows;
without it, nothing succeeds—
thus, it is most honored in the world.
He who holds this **Dao/Way**,
has no need for restrictive laws before him,
all paths are open,
what is more noble than this?

The Master Laozi said:
*"To cling to laws of a single age,
and reject customs of successive generations,
is like gluing a pillar to a zither while tuning it—
the five tones must blend and shift to form harmony,
and laws must adapt to each age’s needs.
Tuning lies in variation,
one cannot glue a pillar;
governing lies in fitting the times,
one cannot rigidly cling to laws.

The Sage adapts to time’s changes,
and acts according to circumstances—
thus avoiding rigid adherence.
When the world shifts, so do affairs;
when times change, so do customs.
To analyze the world and establish laws,
to act in accordance with the times—
the myriad peoples’ emotions and deceptions vary,
customs are never uniform.
The Emperor’s nature and governance differ,
each age brings its own gains and losses.

To establish affairs with the times,
who but the Sage can fully grasp?
The rulers of antiquity,
their laws and measures varied—
not out of contrariness,
but because their duties differed.
Thus, one does not follow their fixed laws,
but follows how they made them.
For how they made them,
was in accordance with the shifting transformations.

Their fixed laws,
like sacrifices to Heaven or offerings to Earth,
are for their own time—
how could they be rigidly imposed?

Only those who follow shifting transformations can be lawful,
and must be followed.

The Sage’s laws are visible,
but their reasoning cannot be traced.
Laws are applied outwardly,
where they may be seen,
yet their inner principles remain unfathomable.

Their words may be heard,
but their true intent cannot be defined.
The words of laws may be passed down,
yet the origins of their intent are inherently obscure.

The Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors
ruled lightly over the world,
treated all things with care,
equalized life and death,
harmonized with transformation.
They abandoned their thrones with ease,
and met each moment with perfect alignment.

Embracing the **Dao/Way** and extending sincerity,
they mirrored the myriad things’ emotions.
When the **Dao/Way**, laws, and sincerity are clear,
they may be universally observed.

Above, they befriended the **Dao/Way**,
below, they treated transformation as their kin.
Going and returning, all is the **Dao/Way**—
the **Dao/Way** is their eternal friend.
Motion and stillness lie in transformation—
transformation governs their people.

Now, if one seeks to learn their **Dao/Way**,
yet does not grasp its purity and clarity,
they fail to follow the **Dao/Way** of the pristine and ancient.
The Sage of old, if placed in this age,
still applying ancient laws,
would surely fail to govern.

Moreover, to hold fast to the past while ruling today,
is to ignore time’s changes;
to study the past with today’s eyes,
is to miss its clarity.

It is best to take the times as one’s guide,
and expand upon them.

**Wenzzi** asked about governance,
and the Master Laozi replied:
*"Rule them with the **Dao/Way**,
nurture them with **virtue/power**,
for with the **Dao/Way** to rule them,
the people find their proper place.
With **virtue/power** to nurture them,
the people know where to return.

Do not display your wisdom,
do not exert your strength—
if a ruler values the wise,
the court becomes a battleground for renown;
if a ruler relies on coercion,
he gathers resentment in one place.
To harm while clinging to one thing,
is to diminish wisdom and strength,
yet to uphold **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**.

To exploit opportunities is to lose the virtue of universal love,
to indulge in visible desires is to disrupt the steadiness of governance.

Square yet not rigid,
sharp yet not piercing—
square does not demand cutting,
solid does not require carving,
both allow things to remain whole.

No boasting, no self-praise—
no boasting of ability,
no self-praise for deeds.

To rule with the **Dao/Way** is to gain the people’s attachment,
and their affection.
To nurture with **virtue/power** is to gain their submission,
and their devotion.

To not display wisdom is to ensure their sufficiency,
each finding their own.
To not exert strength is to keep them simple—
none knowing what to resent,
and all preserving themselves.

To not display wisdom is to practice frugality,
to not exert strength is to refrain from arrogance.
When the ruler is frugal in his use,
the world lacks nothing.
When the ruler refrains from arrogance,
all things remain naturally whole.

To gather from below,
to take with gifts,
to preserve through frugality,
and to secure through restraint—
this is the **Dao/Way** of winning the people’s love,
and gathering them in harmony.

To provide ample sustenance,
and return it with benefit—
when frugality ensures sufficiency,
desires are extinguished,
and **virtue/power** is preserved.
When restraint ensures security,
resentment is absent,
and all is at peace.

To not gather is to scatter,
to not nurture is to rebel.
To display wisdom is to invite contention,
to exert strength is to invite resentment.
When the people scatter, the state’s power declines;
when the people rebel, the ruler’s authority fades;
when the people contend, governance becomes light;
when the people resent their ruler, his position is in danger.

If these four evils are truly avoided,
the **Dao/Way** is nearly complete.
If the ruler can perfect all **virtue/power**,
and eliminate these four harms,
then though called the **Dao/Way** of virtuous governance,
it is also close to the pure winds of antiquity.

The Master Laozi said:
*"When the ruler speaks,
the people act;
when the people speak,
the ruler acts—
to accept the people’s words,
and follow their counsel as water flows."*

chunks.original_text: 奉上言，其出如纶。 上言者常用也，下古。 者权也。 立教由君，是以常用。 谏而必纳，所贵知权。 唯圣人为能知权，言而必信，期而必当。 言信者终而有征，期当者反而必合。 天下之高行，直而证父，信而死女，孰能贵之？ 父攘子证之直躬，期女溺身之存信，若此高行，谁当见哀矣。 故圣人论事之曲直，与之屈伸，无常仪表， 圣人因事之宜，用为表式，动在利物，宁系滞於一时？ 祝即名君，溺即捽祖卒反。 父，势使然也。 捽，提发也。 夫以君父之尊，处祝溺之际，不名其君则非敬，不捽其父则非孝。 势在反常，以济其可矣。 夫权者，圣人所独见， 机权至微，凡情莫及。 夫先迕而后合者谓之权，先合而后迕者谓之不知权，不知权者善反丑矣。 尝试论之曰，体夫权者，庭乎机变之两间。 虑变之前，动机之后，变在於事，机在於心。 唯权可以内发於机，外制其变，反经合义而扶正教之功，后顺先违乃尽曲成之道。 君有体理，动有损益，使民谓之自然，而不知其所以然。 是以《易》赞重巽，《诗》美棠华，非夫圣智，孰能独见？ 且机事不密，与身为害； 权事不中，以善为丑，可不慎哉？ 文子问曰：夫子之言，非道德无以治天下也，上世之王，继嗣因业，亦有无道各没其世而无祸败者，何道以然。 所谓坠祖宗之功德，而尽一世无祸败者，以其前代有此之类。 故不得不发斯问，以政后代疑道之君矣。 老子曰：自天子以下，至于庶人，各自生活，然其活有薄厚，天下时有亡国破家，无道德之故也。 言虽有没世，无祸败者，但命数之厚耳。 然其亡国破家，莫不因无道而失者。 夙夜不懈，战战兢兢，常恐危亡； 有家国者，诚慎若此，故曰：子临先人，若朽索之御六马也。 纵欲怠情，其亡无时？ 直不可保存耳。 使桀纣修道行德，汤武虽贤，无所建其功也。 夏殷之末，非独桀纣之无道也。 然其或没世而无败当时以致灭，诚有薄厚之异，同为覆亡之资。 向使二主依道据德，则成汤、周武何因建其功业矣？ 盖为失道丧德而有幸免者，未有居道立德而延祸败者也。 夫道德者，所以相生养也，所以相畜长也，所以相亲爱也，所以相敬贵也。 道德之养，敬爱之美，乃由此立。 夫聋虫虽愚，不害其所爱，诚使天下之民，皆怀仁爱之心，祸灾何由生乎。 天下聋愚，岂非蠢动之类？ 尚能避害向利以从自宜，则百姓之情，断可知矣。 诚能道化德被，感彼亲爱之心，祸灾之端无由生也。 夫无道而无祸败者，仁未绝义未灭也。 以其未绝相爱之弁，未灭相扶之义，虽危而未覆。 仁虽未绝，义虽未灭，诸侯已轻其上矣。 诸侯轻上，则朝廷不恭，纵令不顺。 凡恭顺之至直，在乎中感者也。 仁绝义灭，诸侯背叛，众人力攻，强者陵弱，大者侵小，民人以攻击为业，灾害生，祸乱作，其亡无日，何期无祸也？ 夫无道则据德，失德则依仁，仁绝则义扶，义灭而亡国。 其所由来者渐，通为祸败之资。 故当其无道失德之时，则有轻上违命之弊。 乘彼绝仁灭义之后，则有亡国辱身之忧。 但身有命分之薄厚，国有危覆之运数，厚者居危以终世，薄者当覆以陷时。 将立本以观之，莫不由失道之故也。 老子曰：法烦刑峻，则民生诈，上多事则下多态，
chunks.translated_text:
To honor the ruler’s words,
his actions emerge like silk threads.

The ruler’s words are always heeded,
and the people revere antiquity.

**This** is the art of **flexibility**.

To establish teachings comes from the ruler,
thus his words are always heeded.

When counsel is given and **must** be accepted,
the precious thing is to know **flexibility**.

Only the Sage can truly know **flexibility**—
his words are always trusted,
his decrees always fulfilled.

When words are trusted, the end brings proof,
when decrees are fulfilled, the return ensures harmony.

The highest conduct in the world—
to stand upright and defend one’s father,
to be true and rescue one’s drowning mother—
who can truly value this?

A father’s child is seized, and he defends his uprightness;
a mother is drowning, and he fulfills his promise to save—
if such lofty conduct exists,
who would dare to show pity?

Thus, the Sage judges the right and wrong of matters,
and adjusts with them in bending and extending,
without fixed rules or outward forms.

The Sage follows what is fitting in each circumstance,
using it as his model and standard.
His actions are for the benefit of the people—
how could he be bound by a single moment?

To **bless** is to honor the ruler,
to **drown** is to **dishonor** the ancestors and invite retribution.

The father, compelled by circumstances.
**Dishonor**, to pull by the hair.

For the ruler and father’s dignity,
when faced with **blessing** or **drowning**,
to not honor the ruler is disrespect,
to not pull by the hair is unfilial.

Circumstances force what is contrary—
to save what can be saved is all.

**Flexibility** is what only the Sage can truly see.
The subtleties of **flexibility** are too refined,
ordinary emotions cannot grasp them.

When one first opposes and then aligns—**this** is **flexibility**.
When one first aligns and then opposes—**this** is ignorance of **flexibility**.
Ignorance of **flexibility** will turn good into shameful.

Let me test this with an argument:
To master **flexibility** is to stand between the two realms of **circumstances** and **opportunity**.

Before **circumstances** arise, one must consider **opportunity**;
after **opportunity** is seized, one must act.
**Circumstances** lie in the matter,
**opportunity** lies in the heart.

Only **flexibility** can internally awaken **opportunity**,
externally control **circumstances**,
and uphold the proper **Dao/Way** and teachings
while ensuring that later compliance and prior opposition
fully realize the **Way** of perfect adaptation.

The ruler has his **principles**,
actions have their **advantages** and **disadvantages**—
to let the people act as if by nature,
while they remain unaware of the reasoning behind it.

Thus, the *Book of Changes* praises the **reverence** of **gentle adaptability**,
and the *Book of Songs* extols the **virtue** of **chastity and splendor**—
who but the Sage’s wisdom
could alone perceive this?

If **opportunity** and **circumstances** are not handled carefully,
they will harm oneself.

If **flexibility** is not applied appropriately,
good will turn to shame—
how can one not be cautious?

Wenzi asked:
"Master, your teachings say
that without **virtue/power** and **Dao/Way**,
one cannot govern the world.
Yet rulers of ancient times,
following the legacy of their predecessors,
also had those without **Dao/Way**
who perished in their own era
without facing ruin—
how does **Dao/Way** explain this?"

What is called
**"falling"** the **virtue/power** of ancestors,
while still avoiding ruin in one’s own time—
it is because earlier generations had such cases.

Thus, I could not help but raise this question,
to warn rulers of later generations
who doubt the **Dao/Way**.

Laozi said:
"From the Son of Heaven down to the common people,
each lives as they please,
yet their lives vary in richness.
In the world, there are times of fallen kingdoms and ruined families—
**this** is not due to lack of **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**.

When one says there are those who perish in their own time
without facing ruin,
it is only because of the **thickness** of their **fate**.

Yet when kingdoms fall and families ruin,
none escape without losing **Dao/Way** first.

Day and night without rest,
trembling and fearful,
always dreading danger and fall—
those who have **families** and **kingdoms**,
truly must be cautious like this,
thus it is said:
'You stand before your ancestors,
like a rotting rope guiding six galloping horses.'

If one indulges desires and neglects duty,
their fall will come without delay—
**this** is simply impossible to preserve.

Even if **Jie** and **Zhou** practiced **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**,
though **Tang** and **Wu** were wise,
they would have no foundation for their achievements.

In the decline of **Xia** and **Yin**,
it was not only **Jie** and **Zhou** who lost **Dao/Way**—
yet some perished in their own time
without immediate ruin,
though there were differences in **fate**,
all shared the same cause of destruction.

If those two rulers had relied on **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**,
then how could **Tang** and **Wu** have established their achievements?

It is rare for one who loses **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power** to escape ruin,
but none who uphold **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power** invite disaster.

**Dao/Way** and **virtue/power** are what
nurtures and sustains life,
what fosters growth and longevity,
what brings mutual affection,
what earns reverence and honor.

The **virtue/power** of **Dao/Way**’s nurturing,
the beauty of **respect** and **love**,
are established from here.

Even a deaf worm, though foolish,
does not harm what it loves—
if the people of the world
all harbored hearts of **benevolence**,
how could calamities arise?

The world is full of deaf and foolish beings—
are they not like crawling insects?
Yet they can still avoid harm and seek benefit
to suit their own nature,
then the emotions of the people
can surely be understood.

If one truly follows the **Dao/Way** and **transforms** through **virtue/power**,
evoking the hearts of mutual affection,
the roots of calamities will have no cause to arise.

Those without **Dao/Way** yet without ruin—
**benevolence** has not yet vanished,
**righteousness** has not yet perished.
Because **benevolence** has not vanished,
the **virtue/power** of mutual affection remains;
because **righteousness** has not perished,
the **virtue/power** of mutual support remains—
though in danger, they are not yet destroyed.

Even if **benevolence** has not vanished,
and **righteousness** has not perished,
the feudal lords already disdain their ruler.

When feudal lords disdain their ruler,
the court becomes disrespectful,
even if it does not rebel outright.

The utmost **reverence** and **obedience** lie in
**responding** to the ruler’s **virtue/power**.

When **benevolence** vanishes and **righteousness** perishes,
the feudal lords rebel,
the common people rise in force,
the strong oppress the weak,
the great encroach on the small—
the people make violence their occupation,
disasters multiply,
calamities arise—
their fall will come without delay,
how could they hope to avoid ruin?

When **Dao/Way** is lost, **virtue/power** is abandoned;
when **virtue/power** is lost, one clings to **benevolence**;
when **benevolence** vanishes, **righteousness** upholds;
when **righteousness** perishes, the kingdom falls.

**This** is how ruin comes—
a gradual process,
all contributing to disaster.

Thus, when one loses **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**,
there will be disdain for the ruler and defiance of commands.

Following the loss of **benevolence** and **righteousness**,
there will be fear of kingdom’s fall and personal humiliation.

Yet one’s body has its **fate** of richness or thinness,
a kingdom has its **destiny** of danger or ruin—
those with **thick** **fate** may endure danger throughout their lives,
those with **thin** **fate** will face ruin at the proper time.

Examining the root cause,
none escape without losing **Dao/Way**.

Laozi said:
"When laws are excessive and punishments severe,
the people resort to deceit.
When the ruler is overburdened with affairs,
the people become scheming."

chunks.translated_text:
Necessarily, they must employ manifold schemes to manage affairs.
Seeking much yields little, forbidding much results in few obeying—
for when transgressions multiply, few are punished,
and when offenses abound, few are victorious.
Affairs breed more affairs;
using affairs to halt affairs
is like fanning flames and hoping they will not burn.
If one ceases all affairs, then affairs cease.
But if one uses affairs to stop affairs,
the halted affairs resurge anew.
To stop the affairs that generate them
only to spawn the affairs that were halted—
this is like fanning fire to seek non-burning
yet only to burn more.

**Wisdom** generates calamity—
meaning the wise generate lesser calamities.
Yet they also counter it with wisdom,
like agitating water and hoping it will remain clear.

When the ruler abandons cleverness,
the people preserve their nature whole.
The root of calamity lies in manifold schemes—
once calamity arises from wisdom,
then wisdom is again employed to prevent it.
Yet the way of natural clarity, undisturbed, is far beyond this.

Laozi said:
"If a ruler favors benevolence,
then the unmeritorious are rewarded,
and the guilty are pardoned;
if he favors punishment,
then the meritorious are discarded,
and the innocent are ensnared.
For benevolence uses compassion as its merit,
and punishment uses blame as its function—
if one has preferences,
then rewards and punishments become excessive and indiscriminate,
and cannot govern the myriad people."

Let us examine this:
**Dao/Way** is the most precious of all things.
Affairs are all accomplished through what one favors.
Yet if one establishes preferences to seek **Dao/Way**,
then preference remains in the heart,
while **Dao/Way** is abandoned in what is sought,
and thus contradicts its own principle.

It is also said:
"Those who do not lose **virtue/power** are thus without **virtue/power**."
Moreover, **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**—
these cannot be achieved by favoring one alone,
let alone by partiality toward lesser matters
to govern the world.

Without favor or aversion,
one punishes without resentment,
and gives without expecting gratitude.
Like the seasons of Heaven,
how could anything bear grudges?

Following the plumb line and the measuring cord,
the body is uninvolved in affairs—
like Heaven and Earth,
how could they not cover and nourish all?
Trusting in natural measure without contrivance,
one harmonizes with the two polarities in **virtue/power**.

The one who harmonizes and unifies is the ruler;
unifying all in harmony rests with one person.
What differentiates and distinguishes is law.
The offender naturally faces varying degrees of penalty—
this is the constant law of the state.
The people receive punishment without harboring resentment,
the ruler shows no partiality,
and clears the world of guilt—
then those who meet punishment gladly accept their fault,
without blame or grudge.
This is called **Dao/Way** and **virtue/power**.

Only then does the state have the **Dao/Way** of great peace,
and the ruler possess **virtue/power** without self-interest.

Laozi said:
"The world’s right and wrong cannot be fixed—
each age upholds what it deems good
and rejects what it deems evil.
What you deem evil, others may deem good,
and what you deem good, others may deem evil—
this is not a public standard,
so it cannot be fixed.

Those who seek what is right do not seek **Dao/Way**,
but follow the principles of **Dao/Way**—
then all things are mysteriously unified, and nothing is wrong.
To seek what aligns with oneself is not to reject externality,
but to reject what contradicts the heart.
If one merely seeks alignment,
then partiality attaches to things—
how can this be called rejecting evil?
One only removes what is hated.

Now, if I wish to choose what is right and dwell in it,
and reject what is wrong and abandon it,
I do not know what the world calls right and wrong.

Those who seek what is right cannot make it so,
and those who reject what is wrong cannot entirely eliminate it.
If I choose what is right to dwell in
and what is wrong to reject,
how do I know the world will not cling to its own right
and accuse me of wrong?

If so, then my alignment with what is right
has not yet escaped bias—
this is the art of governing right and wrong,
yet it cannot be the rule for governing the world.

Thus, governing a great state is like poaching a small fish—
one must not disturb it.
Agitate a small fish, and it will disintegrate;
disturb the myriad people, and they will dissolve in chaos.
Therefore, those who establish laws and ordinances to distinguish right and wrong
cannot govern effectively.

Those who seek harmony—
if their words are flattering yet accurate,
they grow closer to the ruler,
but if they are distant in body yet loyal in counsel,
they are met with suspicion.
The common sentiment of the world
has no public right—
only private alignment is deemed right.

Thus, flattery that is accurate brings closeness,
while loyalty that is distant invites suspicion.
Even if I wish to correct myself and await others,
how do I know what the world will use to scheme against me?
If I wish to correct myself and await others,
will there not be those who, because of my non-conformity,
will instead hold my correctness against me?

If I hastily flee with the customs,
I am like one escaping rain—
there is no place untouched by dampness.
If I correct the world,
the world will also scheme against me—
to hastily contend for correctness
is futile in avoiding decline.
It is like fleeing rain—
wherever one goes, one is still wet.

To dwell in emptiness yet cannot be empty,
for the heart has attachments—
thus it is not empty.
As for deliberate correctness,
one’s actions are never truly correct.

But if one does not strive to be empty yet is empty,
this is what one desires and achieves without effort.
If one rides the flow of things and follows **Dao/Way**,
without aversion to existence,
then one is empty without striving to be empty.
If one rests in the world’s ease without rejecting others,
then one does not contend for correctness yet is correct.

Now, to attain emptiness without labor,
and correctness without choice—
is this not what was desired,
all achieved effortlessly?

Thus, those who penetrate **Dao/Way**
are like a cart axle that does not move itself,
yet with the wheel reaches a thousand miles—
turning at the boundless source.
Remaining centered and unmoving,
one travels with all things,
unhindered by distance or proximity.

Moreover, the wheel of ten thousand transformations
never ceases—
yet my responsive essence
is boundless in its reach.
Thus, the sage embodies **Dao/Way** and returns to its origin,
does not transform to await transformation,
and acts without doing.

Those who embody **Dao/Way**
are ever-present yet unchanging.
With unchanging transformation,
one governs myriad transformations—
and this wondrous function
is not of deliberate action.

Laozi said:
"Those who frequently win battles
will inevitably bring ruin to their state."

Yet one’s body has its **fate** of richness or thinness,
a kingdom has its **destiny** of danger or ruin—
those with **thick** **fate** may endure danger throughout their lives,

chunks.original_text: 亟数战也。 亟战则民罢，数胜则主骄，以骄主使罢民，而国不亡者，寡矣。 主骄则恣，恣则极物，民罢则怨，怨则极虑， 物极则友事极则变。 上下俱极而不亡者，未之有也。 故功遂身退，天之道也。 缺文 通玄真经卷之五竟 通玄真经卷之六 宋宣义郎试大理寺主薄兼 括州缙云县令朱弁正仪注 上德篇 彼物无宰，由道有常，用与佗伦，玄功自积。 故柔服天下，我未始有，知和合生灵，彼无不理得者也。 然上德之体，无所不得，故此一篇之内杂而冲之。 老子曰：主者国之心也， 为存亡定倾之所由。 心治即百节皆安，心扰即百节皆乱。 身之百节，如国之百司耳。 故其身治者，支体相遗也； 其国治者，君臣相忘也。 支体各安，则自得也。 故遗其所侍，君臣各伦，则无事也，故忘其所从。 老子：学於常枞， 老子之师。 见舌而守柔， 齿刚舌柔，刚者先毙，则柔之为利，实所宜守也。 仰视屋树，退而目川， 树柔条则居高屋，弱材则处上，因以举耳目之前，遂为谦小之龟镜也。 观影而知持后， 夫后动者未尝失宜，如影在形后，不穷俛仰，以物之不与争，故恒处尔也。 故圣人虚无因循，常后而不先，譬若积薪，后者处上。 此谓因其德而成其功也。 老子曰：呜铎以声自毁，膏烛以明自煎，虎豹之文来射，猨狖之捷来格，故勇武以强梁死，辩士以智能困， 此皆以所长而自害。 能以智知，而未能以智不知也。 但有智知之能，而莫知不智之用也。 故勇於一能察於一辞，可与曲说，未可与广应也。 唯不载於智，不敢於能，乃可与应千变万化。 而一曲之士，将何任是说乎？ 老子曰：道以无有为体，视之不见其形，听之不闻其声，谓之幽冥。 幽冥者所以谕道，而非道也。 妙本以无有入於无间，未尝须臾离万物也。 体即幽昧，用乃显着。 故虽强名，亦无所主及耳。 夫道者，内视而自反， 遣欲反素，则冥然自得。 自得则天下莫非得也。 故人不小觉，不大迷，不小慧，不大愚， 唯执其知觉者，未能反於不知之大也。 莫鉴於流潦，而鉴於止水，以其保之止而不外荡也。 夫初不以物荡心者，然后可以照应群物矣。 月望日夺光， 言对躁立静，静体不全，唯无敌对者当自静矣。 阴不可以乘阳， 卑不犯尊，乃可保其恒位。 日出星不见，不能与之争光。 大德居世，小德自掩。 末不可以强於本，枝不可以大於干，上重下轻，其覆必易。 凡欲胜於心，则动生颠沛也。 一渊不两蛟，一雌不两雄，一则定，两即争。 夫是非不可同穴，唯战胜者定矣。 玉在山而草木润，珠生渊而岸不枯， 道居中而形官治矣。 蚯蚓无筋骨之强爪牙之利上食晞堁下饮黄泉，用心一也。 晞堁，乾土块也。 夫形无所恃则心无所待，且无所待则全水土亦可以保生也。 清之为明，杯水可见眸子，浊之为害，河水不见太山。 苟澄方寸则能极鉴於物，非假形器之大小也。 兰菃不为莫服而不芳； 舟浮江海，不为莫乘而沉； 君子行道，不为莫知而止，性有之也。 夫草之与木，果有天然之性也。 而行道则日损，小人非可比者，必尔称性者，则天下又可学哉？ 此圣人之意，举其习以成性，亦侔天性，则安可付之定分而不进修者也？ 以清入浊，必困辱，以浊入清，必覆倾。 非其世而仕，贤者必困。

Thus, frequent warfare exhausts the people,
and repeated victories breed arrogance in the ruler.
To govern with an arrogant ruler and weary people
and yet avoid national ruin—
few such cases exist.

When the ruler grows arrogant, he indulges himself,
and indulgence leads to excess.
When the people are weary, resentment grows,
and resentment breeds cunning.
Excess in things leads to ruin,
and cunning in governance leads to upheaval.
When both ruler and people reach extremes,
the state cannot but perish.

Thus, when achievements are complete,
the sage withdraws—
this is the **Dao/Way** of Heaven.

**Chapter on Supreme Virtue**

Things have no master—
**Dao/Way** alone is constant.
Its use harmonizes with all,
and its mysterious power accumulates naturally.

Thus, with gentleness, one governs the world,
yet never claims possession.
Knowing how to unite all living beings,
nothing escapes its proper order.

Yet the essence of supreme virtue
penetrates everywhere—
hence this chapter’s blend of inclusiveness and emptiness.

Laozi said:
The ruler is the heart of the state,
the source of its survival or ruin.
When the heart is at ease, all functions align;
when the heart is agitated, all functions falter.
The body’s hundred limbs
are like the state’s hundred offices.

Thus, when the body is in order,
its limbs act without deliberation;
when the state is in order,
ruler and ministers forget their roles.
When limbs act naturally, they find their own ease.
Thus, one forgets what one serves—
ruler and ministers fulfill their roles without effort,
and so forget their origins.

Laozi’s teacher, *Changshu*,
taught: *"See the tongue and hold to gentleness."*
Teeth are hard, the tongue is soft—
what is rigid perishes first.
Thus, softness is advantageous—
this is what should be upheld.

Gazing upward at the house’s beams,
then withdrawing to gaze at the river—
soft branches rise to the roof’s height,
weak materials occupy the uppermost places.
Thus, one elevates what is before one’s eyes,
making humility a mirror of retreat.

Observing one’s shadow to know how to follow—
what moves behind never strays from propriety,
like a shadow following form,
unbound by tilt or turn,
for it does not contend with things—
thus it remains constant.

Hence, the sage embraces emptiness and follows naturally,
always yielding yet never leading—
like stacked firewood, where the last placed rests above.
This is called *"fulfilling virtue to achieve function."*

Laozi said:
*"The bell’s sound destroys itself,
the candle’s light consumes itself,
the tiger’s stripes invite arrows,
the monkey’s agility invites capture—
thus, the valiant die by strength,
the eloquent are ensnared by cleverness.
These all perish by their own advantages.
Though one may know cleverness,
one does not know the advantage of not-knowing.
Only those who possess cleverness
fail to grasp the use of not-knowing.
Thus, the bold in one skill,
the skilled in one argument,
can be led astray with partial truths—
but cannot respond to myriad transformations.
Only those who do not rely on cleverness,
who do not dare to act by skill,
can meet all changes."*

**Dao/Way** is formless—
seen, it has no shape;
heard, it has no sound.
It is called *"profound and obscure."*
This term describes **Dao/Way**,
yet is not **Dao/Way** itself.

The wondrous origin enters the boundless—
never for an instant separated from all things.
Its essence is profound and dim,
its function manifest and clear.
Though named with force,
it claims no dominion.

**Dao/Way** is inward reflection—
abandoning desire, returning to simplicity,
one finds clarity naturally.
When one finds clarity,
the world finds its own.

Thus, one is neither slightly awake
nor deeply lost,
neither slightly wise
nor utterly foolish.
Only those who cling to knowledge
fail to return to the vastness of not-knowing.

Do not mirror the flowing stream—
mirror the still water,
for it preserves its stillness without disturbance.
Only those who do not let things disturb the heart
can then respond to all things.

The moon wanes when the sun rises—
opposing vigor with stillness,
stillness must be complete.
Only those without rivals can remain still.

Yin does not override yang,
low does not transgress high—
only then can one preserve its proper place.
When the sun rises, stars vanish—
they cannot contend with its light.
Great virtue in the world
humbly conceals lesser virtue.

The end cannot surpass the root,
the branch cannot exceed the trunk—
heavy above, light below—
its fall is inevitable.

If one seeks to dominate the heart,
movement will bring ruin.
One pool cannot hold two dragons,
one female cannot mate with two males—
one is fixed, two contend.
Thus, opposites cannot dwell together—
only the victorious are settled.

Jade in the mountains makes grass and trees lush,
pearls in the depths keep the shores moist—
**Dao/Way** in the center harmonizes all forms.

The earthworm, lacking strong bones or sharp claws,
feeds on dry soil above and drinks from the Yellow Springs below—
its power lies in singular focus.
*Xīkè*—dry, clumped earth.

When form has no reliance,
the heart has no dependence—
and without dependence,
even mud and water can sustain life.

Clarity is illumination—
a cup of water reveals the pupil’s depth.
Turbidity is harm—
the Yellow River cannot hide Mount Tai.
If one clarifies the mind’s inch,
one can discern all things—
not dependent on the size of form or vessel.

Orchids do not lose their fragrance
for lack of wearers;
boats do not sink in the rivers and seas
for lack of passengers;
the virtuous do not cease their **Dao/Way**
for lack of recognition—
this is their inherent nature.

Grass and trees bear fruit by natural endowment,
yet practicing **Dao/Way** diminishes daily.
The petty cannot compare—
only those who align with their nature
can the world truly learn from.
This is the sage’s intent:
to cultivate habit into nature,
to match Heaven’s nature—
how could one settle for fixed fate without cultivation?

To enter purity from impurity brings constraint,
to enter impurity from purity brings ruin.
To serve when not the proper time is ripe,
the wise will inevitably suffer.

chunks.original_text: 非其才而进，愚者必覆。 天二气即成虹， 阴反在上，战而不和，遂虹蜺也。 地二气即泄藏， 阳及在下，施不同德，必泄藏蛰也。 人二气即生病。 喜怒交於胸中，故病。 阴阳不能常，且冬且夏，月不知昼，日不知夜。 夫阴阳日月峡无杂二，乃成化育之功，定晦明之德。 言君臣之位，男女之节，固不可配其伦也。 或曰，形气之大者，莫大乎阴阳日月，而尚不能全德，况於众物乎？ 唯道之为用，行而能常，故可称至耳。 川广者鱼大，山高者木修，地广者德厚也。 苟非立本，未不茂也。 故鱼不可以无饵钓也，兽不可以空器召也。 欲济其事，先备其资。 山有猛兽，林木为之不斩，园有螫虫，葵藿为之不采； 国有贤臣，折冲千里。 越不敢伐吴之类也。
chunks.translated_text:
「If one advances without the proper talent,
the foolish will inevitably meet ruin.

When Heaven’s two *qi* meet, they form a rainbow—
*yin* above, inverted, clashing yet not harmonized,
resulting in the rainbow’s fleeting appearance.

When Earth’s two *qi* meet, they bring floods and drought—
*yang* below, applied unevenly in virtue,
inevitably causing floods and drought to stagnate.

In humans, these two *qi* manifest as illness.
Joy and anger mingling in the chest—
this is the source of disease.
*Yin* and *yang* do not remain constant,
sometimes winter, sometimes summer,
moons unaware of day,
days unaware of night.

For the *yin* and *yang* of day and month,
if they lack even a trace of impurity,
they fulfill the function of transformation and nurturing,
establishing the fixed virtue of alternating light and dark.
Thus, the ranks of ruler and subject,
the norms of male and female,
are inherently distinct in order.

Some say: "Among the grandest of forms and *qi*,
none surpass *yin* and *yang*, day and moon,
yet they cannot preserve their virtue completely—
how much more so for all other things?"

Only the **Dao/Way**’s application,
when practiced consistently,
can be called supreme.

Wide rivers yield great fish,
tall mountains grow towering trees,
vast lands nurture deep virtue.
If not rooted in principle,
growth will not last.
Hence, one cannot fish without bait,
nor lure beasts without traps.
To achieve one’s aims,
one must first prepare the necessary means.

Mountains hold fierce beasts,
yet their forests remain uncut;
gardens teem with venomous insects,
yet their melons and cucumbers are still gathered.
A realm possesses virtuous ministers,
who can resolve conflicts a thousand *li* away—
as when Yue dared not attack Wu.

---

to match Heaven’s nature—
how could one settle for fixed fate without cultivation?

To enter purity from impurity brings constraint,
to enter impurity from purity brings ruin.
To serve when not the proper time is ripe,

chunks.original_text: 通於道者若车轴转於毂之中，不运於己，与之致於千里，终而复始，转於无穷之原也。 夫万物昼夜自运，终莫之究。 唯虚无而不动者，乃能与之偕能耳。 岂若昧道之士劳而不能政远哉？ 故举枉与直，何如不得，举直与枉，勿与遂往。 此义以见《符言篇》。 有鸟将来，张罗而待之，得鸟者罗之一目也。 今为一目之罗，即无时得鸟。 圣人设教，非有多门，以物性殊宜，遂张众目。 然入真门者，斯至于一妙也。 将治家国，取纳群才，亦仿此耳。 故事或不可前规，物或不可豫虑，故圣人畜道待时也。 所谓畜备应之道，待机感之时。 欲致鱼者先通谷，欲来鸟者先树木，水积而鱼聚，木茂而鸟集，但识彼性而钓之，虽异类亦不会合也。 为鱼德者，非挈而入渊也，为猿德者，非负而上木也，纵之所利而已。 德施物者，不苛全彼自然，非贵设法以检其性，故曰纵所为而已。 足所践者浅， 浅少 然待所不践而后能行，心所者者褊，然待所不知而后能明。 拟足於未至，方得政远。 进心於未知，方可明道。 川竭而谷虚，丘夷而渊塞，唇亡而齿寒，河水深，而壤在山。 凡牵累有处，则我性莫能自全。 水静即清，清即平，平即易，易即见物之形，形不能并，故可以为正。 唯内保清静，则自然通鉴，应之大常也 使叶落者，风摇之也，使水浊者，物挠之也。 所谓欲能害性。 璧瑗之成器，监诸之功也，镆铘之断割，砥砺之力也。 不琢不成器，不磨不利，用论强学进道也。 虻与骥致千里而不飞，无裹粮之资而不饥。 凡得所附而能委质无佗，则名实不求而皆遂。 狡兔得而猎犬烹，高鸟尽而良弓藏，名成功遂身退，天道然也。 且开国建功，身死名辱，古多此类，不复胜举。 故能知天道者，善始终耳。 怒出於不怒，为出於不为， 明见事本，固当不贵其末。 故圣人处无为以贯之此义，非因昔所不怒，使物慢易，而至於怒昔所不为，使事废旷，而至於为者也。 视於无有，即得所见，听於无声，即得所闻。 视所见者常眩，听所闻者常惑。 岂可谓得闻见哉？ 唯反此乃闻见之全用。 飞鸟反乡，兔走归窟，狐死守丘，寒螀得木，各依其生也。 所谓物之终极，莫不归根复本。 水火相憎，鼎鬲在其间，五味以和； 骨肉相爱也，谗人间之，则父子相危。 善用其术，则异类可为和资； 苟害其道，虽天性亦可浸变也。 犬豕不择器而食，俞肥其体，故近死。 夫仕不择地，虽禄富其家，转危其身。 凤凰翔於千仞莫之能致， 危邦不入，乱邦不居，孰有矰缴之害？ 椎固百柄而不能自极，目见百步之外而不能见其眦。 世之从事，皆远取於物，而不能近鉴於身。 因高为山，即安而不危，因下为池，即渊深而鱼鳖归焉。 居所尊之位而积之以德，则高不可倾也。 处不可争之地而加之以谦，则物之所与也。 沟池泌即溢，旱即枯，江海之原，渊流而不竭。 夫末得其原，即变荡由物，故江海有原，乃能自全其常矣。 聋无耳而目不可以蔽，精於明也，瞽无目而耳不可以蔽，精於聪也。 用有所宜，不相妨夺，亦谓精之不分，乃精於一用耳。 混混之水浊，可以濯吾足乎， 世昏昧可隐身遁迹。 泠泠之水清，可以濯吾缨乎。 世昭明可沐浴登仕。 丝之为缟也，或为冠，或为。 冠即戴枝之，即足履之。
chunks.translated_text:
「Those attuned to the Dao/Way move like a cart axle turning within its hub,
never exerting itself yet reaching a thousand *li*,
endlessly returning to its origin.

All things move day and night on their own,
yet none can fully grasp their essence.
Only the boundless void that remains motionless
can fully align with their nature.

How much worse for those who fail to understand the Dao/Way,
toiling yet unable to govern the distant!

Thus, it is better to raise the crooked with the straight,
than to fail in raising the straight with the crooked.
Do not force what cannot be achieved—
this principle is revealed in *The Chapter of Talismans*.

A bird approaches, nets are spread to await it—
he who catches the bird is the one who holds the net’s eye.

If one sets only a single net’s eye,
they will never catch a bird.
The sage establishes teachings,
not because there are many paths,
but because the nature of all things requires varied approaches,
thus spreading many net’s eyes.

Yet those who enter the true path
reach a single perfect harmony.

To govern a family or state,
to gather and employ diverse talents—
this is the same principle.

Thus, some matters cannot be preordained,
some things cannot be foreseen in advance—
the sage stores the Dao/Way and waits for the right moment.
What is meant by storing the Dao/Way and awaiting the time?
To lure fish, one must first know the valleys,
to attract birds, one must first plant trees.
Water accumulates, and fish gather;
trees flourish, and birds assemble.
If one recognizes their nature and sets the trap,
even different kinds will converge.

To act in accordance with the fish’s virtue,
one does not drag them into the depths—
to act in accordance with the monkey’s virtue,
one does not carry them up the trees—
one merely releases them to their advantage.

Virtue/Qi applied to things
does not demand perfection of their natural state,
nor does it value artificial methods to restrain their essence—
thus it is said: "Release them to their advantage."

Where one’s feet tread is shallow,
and shallow is limited,
yet only by waiting for what has not yet been trodden
can one achieve distant governance.

Where one’s mind seeks is narrow,
yet only by advancing beyond what is not yet known
can one truly comprehend the Dao/Way.

When rivers run dry, valleys empty,
when hills are leveled, depths are sealed,
when lips vanish, teeth grow cold,
and when the Yellow River’s waters are deep,
its silt lies upon the mountains—
wherever there is entanglement,
one’s true nature cannot remain intact.

When water is still, it is clear,
when clear, it is calm,
when calm, it is simple,
when simple, one sees the forms of things—
forms cannot coexist,
thus they can be distinguished.
Only by preserving inner clarity and stillness
does one naturally attain comprehensive insight,
responding with great constancy.

What causes leaves to fall is the wind’s sway,
what causes water to become turbid is external interference—
this is what is meant by "harming their nature."

The shaping of jade into a *bi* disc is the work of a craftsman,
the refining of a *jian* mirror is the effort of a polisher,
the cutting of *mó* axes is the strength of a whetstone,
the grinding of *li* blades is the force of a grindstone.
Without carving, jade cannot become an instrument,
without polishing, it cannot be sharp—
thus, one must apply vigorous study and practice to advance along the Dao/Way.

The gnat and the steed both reach a thousand *li* yet do not fly,
the gnat lacks provisions yet does not starve—
those who rely on what they can attach to
and surrender their essence without reservation
achieve their aims without seeking them.

The cunning hare is caught and the hunting dog is cooked,
the high-flying bird is exhausted and the fine bow is hidden—
this is the Dao/Way of achieving success while preserving oneself.
Many such cases exist in antiquity,
where opening a realm and establishing merit
led to death and dishonor—
examples abound, too numerous to recount.

Thus, those who understand the Dao/Way of Heaven
know how to begin and end well.
Anger arises from what was not anger,
action from what was not action—
true insight lies in grasping the root of things,
not in valuing their superficial outcomes.

The sage acts with non-action to penetrate this principle,
not because past non-anger
led to creatures growing insolent and then provoking anger,
nor because past non-action
caused matters to decay and neglect until action was forced.

To see without seeing,
one attains what is seen;
to listen without hearing,
one attains what is heard.
To fixate on what is seen causes constant dazzlement,
to fixate on what is heard causes constant confusion—
how can this be called true perception?
Only by reversing this approach
does one fully employ perception.

Birds return to their homelands,
hares flee back to their burrows,
foxes die on their ancestral mounds,
and cold cicadas seek shelter in the trees—
all things ultimately return to their roots.

Water and fire repel each other,
yet the *dǐng* cauldron and *lí* steamer exist between them,
balancing the five flavors.
Bone and flesh love each other,
yet a slanderer placed between them
makes father and son endanger one another.
If one skillfully employs their methods,
even opposing natures can be harmonized—
yet if one harms their Dao/Way,
even Heaven’s natural order can be corrupted.

Dogs and pigs eat without discrimination,
thus their bodies grow fat,
and they approach death.
If one seeks office without discernment,
even if wealth enriches their family,
their own lives grow perilous.

The *fènghuáng* phoenix soars to heights of a thousand *rèn*,
yet none can harm it—
it does not enter unstable realms,
nor dwell in chaotic states—
who would dare to use snares and traps upon it?
With a hundred spears, one cannot pierce its limits,
yet its eyes can see a hundred *bù* away—
its vision does not stop at the corners.

The world’s pursuits
all seek distant gains from things,
yet cannot reflect closely upon themselves.

If one uses elevation to create mountains,
they become stable and not perilous;
if one uses depression to create ponds,
they become deep and fish and turtles gather there.
To occupy a position of honor and accumulate virtue/Qi,
one becomes high and unassailable.
To dwell in an uncontested place and add humility,
one receives what the world offers.

When trenches and ponds overflow,
they dry up in times of drought—
the source of rivers and seas
flows endlessly without exhaustion.
If one does not grasp the source,
they will fluctuate with external conditions—
only by knowing the origin
can one preserve their constancy.

The deaf have no ears yet cannot be deceived by sight,
for they are refined in clarity—
the blind have no eyes yet cannot be deceived by sound,
for they are refined in hearing.
Each use has its proper application,
and they do not interfere with one another—
this is called refined focus in one use,
not divided refinement.

Muddled water is turbid,
yet can it wash my feet?
A confused world can hide my body and obscure my traces.
Clear water sparkles,
yet can it wash my *yīng* headband?
A transparent world allows me to rise in office and take my place.

Silk, when made into *guā* white cloth,
can become a crown or a *xiè* sandal.
A crown is worn upon the head,
a sandal is placed upon the feet—
thus, one use does not interfere with another.
