chunks.original_text: 同一缟所制，辄尔有上下之异； 同一气所生，亦俱然贵贱之殊。 推此察之，复何企怨？ 金之势胜木，一刃不能残一林； 土之势胜水，一桮不能塞江河； 水之势胜火，一酌不能救一车之薪。 夫虽执可制之具，而德力未赡者，仅若无益於事矣。 冬有雷，夏有雹，寒暑不变其节，霜雪麃麃，日出而流。 冬至之前，阳下复成雷； 夏至之前，阴上结成雹。 虽在大寒大暑之月，亦未绝变也。 若施之於霜雪，则见日而自清沛矣。 此所谓中有必然，外不能制，时有必制，物不能然。 唯明哲之士，辨此以为宜耳。 倾易覆也，倚易附也，几易助也，湿易雨也。 故贤人因而成之，乃传其业易简也。 兰菃以芳，不得见霜， 以有芳香之能，故中道夭於采掇。 而才者可不慎也？ 蟾蝫辟兵，寿在五月之望。 以五月半取而灰之，能辟兵伤之毒，此乃以才见害耳。 岂不谓能神於物而不能自神於身？ 斯亦白龟见梦於宋元君之类，可不哀哉？ 精泄者中易残， 动为外邪所害。 华非其时者不可食。 但非正气所资，设使有其英润，亦能反我之常性也。 舌之与齿，孰先弊，绳之与矢，孰先直。 齿刚先弊，矢直先折。 柔而婉者，乃全刚直之德者也。 使影曲者形也，使向浊者声也。 当慎其本。 与死者同病，难为良医，与亡国同道，不可为忠谋。 是知君上当可受药石之谏也。 尝试论曰，凡称难者，犹可严戒精释以涉之，不可正者，容可合权适变以佐之。 物无弃材，理无弃事，取旨会意，或在斯焉。 则所谓君御臣，臣事君，各宜慎其所以者。 使倡吹竿，使工摄窍，虽中节不可使决，君刑亡焉。 决，定也。 不可使定音律矣。 如君臣乱伦，代司政业，则刑法虽当，不足施立。 若因位考法，可谓君刑，双得也。 聋者不歌无以自乐，盲者不观无以接物， 心有所期则形声自至，故静其心者，外无物也。 步於林者，不得直道，行於险者，不得履绳。 婴物不可免乱，犯难不可免害。 而步以之林，行以从险，则安能涉弃逝之夷路，游至直之通衢也？ 海内其所出，故能大， 言含德之所致也。 夫不杜耳目而包声色，不扃真性而一夷险，如斯之道，方与大海同其容，应出纳之德耳。 日不并出，狐不二雄，神龙不匹，猛兽不群，鸷鸟不双。 夫一君之德，一用之村，尚无俦匹，而况圣人大化之道，独运之功也？ 盖非撩不能蔽日，轮非辐不能追疾，然撩辐未足恃也。 凡有能及於物者，莫作相假，考验由实，未足恃功。 故圣人济世利用，推能於物，乘势因人，成事而作其功也。 张弓而射，非弦不能发，矢之命中，十分之一。 夫射本在中，不中何射？ 百发一中，功过不补。 而天下建功从事，莫不然矣。 既忘其屡败，独宰其一成，岂不谬於处实行权矣？ 饥马在厩，漠然无声，投刍其旁，争心乃生。 血气之类，未尝无欲。 故不见可欲，则心不争乱也。 三寸之管无当，天下不能满，十石而有塞，百竹而足。 小人狭志，以无厌不满； 君子器宇雅大，当分而足矣。 循绳而断即不过，县衡而量即不差， 直奉於道，即不过於是非； 平施以德，即不差於厚薄。 县古法以类，有时而遂，杖格之属，有时而施， 治今执古法格异宜，虽绳衡同，亦未足定世，唯审时知变者可。 是而行之谓之断，非而行之谓之乱。
chunks.translated_text:
「Its constancy is thus established.
　　The deaf have no ears yet their sight cannot be deceived—refined in clarity;
　　The blind have no eyes yet their hearing cannot be deceived—refined in perception.
　　Who would then complain or grieve?
　　Gold’s strength surpasses wood—
　　Yet one blade cannot harm an entire forest;
　　Earth’s strength surpasses water—
　　Yet one dipper cannot dam a river;
　　Water’s strength surpasses fire—
　　Yet one sip cannot extinguish a cartload of fuel.
　　Though one holds the means to control,
　　If their virtue and power are insufficient,
　　It is as if they gain no benefit at all.

　　Winter’s thunder, summer’s hail,
　　Cold and heat do not alter their seasons;
　　Frost and snow descend in abundance,
　　Yet melt when the sun rises.
　　Before the winter solstice, the yang-qi descends and forms thunder;
　　Before the summer solstice, the yin-qi ascends and congeals into hail.
　　Even in the months of extreme cold or heat,
　　Their changes are never entirely cut off.
　　If frost and snow are applied to them,
　　They will vanish with the sun’s light—
　　This is what is called *inner necessity* (*zhōng yǒu bìrán*), which cannot be externally controlled;
　　*Seasonal necessity* (*shí yǒu bìzhì*), which cannot be altered by things.
　　Only the wise and enlightened discern this for proper application.

　　Tilt easily topples, lean easily adheres;
　　A slight push aids, moisture easily brings rain.
　　Thus, the virtuous act accordingly and pass on their teachings—
　　Their methods are simple yet effective.

　　The orchid’s fragrance thrives,
　　Yet if it does not see frost,
　　It withers in the midst of its prime—
　　How could those of talent not be cautious?

　　The toad repels soldiers,
　　Its lifespan ending on the fifth month’s full moon.
　　If taken at the halfway point of the fifth month and burned,
　　It can repel soldiers but its poison harms—
　　This is talent being harmed by misuse.
　　Is it not said that one can be divine in things yet fail to divine themselves?
　　Such as the white tortoise dreaming in the Song and Yuan courts—
　　How lamentable!

　　Those whose *qi* is dissipated are prone to inner decay,
　　Whose actions invite external harm.
　　Fruits out of season are inedible.
　　Even if they possess their own vitality and luster,
　　They can disrupt my natural constitution.

　　Which comes first to ruin—the tongue or the teeth?
　　Which is straight—the bowstring or the arrow?
　　The teeth, being rigid, wear first;
　　The arrow, being straight, bends first.
　　What is supple and yielding preserves the virtue of rigidity and straightness.

　　Shadows distort form,
　　Echoes distort voice—
　　One must guard their roots.

　　To treat the dead as if they were alive is no good physician,
　　To serve a fallen kingdom as if it were still standing is no loyal counselor.
　　Thus, a ruler must be open to medicinal advice.

　　When discussing difficulties,
　　One can still enforce strict discipline and refine the *qi* to overcome them;
　　When the proper course is impossible,
　　One may combine expedients and adapt to changes to assist.
　　No material is wasted, no principle abandoned—
　　Seizing intent and harmonizing meaning may lie therein.

　　Therefore, the saying: *"A ruler governs ministers, ministers serve the ruler—
　　Each must be cautious in their approach."*
　　If one commands the *chāngchuí* flute yet lacks control,
　　The ruler’s authority will perish.
　　*Què*—to fix or determine.
　　One cannot fix the pitch of music.

　　If a ruler and minister violate proper order,
　　Or if one usurps political authority,
　　Even if the punishments are correct,
　　They cannot be properly enforced.
　　If one examines positions and laws accordingly,
　　This is called *"ruler’s punishments"*—double gain.

　　The deaf cannot sing to find joy,
　　The blind cannot observe to engage with the world—
　　Yet when the heart has its expectations,
　　Form and sound naturally arise.
　　Thus, calming the heart means nothing external remains.

　　Walking through the woods cannot follow a straight path,
　　Treading on perilous ground cannot measure a plumb line.
　　To be entangled with things is to invite disorder,
　　To confront calamity is to risk harm.
　　Yet if one walks through the woods or treads on perilous ground,
　　How could they then traverse the smooth, abandoned paths,
　　Or wander the wide, straight avenues?

　　The sea encompasses all within its domain,
　　Thus it is vast—
　　This is the virtue of containing all things.
　　He who does not close their ears and eyes yet embraces sounds and colors,
　　Who does not lock away their true nature to level all dangers and risks,
　　Such a person’s Dao aligns with the sea’s capacity—
　　They embody the virtue of harmonious reception and transformation.

　　The sun does not rise twice in one day,
　　The fox does not have two lords,
　　The divine dragon does not pair,
　　The fierce beast does not gather in groups,
　　The rapacious bird does not fly in twos.
　　The virtue of a single ruler,
　　The singularity of one application,
　　Still lacks equal or match—
　　How much more so the Dao of the Sage and the grand transformations,
　　The singular achievements of their solitary operations?

　　It is not the *liáo* whisk that can obscure the sun,
　　Nor the *fú* spokes that can outrun swiftness—
　　Yet even these are not sufficient to rely upon.
　　All who can influence things
　　Do so through relative means—
　　Verification comes from reality,
　　And this is not enough to depend on.
　　Thus, the Sage aids the world and benefits its use,
　　Extending their influence through things,
　　Riding the momentum while relying on people,
　　Accomplishing deeds and claiming their rewards.

　　Drawing the bow to shoot,
　　The string alone cannot release the arrow—
　　Yet only one in ten strikes its mark.
　　If shooting aims to hit,
　　Why shoot if it does not?
　　A hundred shots, one hit—
　　Success and failure cancel each other out.
　　Yet all under heaven build their achievements thus—
　　They forget their repeated failures,
　　Only celebrating their one success,
　　Is this not absurd in balancing reality and expedience?

　　A hungry horse in the stable
　　Is silent and still;
　　Yet when hay is placed beside it,
　　Its competitive spirit awakens.
　　The nature of blood and *qi* is never without desire—
　　Thus, when nothing desirable is seen,
　　The heart does not stir into conflict.

　　A three-inch flute cannot reach its full potential,
　　Yet the world cannot be filled by it alone;
　　Ten stones may suffice to block,
　　Yet a hundred bamboos are needed to reinforce.
　　The petty-minded have narrow ambitions,
　　Ever unsatisfied and never fulfilled;
　　The noble-minded possess spacious virtue,
　　Dividing what is needed and finding sufficiency.

　　Following the plumb line to cut does not exceed,
　　Using the balance scale to measure does not err—
　　Yet if one upholds the Dao directly,
　　They will not exceed right and wrong;
　　If one applies virtue evenly,
　　They will not err in thickness or thinness.
　　To lean on ancient laws and categories,
　　Sometimes proves effective,
　　Yet to rely solely on rigid standards,
　　Sometimes fails.
　　To govern the present while adhering to ancient laws and standards,
　　Though the plumb line and balance may align,
　　Still cannot definitively settle the world—
　　Only those who discern the times and know adaptation can.

　　To act thus is called *duàn* (judgment),
　　To act otherwise is called *luàn* (disorder).」

chunks.translated_text:
The law conforms to the times, it stands firm;
The law defies the times, it falls into disuse.

The farmer toils while the noble is nourished,
Laboring in cultivation to provide for the sovereign’s tribute—
Thus, if one diligently upholds the Dao,
There will be no hardship from lowly servitude.

The foolish speak, the wise choose.
Broadly gathering and praising, they select the good and act upon it.
If one possesses true wisdom,
They can establish themselves by following others.

To perceive clearly is like holding jade and stone—
Those who see principles distinctly,
Are like jade within stone, plainly discernible.
If perception is dim, one must preserve their counsel.
If vision is murky, action becomes impossible.

The brilliance of a hundred stars
Cannot match the light of a single moon,
And ten open windows
Cannot rival the clarity of one door.
Those who accumulate small wisdom, deeming themselves enlightened,
Cannot yet comprehend the myriad categories.

A belly-serpent cannot serve as a foot,
Nor a tiger as wings.
The Dao of Heaven diminishes excess,
Yet even so, if it unleashes calamity and venom,
Those who harm the world—
Should they not be feared and warned?

Now, the ancient six *chi* (feet),
Is but a single *bu* (step) of today.

chunks.original_text: 卧而越之，下才不难， 既在一步之内，又处人下，将欲过，岂难跨越？ 才与材同用也。 立而踰之，上才不易， 取向者六尺之度，随卓立之将踰，上材即不易其得也。 势施异也。 同此六尺之材，而异所施之势，即难易将隔，上下县殊，是以君子恶居下流，自强不息也。 助祭者得尝，救斗者得伤， 且辅相善恶，犹利害以及身，则自为之效，足可明矣。 蔽於不祥之木，为雷霆所朴。 苟失所依，虽不遇刑诛，亦未免所累。 故君子择处其地也。 日月欲明，浮云盖之； 何水欲清，沙土秽之； 丛兰欲修，秋风败之； 人性欲平，嗜欲害之； 当慎所好恶也。 蒙尘而欲无眯，不可得洁。 未闻犯声色而性全者也。 黄金龟钿，贤者以为佩，土坏布在地，能者以为富。 故与弱者金玉，不如与之尺素。 物无贵贱，唯合宜当用为贵耳。 夫不能佩，不能富者，自可谓失治地之宜，旷进德之道也。 毂虚而中立三十辐，各尽其力，使一辐独入，众辐皆弃，何近远之所能至。 凡人君虚心延士，则仁者为之处，义者与之立，各尽其力矣。 将任一材，固不可驱御天下也。 橘柚有乡，雈苇有丛，兽同足者相从游，鸟同翼者相从翔。 方以类聚，物以群分。 虽杂糅无穷，唯同之者可治也。 欲观九州之地，足无千里之行，无政教之原，而欲为万民上者，难矣。 君能度时布政，因情设教，而兆民自戴於己，亦何难之有哉？ 凶凶者获，提提者射。 谓其有涌有捷，来彼擒射。 故太白若辱，广德若不足。 至素者，容忍常德可不溢。 君子有酒，小人鞭缶，虽不可好，亦不可丑。 君子有酒以成礼，小人击缶亦为乐。 虽节奏非度，世之不传，而适欢和志，自合乐本。 然则礼乐天性，备适贤愚，未可丑小人，独美君子也。 人之性便衣丝帛，或人射之即被甲，为所不便，以得其便也。 既而有所贵者，当在乎时，则知常所贱，未可定弃也。 三十辐共一毂，各直一凿，不得相入，犹人臣各守其职也。 能列材以定位，则任力以致远也。 善用人者，若蚈之足，众而不相害，若舌之与齿，坚柔相而不相败。 善用臣下者，百官虽众，近无夺伦； 文武虽异，亲而成业也。 石生而坚，菃生而芳，少而有之，长而愈明。 夫万物之其宜者，治之则遂。 抑背其性，劳而无功矣。 扶之与提，谢之与让，得之与失，诺之与己，相去千里。 同用异宜，至近而远，世多此类。 故圣人历示以为诫也。 再生者不获莘，而叶太早者不须霜而落。 贵适中也。 先之则失常，后之即亏分。 污其准，粉其颡，腐鼠在昨，烧熏於堂，入水而憎濡，怀臭而求芳，虽善者不能为工。 夫设法不当本，虽善用其法者，亦无以巧取成济也。 冬冰可折，夏木可结，时难得而易失。 天下事理，无难无易，有得时失时之难易，是以重之过於尺璧也。 木方盛，终日采之而复生，秋风下霜，一夕而零。 顺於天者，将易其功； 任於己者，徒劳其力。 质的张而矢射集，林木茂而斧斤入，非或召之也，形势之所致也。 行标於世，必来众妬。 禄丰於家，莫不倾夺。 乳犬之噬虎，伏鸡之搏狸，恩之所加，不量其力。 世莫有量其力分守所爱者，唯信情骋欲，以至於自害耳。 夫待利而登溺者，亦必将以利溺人矣。 赏彼登溺，待之以利，则天下莫不愿溺而拯拔矣。
chunks.translated_text:
To lie down and cross it, the lower talent finds no difficulty,
Yet when it lies within a single step and beneath others,
To pass over it—how difficult to stride across?
Talent and material are used in the same way.

To stand and surmount it, the higher talent is not easily attained;
If one seeks to ascend, measuring the six *chi* (feet),
As they prepare to rise, the higher talent will not easily be gained.
The circumstances differ in their application.

With the same six *chi* of material,
Yet differing in where the circumstances are applied,
Then difficulty and ease become separated,
And distinctions between high and low arise.
Thus, the virtuous avoid dwelling in the lowly stream,
And strive endlessly to strengthen themselves.

The assistant to the sacrificial rites gains a taste,
The one who rescues a drowning man gets hurt—
Those who aid in both good and evil,
Still suffer harm or benefit from it themselves.
Thus, their own consequences are clear enough.

Covered by an unlucky tree,
It is struck by thunder and lightning.
If one loses their proper foundation,
Even without encountering punishment,
They will not escape entanglement.
Hence, the virtuous choose their place carefully.

When the sun and moon wish to shine,
Floating clouds obscure them;
When clear waters wish to be pure,
Sand and soil defile them;
When fragrant orchids wish to flourish,
Autumn winds wither them;
When human nature seeks balance,
Lustful desires corrupt it.
Thus, one must be cautious in their likes and dislikes.

To be covered in dust yet wish to remain unstained—
It cannot be achieved.
I have never heard of one who avoids transgressing against *yīn-yáng* (陰陽) yet remains whole in nature.
Jade and gold are worn by the worthy as ornaments,
While coarse cloth and earthenware are treasured by the capable as wealth.
Thus, giving gold and jade to the weak
Is not as good as giving them a length of plain silk.
Things have no inherent nobility or baseness—
Only their proper use at the right time makes them noble.

Those who cannot wear jade or gold,
Nor treasure coarse cloth and earthenware,
Can truly be called those who have lost the suitability of their place
And neglected the Dao of advancing their virtue.

Thirty spokes converge upon one hub,
Each straight in its own groove,
Yet unable to enter one another—
Just as ministers each uphold their duties.
If one can arrange talents according to their proper stations,
They will then employ their strengths to achieve great distances.

The skillful use of people
Is like the legs of a centipede—
Many yet without mutual harm,
Or the tongue and teeth—
Firm and soft complementing each other without destruction.

The skillful use of ministers and subjects
Is such that officials, though many,
Have no encroachment upon their ranks;
The civil and military, though different,
Are close and complete their undertakings.

Stone is born firm,
Orchids are born fragrant—
From youth, their qualities are present,
And with age, they become ever clearer.
If one governs things according to their nature,
They will naturally succeed.
To force or restrain them,
To take or give them,
To accept or decline them—
These are as distant as heaven and earth.

Same use, yet differing in suitability,
Though near, they are far apart.
The world is full of such cases.
Hence, the Sage demonstrates them as warnings.

Those who grow twice do not reap the *shēn* (莘) grain,
While leaves that sprout too early fall without frost.
Nobility lies in moderation.
Too soon, and it loses its proper measure;
Too late, and it falls short of its due.

To sully their standard,
To powder their foreheads,
To have a rotten rat beside them,
Yet burn incense in the hall—
To enter water yet hate its dampness,
To embrace foulness yet seek fragrance,
Even the most skilled cannot succeed.

If methods are not grounded in their proper principles,
Even those who skillfully apply them
Cannot cleverly achieve their ends.

Winter ice can be bent,
Summer wood can be tied—
Opportunity is hard to obtain yet easy to lose.
It is more precious than a measure of jade and gold.

When trees are in full vigor,
They regrow even after daily cutting,
But when autumn winds descend and frost arrives,
They wither in a single night.
To act in accordance with Heaven’s Dao,
One will easily achieve their aims;
To rely solely on oneself,
One will only waste their strength.

The bowstring drawn and arrows released,
The forest dense and axes entering—
This is not summoned by any,
But the result of form and circumstance.

To stand out in the world,
One must invite universal envy.
If blessings overflow in the home,
They will not escape being coveted and taken.
A suckling pup biting a tiger,
A crouching chicken striking a weasel—
Favor is bestowed without regard to strength.
The world has no one who measures strength and guards their affection,
Only those who indulge desire without restraint,
And thus bring harm upon themselves.

Those who wait for profit to rise from drowning,
Will also drown others for profit.
To reward those who rise from drowning,
And to await them with profit—
Then the world will have none who do not wish to drown and be rescued.

chunks.original_text: 如简子利於放鸠，反多捕者，是以为治之本不贵当功，而在绝其原。 舟能浮，石能沈，愚者不知之焉。 圣人知沉浮之理定矣，故不妄动也。 骥驱之不进，引之不止，人君不以求道里。 贤俊虽有才而忠不奉上，则不可为治也。 水虽平必有波，衡虽正必有差，尺寸虽齐必有危。 虽法教齐平，执而用者未免失当。 非规矩不能定方圆，非准绳无以正曲直，用规矩者，亦有规矩之心。 夫内怀精诚，外无法教，则民之伦叙日知所由。 然其法教大张，精诚不副者，斯亦不信於民，不得於世矣。 故能用规矩者，直在规矩之心。 是以《精诚篇》云：同言为信，信在言前； 同令而行，诚在令外。 岂不谓素有诚信，乃能施用法教也？ 太山之高，倍而不见，秋毫之末，视之可察。 物无巨细，但反之则迷，审之则明也。 竹木有火，不钻不熏，土中有水，不掘不出。 虽性之有道，唯精研乃可得也。 矢之疾不过二里，跬步不休，跛鳖千里。 累世不止，丘山从成。 将欲致远，在乎久而不在动也。 故绵绵者用之无尽，若愚公之类，而山可移焉。 临河欲鱼，不若归而织网。 术其本者，乃可自期也。 弓先调而后求劲，马先顺而后求良，人先信而后求能。 志素求饬，不能饬矣。 保质遗华，文自生矣。 巧冶不能销木，良匠不能琢冰，物有不可，如之何君子不留意。 勿致意於不能之外。 使人无渡河，可； 使河无波，不可。 无所涉去，则彼我自宁。 涉之欲求不溺，不可无也。 无日不辜，甑终不堕井矣。 将无犯涉之罪，则纵彼以波起。 如甑之在灶，无由堕井者也。 刺我行者欲与我交，告我货者欲与我市。 未知其本，不可定怨於物。 而本之难知，故其忽直可者耳。 行一棋不足以见智，弹一弦不足以为悲。 遽责於物，难尽其能。 今有一炭然，掇之烂指相近万石俱熏，去之十步而不死。 同气而异积， 夫气类虽同，积德之异者，固不可辄偕其动用耳。 有荣华者，必有愁悴。 若素安其实，即能一味於世。 上有罗执，下必有麻， 夫主饬其贵，必民苦於贱。 下苦於贱，上难保其贵矣。 木大者根瞿，山高者基扶。 贵立本也。 老子曰：鼓不藏声，故能有声； 镜不没形，故能有形。 怀而存之，固不能常保。 虚而静之，则自然备应也。 金石有声，不动不鸣； 管箫有音，不吹无声。 是以圣人内藏，不为物唱，事来而制，物至而应。 圣人含应而不唱，如彼金石也。 天行不已，终而复始，故能长久。 轮复其转，故能致远。 天行一不差，而无过矣。 常居自然之运，故在不替之德。 天气下，地气上，阴阳交通，万物齐同。 齐受和气，同一生成。 君子用事，小人消亡，天地之道也。 天地交泰，故君子辅相以成功。 天气不下，地气不上，阴阳不通，万物不昌， 谓物不蕃息也。 小人得势，君子消亡， 否则反常，故君子俭德以避难。 五谷不植，道德内藏。 内藏即不昌，消亡之义也。 天之道，损盈而益寡，地之道，损高而益下， 归於均也。 鬼神之道，骄溢与下， 害盈益谦。 人之道，多者不与， 恶盈好谦。 圣人之道，卑而莫能上也。 由谦以致上，则天下不能得上。 天明日明，而后能照四方，君明臣明，域中乃安，有四明，乃能久长。 明 君臣之明，非贵相察。 谓其不昧治化之道，斯与天日同功比德，天下乃宁，四时而安也。
chunks.translated_text:
The reed’s leaves spread and arrows fly in unison,
The forest flourishes and axes strike deep—
Not summoned by any will,
But the inevitable consequence of form and circumstance.

To excel in the world,
One must invite universal resentment.
If wealth abounds in the household,
None will resist its plunder.

A nursling pup daring to bite a tiger,
A hen striking a weasel while crouching—
Favor is given without regard to strength.
The world knows no one who weighs strength and guards their affection,
Only those who trust emotion and indulge desire,
And thus bring ruin upon themselves.

Those who wait for gain from rescuing the drowning,
Will also drown others for gain.
To reward those who rise from drowning,
And to await them with profit—
Then the world will have none who do not wish to drown and be saved.

---

As for Jianzi, though he profited from releasing doves,
He ended up capturing more—
This shows that the true foundation of governance
Does not lie in achieving immediate results,
But in cutting off its source.

A boat can float, a stone can sink,
Yet the foolish do not comprehend this principle.
The Sage understands the fixed laws of sinking and floating,
Thus never acts rashly.

A swift horse does not advance when driven,
Nor halt when pulled—
A ruler should not seek the Dao in such ways.
Even if the worthy are talented,
If they lack loyalty and do not offer their service,
They cannot be relied upon for governance.

Though water is level, waves must arise,
Though a balance is true, it must tilt,
Though measures are uniform, they must falter.
Even if laws and teachings are equal and fair,
Those who enforce and apply them may still err.

Without the compass and square, no shape can be defined,
Without the plumb line and level, no crookedness can be corrected.
Yet even those who use the compass and square
May harbor flaws in their own hearts.

If one’s inner sincerity is pure,
And external laws and teachings are absent,
The people’s natural order will daily reveal its path.
But if laws and teachings are widely proclaimed,
Yet inner sincerity fails to match,
Then neither will the people trust nor the world accept.

Thus, the true mastery of laws lies in the heart’s sincerity.
Hence the *Precision and Sincerity* chapter states:
*"Words spoken in unison are trustworthy,
For trust lies in the speaker’s resolve before utterance;
Orders given in harmony are obeyed,
For sincerity lies beyond the command itself."*
Does it not mean that genuine sincerity must precede the application of laws?

The Tai Mountain’s height—
Doubled, yet still unseen—
The autumn hair’s tip—
Examined, yet clearly discerned.
Things, great or small,
If turned away, become obscured,
If scrutinized, become clear.

Fire in bamboo and wood—
Without drilling, it does not spread.
Water in the earth—
Without digging, it does not emerge.
Though nature has its ways,
Only through diligent study can they be attained.

An arrow’s speed does not exceed two *li*,
Yet if taken step by step without rest,
A lame tortoise can traverse a thousand *li*.
Layered ages without pause,
And hills become mountains.
To reach distant goals,
Lies in persistence, not in haste.

Thus, steady effort endures without exhaustion,
Like the foolish old man who could move mountains.
To catch fish by the river,
Better to return home and cast nets.
Mastering the root alone
Ensures self-reliance in the long term.

A bow must first be strung before seeking its strength,
A horse must first be trained before seeking its excellence,
A person must first be trusted before seeking their ability.
If one’s resolve is refined from the start,
It cannot later be refined.
Preserve one’s essence, and splendor will follow naturally.
A skilled artisan cannot burn wood,
A master craftsman cannot carve ice—
Things have their limits; how can the virtuous ignore this?
Do not fixate on what cannot be achieved.

To make people never cross the river,
Is possible;
To make the river never have waves,
Is impossible.
If there is no crossing to be made,
Then peace remains between us and them.
But if one must cross and seek to avoid drowning,
It cannot be without waves.

If a pot never falls into a well,
It will never be without blame—
Yet the pot on the hearth
Has no way to fall into the well.
Those who reproach my actions wish to engage with me,
Those who offer goods wish to trade with me.
If I do not know their true intentions,
I cannot blame them for their deeds.
Yet since their motives are hard to discern,
I must treat them with sudden directness.

A single move in chess does not reveal one’s wisdom,
A single pluck on a string does not express one’s sorrow.
To hastily accuse others
Is to fail to exhaust their potential.

Now, there is a burning coal:
If touched, it scorches one’s fingers—
Yet if placed near a pile of ten thousand stones,
All may be warmed.
If removed ten steps away,
It does not kill.
Though their *qi* is the same,
Their accumulated virtue differs—
For though their *qi* may be similar,
Those whose virtue is unevenly stored
Cannot be recklessly paired in their actions.

There is splendor, there must be decline.
If one’s nature is truly settled,
Then one can remain undisturbed by the world’s changes.
When the upper reaches are strict,
The lower must suffer.
If a lord refines his nobility,
The people will endure the burdens of lowliness.
If the lower suffer lowliness,
The upper cannot long preserve his nobility.

Great trees have deep roots,
High mountains have firm foundations—
Nobility rests in its roots.
Laozi said:
*"The drum does not hide its sound,
Thus it can produce sound;
The mirror does not conceal its form,
Thus it can reflect form.
To hoard and preserve,
One cannot always maintain it.
To empty and still,
Then all responses will naturally suffice."*

Metal and stone produce sound,
Yet they do not ring unless struck.
Flutes and shawms emit tones,
Yet they are silent unless blown.
Thus the Sage remains inwardly reserved,
Never led by external things,
Acting only when matters arise,
Responding only when things present themselves.
The Sage contains responses without prompting,
Like metal and stone.

The Dao of Heaven flows without ceasing,
Yet returns to its beginning,
Thus it endures forever.
The wheel turns repeatedly,
Thus it reaches distant places.
If Heaven’s Dao is never misaligned,
There is no excess.
Abiding in Heaven’s natural course,
One attains unchanging virtue.

When Heaven’s *qi* descends,
And Earth’s *qi* ascends,
Yin and Yang intermingle,
All things harmonize in unity.
Unity receives the nurturing *qi*,
And all things are born in equal measure.
The virtuous thrive, the depraved perish—
The Dao of Heaven and Earth.

When Heaven and Earth exchange in harmony,
The virtuous support and complement each other to achieve success.
If Heaven’s *qi* does not descend,
And Earth’s *qi* does not ascend,
If Yin and Yang do not intermingle,
All things do not flourish—
Meaning they do not multiply and grow.
The depraved gain influence,
The virtuous perish—
This is contrary to the natural order,
Thus the virtuous cultivate moderation to avoid calamity.

The Five Grains do not grow,
Yet the Dao of Virtue remains preserved.
If the Dao of Virtue is preserved,
It does not flourish—
This is the meaning of perishing.

The Dao of Heaven:
*"It diminishes the full and benefits the scarce,
The Dao of Earth:
*"It diminishes the high and benefits the low,
Both returning to balance.
The Dao of Ghosts and Spirits:
*"It harms the arrogant and benefits the humble.
The Dao of Man:
*"It shuns the excessive and favors the modest.
The Dao of the Sage:
*"It is lowly, yet none can surpass it.
Through modesty, one attains the heights,
Thus the world cannot claim the heights for itself.

When Heaven’s light is clear,
Then it can illuminate the four directions.
When a ruler is enlightened,
And his ministers are enlightened,
The realm will be at peace,
And the four seasons will bring stability.
This is the path to enduring prosperity.

The enlightenment of ruler and minister
Is not about mutual scrutiny—
It is about not obscuring the Dao of governance,
Thus aligning with Heaven’s light and comparing virtues,
And the world will find peace,
With the four seasons in harmony.
chunks.overlap_context:
A suckling pup biting a tiger,
A crouching chicken striking a weasel—
Favor is bestowed without regard to strength.
The world has no one who measures strength and guards their affection,
Only those who indulge desire without restraint,
And thus bring harm upon themselves.

Those who wait for profit to rise from drowning,
Will also drown others for profit.
To reward those who rise from drowning,
And to await them with profit—
Then the world will have none who do not wish to drown and be rescued.

chunks.original_text: 然君臣未正，则虽天日之明域中，未免昏乱。 人法天者，乃长久也。 其施明者，明其化也。 所施之明，直能化下。 天道为文，地道为理， 星纬之文，川渎之理。 一为之和，时为之使，以成万物，命之曰道。 一气以和生，四时以信长。 推变万类，名昊天之道也。 大道坦坦，去身不远， 身者，天地之一物，岂非道乎哉？ 修之身，其德乃真， 唯顺安命不知其他，则冥符真体自然成德也。 修之物，其德不绝。 由接物恢弘精，顺理本动，而因万物之无穷，故德之莫能御也。 天覆万物，施其德而养之，与而不取，故精神归焉。 夫养物之主，莫非天德也。 然无状系物，岂外取哉？ 精神者，初禀轻清之朗廓，故天有不德之德，所以上也； 精神有虚通之能，所以贵也。 以贵归上，理从其类耳。 与而不取者上德也，是以有德。 无迹而成功，不德而居上。 高莫高於天也，下莫下於泽也，天高泽下，圣人法之，尊卑有叙，天下定矣。 泽当如地。 圣人法天地以叙尊卑，故君臣父子各正其所，古今不易，是称大定。 地泽万物而长之，与而取之，故骨骸归焉。 天有长物之形，地有资与之德，然在方系物矣，安取其功哉？ 骨肉者初禀重浊，终委块壤，故地有执德之迹，所以下也。 骨肉有滞碍之患，所以贱也。 以贱归下，理亦然者耳。 与而取者下德也，下德不失德，是以无德。 全乎有迹之功，固非上德之位，是以圣人玄德同於天也，立德同於地也。 地承天，故定宁，地定宁，万物形， 形犹生成。 地广厚，万物聚， 聚载其上。 定宁无不载，广厚无不容。 地势深厚，水原入聚，地道广方，故能长久， 广有大林，方有大德。 圣人法之，德无不容。 卑则物归，宁则自得。 阴难阳，万物昌； 阴为阳所制，则万物昌盛，谓四月节前也。 阳消阴，万物湛。 阳为阴所消，则万物湛息。 谓十月节前也。 物昌无不赡也，物湛无不乐也，物乐则无不冶者矣。 气生於形，故赡也。 无劳於生，故乐也。 处其静者，将自治矣。 阴害物，阳自屈，阴进阳退，小人得势，君子避害，天道然也。 动静有时，故违天，必有大咎也。 阳气动，万物缓而得其所，是以圣人顺阳道。 所谓顺时而行，乃能得欲举，无违事也。 夫顺物者物亦顺之，逆物者物亦逆之， 化周彼者，物无异也； 物异我者，化未周也。 故不失物之情性。 污泽盈，万物无节成； 物也者，所宜为性，时宜为情。 布政设教，不失二宜，则万物全其润泽，咸有信而成熟。 污泽枯，万物无节叶。 英华及节而不生矣。 故雨泽不行，天下荒亡， 山无法道，抑否失时，则蒸人不粒，荒乱流亡也。 阳上而复下，故为万物主。 位高而德谦也。 高则物奉，谦则物亲，故可为之主矣。 弗长有，故能终而复始， 其道消息，故不穷绝。 终而复始，故能长久，故为天下母。 母天下者，非有是德，如何也？ 阳气蓄而后能施，阴气积而后能化，未有不蓄积而能化者也。 夫自体未全，不能立事，况胜任万物，非乎蓄积之大哉？ 故圣人慎所积。 唯积德合和，堪化天下矣。 阳灭阴，万物肥； 阴灭阳，万物衰。 故王公尚阳道则万民昌， 谓和气洽民矣。 尚阴道即天下亡。 谓杀气灭国耳。 阳不下阴，万物不成， 阴体卑静，故阳德不降，则不能成化。
chunks.translated_text:
The Way of Ruler and Subject yet unaligned,
Even though Heaven’s light shines over the realm,
Chaos and darkness still prevail.

To emulate Heaven is to endure.
The application of enlightenment lies in its transformative power.
The enlightenment applied must first transform those below.

The Dao of Heaven is *wen* (pattern),
The Dao of Earth is *li* (principle).
The patterns of stars and constellations,
The principles of rivers and streams—
One unifies them in harmony,
Time governs their shifts,
Thus all things are completed—
This is called the Dao.

Qi unifies to generate life,
The four seasons faithfully nurture growth.
Pushing through transformations of myriad forms,
This is the Dao of the Celestial Sovereign.

The Great Dao is vast and near—
The body, a thing of Heaven and Earth,
How could it not be the Dao?

Cultivate it within the self,
And virtue becomes true.
If one follows naturally and accepts fate,
Unknowingly aligning with the true essence,
Then virtue arises spontaneously.

Cultivate it in things,
And virtue will never cease.
Through expansive interaction with all things,
Following their inherent principles,
And thus aligning with the boundless nature of all things,
Virtue cannot be constrained.

Heaven covers all things,
Bestowing its virtue to nourish them,
Giving without taking—
Thus, spirit returns to it.

The master of nourishment is none other than Heaven’s virtue.
Yet without form, it binds all things—
How could it be externally imposed?

Spirit is initially endowed with lightness and clarity,
Thus Heaven possesses virtue without virtue—
This is why it is exalted.
Spirit has the capacity for emptiness and openness—
This is why it is honored.
To honor and return to the exalted is natural,
As things follow their kind.

To give without taking is the virtue of the exalted—
Thus, it possesses virtue.
Without trace yet achieving success,
Without virtue yet residing above—
Nothing is higher than Heaven,
Nothing is lower than the marsh.
Heaven is high, the marsh is low—
The Sage follows this,
Establishing order of high and low,
Thus the world is settled.

The marsh should be like the Earth.
The Sage follows Heaven and Earth,
Ordering high and low,
Thus ruler and subject, father and son,
Each fulfill their proper roles—
Ancient and modern, unchanging,
This is called Great Stability.

Earth nourishes and sustains all things,
Giving and taking—
Thus bones and flesh return to it.

Heaven has the form of sustaining all things,
Earth has the virtue of providing resources,
Yet when it comes to binding all things,
Where does it claim its function?

Bones and flesh are initially heavy and turbid,
Ultimately returning to the clods of earth—
Thus Earth has the trace of enduring virtue—
This is why it is lowly.
Bones and flesh suffer from stagnation and obstruction—
This is why they are base.
To base and return to the lowly is natural,
As things follow their kind.

To give and take is the virtue of the lowly—
The lowly virtue does not lose virtue,
Thus it has no virtue.
Fully achieving traceable results,
It is not the position of exalted virtue—
Thus the Sage’s mysterious virtue aligns with Heaven,
And established virtue aligns with Earth.

Earth supports Heaven,
Thus stability and peace endure.
Earth is stable and peaceful,
Thus all things take form—
Form is like birth and growth.
Earth is vast and thick,
Thus all things gather upon it.
Stability and peace hold nothing unborne,
Vastness and thickness contain nothing unheld.
Earth’s depth and thickness gather waters and streams,
Earth’s Dao is broad and square—
Thus it endures.
Broadness holds great forests,
Squareness embodies great virtue.
The Sage follows this,
Thus virtue contains all things.
Lowliness draws things to it,
Peace brings self-possession.

When Yin harms things, Yang withdraws,
And if Yin advances while Yang retreats,
The petty gain influence,
The virtuous avoid harm—
This is the Dao of Heaven.
Motion and stillness have their times,
Thus to defy Heaven brings great calamity.

When Yang-qi moves, all things relax and find their place—
Thus the Sage follows the Dao of Yang.
To act in accordance with the times,
One can achieve desires without contradiction.

To follow things, things will follow in return;
To oppose things, things will oppose in return.
To transform thoroughly, things will not differ;
If things differ from me, transformation is incomplete.
Thus, one does not lose the nature and disposition of things.

When the marsh overflows, all things grow without measure;
Things have their inherent nature as their proper form,
And their proper time as their disposition.
To govern and teach without losing these two,
Then all things will flourish with nourishment,
All will be trustworthy and mature.

When the marsh dries up, all things wither without leaves—
Their blossoms and flowers do not appear at their proper times.
Thus, if rains do not fall in season,
The world falls into ruin and chaos—
Mountains without paths,
Oppression and neglect,
Then the people do not bear grain,
And chaos and flight ensue.

Yang ascends yet returns below,
Thus it is the master of all things.
High in position yet humble in virtue.
Highness makes things reverent,
Humility makes things affectionate—
Thus it can be their master.

Not overreaching possession,
Thus it can end and begin anew.
Its Dao wanes and flourishes,
Thus it does not reach exhaustion.
Ending and beginning anew,
Thus it endures—
Thus it is the Mother of the world.
To be the Mother of the world,
Without this virtue, how could it be?

Yang-qi accumulates before it can be bestowed,
Yin-qi accumulates before it can transform—
There is none who can transform without accumulation.
If one’s own essence is not complete,
One cannot establish affairs—
How much more to govern all things?
Thus the Sage is cautious in what is accumulated.
Only by accumulating virtue and achieving harmony
Can one be capable of transforming the world.

When Yang extinguishes Yin, all things thrive;
When Yin extinguishes Yang, all things decline.
Thus, if kings and nobles uphold the Dao of Yang,
The people will flourish—
Meaning harmonious qi nourishes the people.
If they uphold the Dao of Yin, the world will perish—
Meaning killing qi destroys the state.

If Yang does not descend to Yin,
All things cannot be completed.
Yin is low and still,
Thus Yang’s virtue does not descend—
Then transformation cannot be achieved.

chunks.original_text: 君不下臣，德化不行， 臣道代终，故君恩不施，则不能行政。 故君下臣即听明， 得天下耳目视听耳。 不下臣即暗聋。 一人闻见，不可胜用。 日出於地，万物蕃息，王公居民上，以明道德； 大人居上位，则道洽德被於民，如日出地，蕃息万物。 日入於地，万物休息，小人居民上，万物逃匿。 小人居上位，则无方御下，使之离散，如日入地，万物当废息乎？ 雷之动也，万物启； 雨之润也，万物解； 大人施行，有似於此。 动以启蛰，润以发生。 人君行令，若天作雷雨，未有不从其令也。 阴阳之动有常节，大人之动不极物。 法天应时，所以动而无失。 亢极於物者，则抑性而有绝也。 雷动地，万物缓； 风摇树，草木散。 大人去恶就善， 天地布德除秽，大人革弊施政耳。 民弗远徙，故民之有去就也，去尤甚，就尤愈。 民皆乐土，不愿移徙，唯苛政之甚，不得不去。 惠泽少及，不得不就。 非谓性分之所易也。
chunks.translated_text:
The lord does not descend to his ministers,
And virtue’s transformation cannot be enacted—
Thus the ministers’ way comes to an end,
And the lord’s benevolence is not bestowed,
Then governance cannot be achieved.

Therefore, when the lord descends to his ministers,
Their wisdom is heard—
He gains the ears and eyes of all under heaven.
If he does not descend to his ministers,
He becomes deaf and blind.
A single person’s perception
Cannot be relied upon to govern all.

When the sun rises from the earth,
All things flourish and grow—
Kings and nobles dwell above the people,
Illuminating virtue and the Dao.
When great officials occupy high positions,
The Way spreads and virtue enfolds the people,
Like the sun rising from the earth,
Nourishing all things.

When the sun sets into the earth,
All things rest—
When petty men rule above the people,
All things flee and hide.
When petty men occupy high positions,
They cannot govern in all directions,
Driving the people to scatter,
Like the sun setting into the earth—
Would all things then perish and cease?

When thunder moves, all things awaken;
When rain nourishes, all things unfurl—
Great officials act in this manner:
Stirring to awaken the dormant,
Nourishing to bring forth growth.
When the sovereign issues decrees,
Like heaven’s thunder and rain,
None dare disobey his command.

The movements of Yin and Yang follow fixed seasons,
Yet great officials do not exhaust the people.
They follow the heavens and respond to the times,
Thus their actions are never misplaced.
Those who push beyond the limits of the people
Suppress their nature and bring ruin.

When thunder shakes the earth, all things relax;
When wind sways the trees, grasses and woods scatter.
Great officials abandon vice and embrace goodness—
Heaven and earth spread virtue and remove filth,
Great officials reform flaws and enact governance.
The people do not flee far,
Thus their coming and going is extreme:
They flee when wrongs are extreme,
They gather when benefits are greater.
All people love their native soil,
And do not wish to migrate—
Only when governance is oppressive beyond measure
Are they forced to depart.
When kindness and blessings reach few,
They are compelled to return.
This is not because their nature easily shifts.

chunks.original_text: 风不动，火不出，大人不言，小人无述。 火因风出，民由上教。 火之出也，必待薪，火人之言，必有信。 有信而真，何往不成？ 夫火之依薪，言之在信，所以炎炽。 若能法教有恒，真而不渝，所往皆遂也。 河水深，坏在山，丘陵高，下入渊， 义已见上。 阳气盛，变为阴，阴气盛，变为阳，故欲不可盈，乐不可极。 盈则覆，极则反。 忿无恶言怒无作色，是谓计得。 能审报复之道，而不先犯以招其咎，是谓保安之计得也。 火上炎，水下流，圣人之道，以类相求， 虽舛错万类，而同其方者，莫不得之。 圣人依阳天下和同，依阴天下溺沉。 阳道生畅，阴道肃杀。 若然流布德泽，则民和洽； 全用荆楚，则民垫溺也。 老子曰：积薄成厚，积卑成高， 高行厚德在乎积修，首辱重变在乎积犯。 君子日汲汲以成辉，小人日快快以至辱。 汲汲自强，日以成德； 快快从欲，以至身辱。 所积之异。 其消息也，虽未能见， 言君子之心，亦未能消息。 倚伏之道，但慕善直，前自成辉耳。 故见善如弗及，依不善如不祥。 见彼善事，欲速循进； 处不善事，如在灾祸也。 苟向善虽过无怨； 且有向道之者，虽为物所咎，亦无加怨於物。 以明君子之道自有常行之矣。 苟不向善，虽忠来恶， 素无向善之心，虽有物忠顺於己，而必有不忠之时； 虽来其恶，遂生怨於彼者也。 然物与我期，理难常顺，责彼以恒，固未之可。 乃知怨之所起，直在自无恒德也。 故怨人不知自怨， 怨由自作，奈何非物。 勉求诸人，不如求诸己。 自得即物无不得，岂非不假求佗人？ 故声自召也，类自求也，名自命也，人自官也，无非己者。 已上四者，皆由己得也。 自官，谓贤愚所赡之位耳。 操锐以刺，操刃以击，何怨於人？ 害物物报，怨可自怨。 故君子慎其微。 慎机发之微也。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和， 夫二气交盛，乃曰和也。 万物之形，虽背阴向阳，而虚灵之气则禀和也。 和居中央，是以木实生於心，草实生於英， 英亦草心。 卵胎生於中央， 皆和居中央，而生其草木胎卵。 虽情性殊别，然其禀气受类，莫非以和居中之故也。 不卵不胎，生而须时。 自湿自燥而化生者，须伺春秋湿燥之节以感生也。 斯亦与和俱生耳。 地平即水不流，轻重均即衡不倾，物之生化也，有感以然。 阳盛即生，阴盛即死。 如彼衢水，随感倾波，得乎中和，平而正也。 老子曰：山致其高，而云雨起焉，水致其深，而蛟龙生焉。 君子致其道，而德泽流焉。 道之高深，固能流德。 夫有阴德者，而有阳报，有隐行者，必有昭名。 夫阴德无机，乃德之真者。 隐行无求，乃行之实者。 既真且实，虽欲报之不明，名之不显，亦未之得矣。 树黍者不获稷，树怨者无报德。 种黍得黍，树怨得怨。 通玄真经卷之六竟 通玄真经卷之七
chunks.translated_text:
The wind does not move, the fire does not emerge,
The sage remains silent, the petty do not speak.
Fire emerges only with wind,
The people follow the teachings of their superiors.

When fire emerges, it must have fuel,
When a person speaks, their words must be true.
With truth and sincerity, what cannot be accomplished?
Fire depends on fuel, speech on truth—
Thus they blaze and flourish.

If one follows teachings with constancy,
And remains true without wavering,
All endeavors shall succeed.

The Yellow River runs deep, its destruction lies in the mountains;
High hills descend into the abyss—
The principle is already evident above.

When *yang* qi prevails, it transforms into *yin*;
When *yin* qi prevails, it transforms into *yang*.
Thus, desire cannot be overfilled,
Nor joy pushed to its extreme.
Excess leads to ruin,
Extremity invites reversal.

Anger without harsh words,
Rage without showing color—
This is called *calculating success*.

To discern the way of retaliation,
Yet not to provoke blame by striking first—
This is called *securing safety through strategy*.

Fire ascends, water descends;
The Sage’s Way seeks its kind—
Though myriad things may stray,
Those sharing its principle shall all be found.

The Sage, relying on *yang*, brings harmony to the world;
Relying on *yin*, brings stagnation and drowning.
The *yang* Way nurtures and flourishes,
The *yin* Way is stern and destructive.
If virtue and blessings are spread widely,
The people shall be harmonious and content;
If only the harsh ways of Chu are employed,
The people shall sink in misery.

Laozi said:
Thin layers accumulate into thickness,
Low steps rise to heights.
Noble conduct and profound virtue arise from steady cultivation,
While initial shame and grave errors stem from repeated transgressions.
The virtuous strive earnestly to achieve brilliance,
The petty indulge recklessly to invite disgrace.
Earnest self-strengthening builds virtue daily;
Reckless indulgence in desires leads to self-ruin.
The difference lies in what is accumulated.

Though its rise and fall may not be immediately visible,
The virtuous heart does not waver in its constancy.
The Way of rise and fall lies in emulating goodness and uprightness,
Advancing swiftly toward brilliance from the start.
Thus, seeing goodness as if unable to catch up,
Treating evil as if facing calamity.
Witnessing virtuous deeds, one hastens to follow;
Encountering vice, one acts as if in disaster.
If one turns toward goodness, even exceeding bounds brings no regret;
Those who follow the Way, though blamed by others,
Shall bear no resentment toward them.
For the virtuous Way has its unchanging practice.

If one does not turn toward goodness,
Even loyalty may turn to evil—
Without an inherent inclination toward virtue,
Even if others are loyal, there shall be times of betrayal;
Though they bring harm, resentment shall arise toward them.
Yet, people and I have mutual expectations,
And constancy in virtue is not easily maintained.
To blame others for their inconstancy is unjust.

Thus, those who harbor resentment do not blame themselves,
For resentment stems from one’s own actions—
Why accuse others?
Seeking virtue in others is less fruitful than seeking it within.
Self-mastery ensures all else is obtained—
Why rely on others?
Thus, reputation is self-summoned,
Kindred spirits seek one another,
Fame is self-bestowed,
And position is self-assumed—
None of it comes from outside oneself.

Self-assumed position refers to the rank befitting wisdom or folly.
Wielding sharpness to strike, wielding blades to attack—
Why blame others?
Harming others invites retaliation;
Resentment is self-inflicted.
Thus, the virtuous must guard against the subtle beginnings.

All things bear *yin* while embracing *yang*,
Their harmonizing *qi* forming unity.
When the two *qi* blend in balance, it is called *he*.
Though things may face *yin* or turn toward *yang*,
Their vital essence receives harmony.
*Harmony* resides centrally—
Thus, grains grow in the heart,
Grasses bear fruit in their stalks,
For stalks are the heart of grasses.
Eggs and fetuses form in the center,
All born from *harmony* dwelling centrally.
Though their natures differ,
They all receive *qi* and kindred essence
From *harmony*’s central abode.

Those not born from eggs or wombs
Require time to gestate,
Moistened and dried by seasonal shifts to take form—
They too arise with *harmony*.

When the earth is level, water does not flow;
When light and heavy are balanced, the scale does not tilt.
All things’ transformations arise from response.
When *yang* prevails, life emerges;
When *yin* prevails, death ensues.
Like water in the crossroads,
It tilts with each stimulus—
Attaining *zhonghe* (central harmony),
It remains balanced and upright.

Laozi said:
Mountains reach their height, and clouds and rain gather there;
Waters reach their depth, and dragons take form within.
The Sage cultivates the Way,
And virtue flows from it.
The Way’s height and depth
Naturally spread blessings.

Those with hidden virtue shall receive manifest reward,
Those with concealed deeds shall earn renowned name.
Hidden virtue lacks artifice—
This is the truest virtue.
Concealed deeds seek nothing—
This is the most genuine conduct.
When both true and real,
Even if rewards remain unseen and names unproclaimed,
They cannot be withheld.

He who plants millet reaps not barley,
He who sows resentment reaps none in return.
Plant millet, harvest millet;
Sow resentment, reap resentment.

*Completes the Sixth Scroll of the Treatise on Penetrating the Mysterious*
*Begins the Seventh Scroll of the Treatise on Penetrating the Mysterious*

Heaven and earth spread virtue and remove filth,
Great officials reform flaws and enact governance.
The people do not flee far,
Thus their coming and going is extreme:
They flee when wrongs are extreme,
They gather when benefits are greater.
All people love their native soil,
And do not wish to migrate—

chunks.original_text: 宋宣义郎试大理寺主薄兼 括州缙云县令朱弁正仪注 微明篇 道周象外谓之微，德隐宜中谓之明。 是知非微无以究真宗，非明无以契玄旨，微明之义，体用两然。 老子曰：道可以弱，可以强，可以柔，可以刚，可以阴，可以阳，可以幽，可以明，可以包裹天地，可以应待无方。 此与《道原篇》意同也。 知之浅，不知之深，知之外，不知之内，知之粗，不知之精，知之乃不知，不知乃知之，孰知知之为不知，不知之为知乎？ 夫道不可闻，闻而非也； 道不可见，见而非也； 道不可言，言而非也。 孰知形之不形者乎？ 故天下皆知善之为善也，斯不善矣。 知者不言，言者不知。 夫道绝形声，非闻见能辩； 德非藻饰，岂善恶能明？ 故知者不言，言者不知，其至已矣。 文子问曰：人可与微言乎？ 老子曰：何为不可。 唯知言之谓乎？ 夫知言之谓者，不可言言也。 微言，谓至妙言。 唯忘其言，可与言也。 争鱼者濡，逐兽者趋，非乐之也。 故至言去言，至为去为，浅知之人，所争者末矣。 夫言有宗事有君。 夫为无知，是以不吾知。 道者无名之妙，言者至理之宗，达妙者无言，明宗者不竞。 是言至而无言为至，而无为而知自知尔，执云吾知。 文子问曰； 为国亦有法乎？
chunks.translated_text:
The **Master of the Great Hall of Justice, Jù Biàn**, of the **Song Dynasty**, in his **Proper Conduct and the *Micro-Luminous* Chapter**:

*"Dao* beyond form is called *micro* (微),
*Virtue* concealed within propriety is called *luminous* (明).

Thus, without *micro* one cannot fathom the True Principle,
Without *luminous* one cannot grasp the Mysterious Intent.
The essence of *micro-luminous* lies in the duality of *body* and *function*.

Laozi said:
*The Way* can be weak, can be strong,
Can be yielding, can be firm,
Can be yin, can be yang,
Can be obscure, can be luminous,
Can enfold Heaven and Earth,
Can respond without measure.
This aligns with the intent of *The Origin of the Way* (《道原篇》).

Shallow knowing, deep not-knowing,
Knowing’s exterior, not-knowing’s interior,
Knowing’s coarse, not-knowing’s refined,
Knowing is not-knowing, not-knowing is knowing—
Who knows knowing as not-knowing,
Not-knowing as knowing?

*The Way* cannot be heard—heard, it is false;
*The Way* cannot be seen—seen, it is false;
*The Way* cannot be spoken—spoken, it is false.
Who knows the formless as form?

Thus, all under Heaven know goodness as goodness—
And so it becomes not-goodness.
The wise do not speak; the speaker does not know.

*The Way* transcends form and sound—
Hearing and seeing cannot discern it;
*Virtue* lacks embellishment—
Good and evil cannot illuminate it.

Thus, the wise do not speak; the speaker does not know—
This is the utmost attainment.

**Wénzǐ asked:** Can one be entrusted with *micro-speech*?
Laozi replied: *Why not?*
Do you mean *knowing how to speak*?
He who knows *how to speak* cannot speak *micro-speech*.
*Micro-speech* refers to the most exquisite speech.
Only when one forgets speech itself
Can one be entrusted with it.

The fisherman’s hands grow wet,
The hunter’s feet grow swift—
Not because they take pleasure in it.
Thus, the utmost speech transcends speech,
The utmost action transcends action.
The shallowly wise contend over trifles.

Speech has its *root* (宗),
Action has its *master* (君).
He who acts without knowing
Is why he is not known.

*The Way* is the ineffable marvel of the nameless,
Speech is the supreme principle of truth.
Those who grasp the marvel do not speak,
Those who illuminate the principle do not vie.
When speech reaches its utmost, it is without speech—
When action reaches its utmost, it is without action—
Yet self-awareness arises naturally.
One clings, saying, *"I know."*

**Wénzǐ asked:** Does governing a state also have its *law*?

chunks.original_text: 老子曰：今夫挽车者，前呼邪轷， 音乎。 后亦应之，此挽车劝力之歌也。 虽郑、卫、胡、楚之音，不若此之义也。 治国有礼，不在文辩。 法令滋彰，盗贼多有。 夫所用者有宜，各当其要，犹挽车劝力，不当奏以咸池之乐。 治国宁民，务崇朴素，何烦藻丽之说也？ 老子曰：道无正而可以为正，譬若山林而可以为材，材不及山林，山林不及云雨，云雨不及阴阳，阴阳不及和，和不及道。 道者所谓无状之状、无物之象也，无达其意，天地之间，可陶冶而变化也。 夫道无正，正出於道，犹山林非材，而材出於山林。 自云雨已下，言不及道者，以其无状无象，故能包罗万有，总括群方。 唯体道者，知变化无穷也。 老子曰：圣人立教施政，必察其终始，见其造恩。 造恩，谓制法立教也。 故民知书即德衰，知数而仁衰，知券契而信衰，知机械而实衰。 斯数者皆由大道而后兴，随时而立制。 制之逾谨，违之逾切，是知实信衰而机械设，机械设而奸滥甚矣。 瑟不鸣，而二十五弦各以其声应； 轴不运於己，而三十辐各以其力旋。 弦有缓急，然后能成曲； 车有劳佚，然后能致远。 使有声者乃无声，使有转者乃无转也。 瑟无声，声在於弦； 轴不转，转在於轮。 是无声而能有声，无转而能有转，故无声之声而曲即成，无转之转乃能致远也。 上下异道，易治即乱，位高而道大者从，事大而道小者凶。 冠不可践於足，臣不可尊於君。 上下乖乱，亡无日矣。 小德害义，小善害道，小辩害治，苛悄伤德。 矜小惠而蔽大道，纵小忿而伤至德。 大政不险，故民易导，至德优游，故下不贼。 至忠复素，故民无伪匿， 上有平正，下无险诐； 上有清简，下无巧伪。 老子曰：相坐之法立，即百姓怨，减爵之令张，即功臣叛。 狱讼相引，无辜者受其怨； 爵位减黜，有功者怀其叛。 故察於刀笔之迹者，不知治乱之本，习於行阵之事者，不知庙战之权。 治乱者，谓垂拱无为之化，非督责之吏所知。 庙战者，谓决胜之术在方寸之地，非一卒之能晓。 圣人见福於重关之内，虑患於冥冥之外。 重关之内，冥冥之外，谓出祸福之场，绝思虑之境，自非圣人，安能玄鉴也？ 愚者惑於小利，而忘大害，故事有利於小而害於大，得於此而忘於彼。 小见忘大，得利忘害，迷倒之甚，弄愚若何？ 故仁莫大於爱人，智莫大於知人，爱人即无怨刑，知人即无乱政。 爱人犹己，则刑不滥； 知人尽诚，即政无乱。 老子曰：江河之大，溢不过三日，飘风暴雨日中不出须臾上。 言人为暴，不久而亡，由飘风横厉，不日而止也。 德无所积而不忧者，亡其及也。 夫忧者所以昌也，喜者所以亡也，故善者以弱为强，转祸为福。 道冲而用之，又不满也。 愚者执迷而不返，以忧为喜，则速亡； 善者守道以全朴，转祸为福，则必昌。 老子曰：清静恬和，人之性也。 仪表规矩，事之制也。 知人之性，即自养不悖，知事之制，则其举措不乱。 恬和者，率性之本也。 规矩者，制欲之过也。 牵於欲利，虽静而常悖； 明其法度，虽动而不乱。 发一号，散无竞，总一管，谓之心。 见本而知末，执一而应万，谓之术。 发号，谓使心不竞。 使心不竞，即混百节而归根，应万物而冥一谓之术。 居知所为，行知所之，事知所乘，动知所止，谓之道。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master Laozi said:

Now, take the driver of a cart:
He calls *"Yā!"* and *"Chuò!"* from the front,
And the sound is answered.
The rear also responds in kind—
This is the driver’s song urging strength.
Though the music of Zheng, Wei, Hu, and Chu
May differ in tone,
None surpasses this in its purpose.

Governing a state relies on *rites* (礼),
Not on eloquence or argument.
When laws and decrees grow excessive,
Thieves and bandits multiply.
The proper use of things must fit their purpose,
Each must serve its role—
Like the driver’s song urging strength,
Yet it would be misplaced to play with the music of Xianchi.
Why trouble with ornate speech
When governing a state and calming the people
Requires only the elevation of simplicity and plainness?

The Master Laozi said:
*The Way* has no fixed form yet can be the standard,
Like mountains and forests that can yield materials—
Materials do not encompass mountains and forests,
Mountains and forests do not encompass clouds and rains,
Clouds and rains do not encompass yin and yang,
Yin and yang do not encompass harmony,
And harmony does not encompass *The Way*.
*The Way* is the formless form, the symbol without substance—
Without understanding its intent,
One cannot transform and refine between heaven and earth.
*The Way* has no fixed form,
Yet fixed forms arise from *The Way*,
Just as materials do not encompass mountains and forests,
Yet mountains and forests yield materials.
From clouds and rains downward,
Those who speak of what does not encompass *The Way*
Do so because it is formless and symbol-less,
Yet it embraces all things and encompasses all *Dao* (方).
Only those who embody *The Way*
Know its boundless transformations.

The Master Laozi said:
The Sage establishes teachings and implements governance,
Yet must observe their beginning and end,
And discern their underlying *virtue/power* (造恩).
*Constructing virtue/power* means creating laws and teachings.
Thus, when the people know writing, *virtue/power* declines,
When they know calculation, benevolence declines,
When they know bonds and contracts, trust declines,
When they know tools and devices, substance declines.
These four arise only after *The Way* has been lost,
And measures are established according to the times.
The stricter the measures become,
The more they are violated—
Thus, trust and sincerity decline,
And cunning and deceit flourish.

The zither does not sound,
Yet its twenty-five strings each respond with their own tone;
The axle does not turn by itself,
Yet its thirty spokes each exert their force in rotation.
Strings have slackness and tightness,
Only then can they produce melody;
Carts have labor and rest,
Only then can they reach distant places.
Those who make sound do so without sound,
Those who make turning do so without turning—
The zither has no sound,
Yet sound resides in the strings;
The axle does not turn,
Yet turning resides in the wheels.
Thus, there is sound without sound,
And turning without turning—
Only then can melody be produced,
Only then can distant places be reached.

High and low follow different *Dao* (道):
If *The Way* is great yet the position is low, it brings disaster;
If *The Way* is small yet the task is great, it brings ruin.
A cap cannot be worn on the feet,
A subject cannot be honored above his lord.
When high and low are disordered,
Ruination comes without delay.

Small *virtue/power* harms righteousness,
Small goodness harms *The Way*,
Small argument harms governance,
Excessive strictness harms *virtue/power*.
To cling to minor kindness while obscuring *The Way*,
To indulge minor anger while harming supreme *virtue/power*—
Great governance is not harsh,
Thus the people are easily guided;
Supreme *virtue/power* is effortless,
Thus the lower ranks do not rebel.
Utmost loyalty returns to simplicity,
Thus the people have no deceit or concealment;
Above, there is fairness and rectitude,
Below, there is no treachery or guile;
Above, there is clarity and frugality,
Below, there is no craftiness or falsehood.

The Master Laozi said:
When the *law* of seating is established,
The common people grow resentful;
When the decree of demoting ranks is put forth,
Meritorious officials rebel.
Lawsuits proliferate and drag others into blame,
The innocent suffer their grievances;
Ranks are diminished and meritorious officials harbor resentment,
Thus they plot rebellion.
Those who examine only the traces of lawsuits
Do not know the root of order and chaos;
Those who are skilled in military formations
Do not know the strategies of decisive victory.
Order and chaos are determined by the transformation of *The Way* through non-action,
Not by the knowledge of officials who supervise and reprimand.
Decisive victory is achieved through insight in the mind’s realm,
Not by the understanding of a single soldier.
The Sage perceives blessings within fortified gates,
And foresees calamities in the unseen depths.
Within fortified gates and in unseen depths—
The Sage alone can discern the profound.

The foolish are bewildered by minor gains,
Yet forget the greater harm—
Thus, some *Dao* bring small profit yet great ruin,
Gain here yet lose there.
To see the small and forget the great,
To gain profit yet forget harm—
How deeply deluded are they!
How can they be led astray?

Thus, benevolence finds no greater expression than loving others,
Wisdom finds no greater depth than knowing others.
To love others as oneself,
Is to prevent unjust punishment;
To know others with sincerity,
Is to ensure governance remains unerring.

Loving others is like loving oneself,
Then punishment will not be excessive;
Knowing others with sincerity,
Then governance will not be disordered.

The Master Laozi said:
The vastness of the rivers and seas,
Though they overflow, does not last beyond three days;
A sudden gust of wind and torrential rain
Do not persist beyond a moment.
This shows that violent rule is brief,
And ruin comes swiftly—
Just as the wind rages fiercely,
Yet ceases just as quickly.

Those whose *virtue/power* has no foundation
Yet fear no ruin—
It is because they have not yet reached it.
Worry is the means of flourishing,
Joy is the means of ruin—
Thus, the good turn misfortune into blessing,
And the wise transform calamity into fortune.
*The Way* is boundless yet can be employed,
Yet never becomes full.
The foolish cling to delusion and do not turn back,
Taking worry as joy,
And thus meet swift ruin;
The good uphold *The Way* and preserve simplicity,
Transforming calamity into fortune,
And thus flourish without fail.

The Master Laozi said:
Serene stillness and tranquil harmony
Are the nature of humankind.
Ceremonial forms and rules
Are the measures of *Dao*.
To know the nature of others,
Is to cultivate oneself without contradiction;
To know the measures of *Dao*,
Is to ensure one’s actions are not disordered.
Tranquil harmony is the foundation of natural disposition,
Rules are the excess of restraining desire.
Drawn by desire and profit,
Even stillness becomes contradiction;
Clarity in *Dao* and measure,
Even movement remains unerring.

Issue a single command,
And all respond without contention—
This is called *The Way*.
To grasp the root and know the branches,
To hold one principle yet respond to all things—
This is called *skill*.
To issue a command means to prevent the heart from contention;
To prevent the heart from contention
Is to harmonize all actions and return to their foundation,
To respond to all things yet remain unified in *The Way*—
This is called *skill*.

To dwell knowing what to do,
To act knowing where to go,
To handle affairs knowing what to rely on,
To move knowing when to stop—
This is called *The Way*.

chunks.original_text: 至人者，行藏有时，吉凶县料，若其不然，何以为道也？ 使人高贤称誉己者，心之力也； 使人卑下诽谤己者，心之过也。 言出於口，不可禁於人，行发於近，不可禁於远。 善恶由已，谤誉因人，众口所称，莫之能禁。 一行有亏，无远不至。 事者难成易败，名者难立易废，凡人皆轻小害，易微事，以至於大患。 夫祸之至也，人自生之，福之来也，人自成之，祸与福同门，利与害同邻，自非至精，莫之能分，是故智虑者祸福之门户也，动静者利害之枢机也，不可不慎察也。 夫至人所为必谋，始克料於终。 且名利之所起即祸福之生门，故杜名利之原，闭祸福之门，即智虑自通，而动静无变也。 老子曰：人皆知治乱之机，而莫知全生之具，故圣人论世而为之事，权事而为之谋。 圣人能阴能阳，能柔能刚，能弱能强，随时动静，因资而立功，睹物往而知其反，事一而察其变，化即为之象，运则为之应，是以终身行之无所困。 人皆能机於治乱之道，而不能全身於治乱之间，故圣人论世权事，应变无穷，相时而为，终身不辱也。 故事或可言而不可行者，或可行而不可言者，或难成而易败者。 所谓可行而不可言者，取舍也； 可言而不可行者，伪诈也； 易为而难成者，事也； 难成而易败者，名也。 此四者，圣人之所留心也，明者之所独见也。 审行藏之势，察成败之由，其唯圣明方能独见也。 老子曰：道者敬小微，动不失时，百射重戒，祸乃不滋。 计福勿及，虑祸过之。 同日被霜，蔽者不伤，愚者有备，兴智者同功。 贤者无虑为愚，愚者有备为贤。 夫积爱成福，积憎成祸，人皆知救患，莫知使患无生。 夫使患无生易，施於救患难。 今人不务使患无生，而施救患难，虽神人不能为谋。 患祸之所由来，万万无方。 圣人探居以避患，静默以待时； 小人不知祸福之门，动而陷於刑，虽曲为之备，不足以全身。 故上士先避患而后就利，先远辱而后求名。 故圣人常从事於无形之外，而不留心於已成之内，是以祸患无由至，非誉不能尘垢。 夫陷於利害由爱憎。 爱憎不生，毁誉安在？ 君子见未形则易治，小人曲备而终祸。 救於已形，成则难脱也。 老子曰凡人之道心欲小，志欲大，智欲圆，行欲方，能欲多，事欲少。 所谓心小者，虑患於未生，戒祸慎微，不敢纵其欲也。 志大者，兼包万国，一齐殊俗，是非辐辏，中为之毂也。 知圆者，终始无端，方音旁流四远，渊泉而不竭也。 行方者，直立而不挠，素白而不污，穷不易操，达不肆志也。 能多者，文武备具，动静中仪，举动废置，曲得其宜也。 事少者，秉要以偶众，执约以治广，处静以持躁也。 故心小者禁於微也，志大者无不怀也，智圆者无不知也，行方者有不为也，能多者无不治也，事少者约所持也。 凡此数者，非夫至圣高真，莫能兼也。 故圣人之於善也，无小而不行，其於过也，无微而不改，行不用巫觋，而鬼神不敢先，可谓至贵矣。 然而战战栗栗，日慎一日，是以无为而有成也。 外不负物，内不惭心。 何须巫觋？ 宁惧鬼神？ 由怀兢伤然可保终也。 愚人之智，固已少，而所为之事多，故动必穷，故以正教化，易而必成； 以邪教化，其势难而必败。 舍其易而必成，从事於难而必败，愚惑之所致。
chunks.translated_text:
The Perfect Person acts and withdraws in due measure,
Knows when to embrace fortune and when to face misfortune—
If otherwise, how could they be said to follow *The Way*?

To make others praise and honor me as a lofty sage,
Is the strength of my heart;
To make others revile and slander me as lowly and base,
Is the fault of my heart.

Words issue from the mouth,
Yet cannot be restrained by others;
Actions arise from the near,
Yet cannot be restrained from afar.

Good and evil originate with oneself,
Praise and blame come from others—
What all mouths proclaim,
No one can suppress.

One flaw in conduct,
And its consequences reach far;
Matters are hard to complete yet easy to ruin,
Reputation is hard to establish yet easy to lose.
Ordinary folk all slight minor dangers,
Neglect small matters,
And thus invite great calamities.

For when disaster arrives,
It is self-generated;
When fortune comes,
It is self-created.
Disaster and fortune share the same threshold,
Benefit and harm dwell as neighbors—
Without the utmost discernment,
None can separate them.
Thus, deliberate consideration is the gateway to disaster and fortune,
Action and stillness are the pivot of benefit and harm—
They must not be overlooked.

The Perfect Person’s every action is deliberate,
And they measure the end from the beginning.

For where name and profit arise,
There too disaster and fortune take root.
Thus, to block the source of name and profit,
And seal the gate of disaster and fortune,
Is to let wisdom naturally unfold,
And to act and remain still without change.

Laozi said:
All know the mechanisms of order and chaos,
Yet none know how to preserve life whole.
Therefore, the sage assesses the world and acts accordingly,
Weighs affairs and plans accordingly.

The sage can be subtle and manifest,
Soft and firm,
Weak and strong—
They adapt to the times, moving or still,
And establish merit according to their resources.
They perceive things in their course
And know their reversals;
They embody *The Way* as their form,
And respond to its transformations.
Thus, they act throughout their life
Without ever being constrained.

All can grasp the principles of order and chaos,
Yet none can preserve themselves within their shifting currents.
Therefore, the sage assesses the world and weighs affairs,
Responds to endless changes,
Acts in accordance with the times,
And never suffers disgrace.

Thus, some matters may be spoken of yet cannot be done,
Some may be done yet cannot be spoken of,
Some are hard to complete yet easy to ruin.

What is done yet cannot be spoken of—
Taking and discarding.
What is spoken of yet cannot be done—
Deceit and trickery.
What is easy yet hard to complete—
Affairs.
What is hard to complete yet easy to ruin—
Reputation.
These four matters,
The sage attends to with care,
And the enlightened alone can truly perceive.

To examine the shifts of action and withdrawal,
And discern the causes of success and failure—
Only the sage and the wise can truly see.

Laozi said:
*The Way* of the common person is—
Their heart desires smallness,
Their ambition desires greatness,
Their wisdom desires completeness,
Their conduct desires rectitude,
Their capacity desires abundance,
Their undertakings desire fewness.

By "heart small" is meant—
To guard against disaster before it arises,
To be cautious of ruin in its minutiae,
And not to dare indulge their desires.

By "ambition great" is meant—
To encompass all under heaven,
To unify diverse customs,
And to gather the myriad judgments
As the hub of a wheel.

By "wisdom complete" is meant—
To know the end and the beginning without limit,
To let sound flow in all directions,
And to be like a deep spring never exhausted.

By "conduct rect" is meant—
To stand straight yet never bend,
To remain pure yet never stain,
To endure hardship without altering their principles,
And to achieve success without arrogance.

By "capacity abundant" is meant—
To possess both literary and martial arts,
To balance movement and stillness with propriety,
And to adapt every action to its fitting measure.

By "undertakings few" is meant—
To grasp the essential and align with the multitude,
To hold fast to the strict and govern the broad,
To maintain stillness amidst chaos.

Thus, the small-hearted are restrained by the minute,
The great-ambitioned embrace all without exception,
The wise-knowing lack no understanding,
The rect-conducted have nothing they refuse,
The abundant-capacityed govern all without flaw,
The few-undertakings hold what is essential.

All these qualities,
None but the most exalted sage and true adept can fully embody.

Thus, the sage’s approach to goodness—
No minor matter goes undone,
And to their faults—
No subtle error remains uncorrected.
They act without relying on shamans and sorcerers,
Yet ghosts and spirits dare not act before them—
This is the height of nobility.

Yet they tremble and guard themselves,
Each day more cautious than the last,
And thus achieve without doing.

Externally, they do not fail others,
Internally, they do not shame themselves—
Why need they summon shamans and sorcerers?
Why fear ghosts and spirits?
From their reverent and wounded heart,
They can be preserved to the end.

The fool’s wisdom is already meager,
Yet their undertakings are many—
Thus their actions must falter.
If they employ upright teachings,
It is easy and must succeed;
If they employ perverse teachings,
It is difficult and must fail.

To abandon what is easy yet certain to succeed,
And to pursue what is difficult yet certain to fail—
This is the path of folly and confusion.

chunks.original_text: 不量得失，坐致危亡。 事繁难治，虽劳将败。 物简易从，必成而不为者，愚之至也。 老子曰：福之起也绵绵，祸之生也纷纷，祸福之数，微而不可见。 圣人见其始终，故不可不察。 福如鸿毛，圣人独见； 祸若太山，愚者莫睹。 明主之赏罚，非以为己，以为国。 适於己而无功於国者，不施赏焉； 逆於己而便於国者，不加罚焉。 明主赏罚在於公正。 益於国，便於人，则行； 利於己； 不利於人，则止也。 故义载乎宜，谓之君子，遗义之宜，谓之小人。 君子小人，岂有定分？ 举措合宜，即为君子； 动用乖分，即为小人。 通智得而不劳， 上士县解。 其次劳而不病， 中人勉力不倦。 其下病而不劳。 下士心眼昏滞，精神迷倒，故劳逾甚，病逾笃也。 古之人，味而不舍也，今之人，舍而不味也。 不舍，不居也。 味，道味也。 古人味道而不居，今人无道而自伐也。 纣为象着， 箸以象牙为之。 而箕子喜， 喜其华侈。
chunks.translated_text:
Without measuring gain and loss,
One sits and invites peril and ruin.

When undertakings are manifold and difficult to govern,
Even toil will lead to defeat.

When things are simple and easily followed,
Yet one does not act—
This is the ultimate folly.

Laozi said:
*"Fortune arises softly and subtly,
While calamity erupts in tumultuous waves.
The patterns of fortune and misfortune
Are faint and unseen by the common eye.*

*The Sage perceives their beginning and end,
Thus one must not fail to observe them.*

*Fortune is as light as a feather—
Only the Sage discerns it;
Calamity looms like a great mountain—
The fool sees nothing of it.*

*The enlightened ruler’s rewards and punishments
Are not for himself alone,
But for the realm.
What benefits oneself yet serves no function for the state
Shall not be rewarded;
What harms oneself yet aids the state
Shall not be punished.
Thus the enlightened ruler’s rewards and punishments
Rest upon impartial justice.*

*What benefits the state and aids the people—
Then it is done;
What profits oneself yet harms the people—
Then it is halted.*

*Therefore, righteousness lies in what is fitting—
This is called the gentleman.
To abandon what is fitting—
This is called the petty man.*

*Is there a fixed distinction between gentleman and petty man?
When actions and measures align with propriety—
Then one is a gentleman;
When conduct and use stray from due measure—
Then one is a petty man.*

*Those of supreme wisdom act without effort—
The highest sage attains effortless mastery.
The next toil without exhaustion—
The middle person strives without weariness.
The lowest labor without gain—
The vulgar, their minds dull and spirit bewildered,
Thus their toil grows ever heavier,
Their affliction ever deeper.*

*The ancients savored the Dao without clinging,
The moderns abandon it without tasting.
Not to cling—this is not dwelling.
To savor—this is savoring the Way.*

*The ancients savored the Dao without clinging,
The moderns, lacking the Way, yet boast of themselves.*

*Zhou’s tyrant made a ceremonial cap adorned with elephants,
And used ivory chopsticks—
Yet Ji Zi rejoiced,
For he delighted in its extravagant splendor."*

chunks.original_text: 鲁以偶人葬， 偶人，刻木似人，为盟器之类也。 而孔子叹。 叹其非礼。 见其所始，即知其所终。 小人见象着、偶人，以为其生也荣，其死也盛； 君子观之，其道也衰，其德也亡。 老子曰：仁者，人之所慕也； 义者，人之所高也。 为人所慕，为人所高，或身死国亡者，不周於时也。 故知义而不知世权者，不达於道也。 徒高七义之风，不识机权之变，无救败亡，岂为周达者也？ 五帝贵德， 无为而治。 三王用义， 诛暴宁民。 五伯任力， 任知力也。 今取帝王之道施五伯之世，非其道也。 故善不同，非誉在俗，趋行等，逆顺在左右。 言时代既异，治化不同。 当五伯之时，行太古之道，犹胶柱调瑟，疗渴以鸩，实亦难矣。 知天之所为，知人之所行，即有以经於世矣。 经治常也。 知天而不知人，即无以与俗交，知人而不知天，无以与道游。 知天和人，知俗知时，可以治世，可与道游也。 直志适情，即坚强者贼之，以身役物，即阴阳食之。 适我志即乖彼心，必为强坚者所忤。 徇於物即劳其体，犹冰炭之相攻。 阴阳谓躁静也。 得道之人，外化而内不化，外化所以知人也，内不化所以全身也，故内有一定之操，而外能屈伸，与物推移，万举而不陷，所贵乎道者，贵其龙变也。 得道之人，其动也天，其静也地。 动静适时，卷舒在我。 故俗莫得而害，世莫得而羁。 故尼父见老君，其犹龙乎？ 变化无方也。 守一节，推一行，虽以成满，犹不易，拘於小好，而塞於大道。 既滞一方，宁论大道。 道者寂寞以虚无，非有为而於物也，不以有为於己也。 物我之间，居然已泯； 寂寞之际，自然而神。 是故举事而顺道者，非道者之所为，道之所施也。 道本无为，今云顺道，即是有为。 有为即事起，事起即患生。 且道无常容，事无常顺，为事逆之，则是非纷然，祸息斯作，故云非道者所为也。 施者，设也。 言外设程科，是道仪表，非其真实，不可执之。 执者失之，为者败之。 理可明也。
chunks.translated_text:
「The state of Lu buried its dead with *ou-ren*—
*Ou-ren*, carved wooden figures resembling humans, were used as ritual vessels of the covenant.
Yet Confucius sighed—
He lamented their lack of propriety.
Observing their origin,
One could discern their end.
The petty man, seeing the ceremonial cap adorned with elephants and the *ou-ren*,
Believed that in life they were honored,
And in death they were grandly treated;
The noble man, gazing upon them,
Knew that their Dao was in decline,
Their virtue/power extinguished.

Laozi said:
*"Ren"* is what people admire,
*"Yi"* is what people esteem.
To be admired by people,
To be esteemed by people,
Yet sometimes meet with death and the fall of one’s state,
Is because one does not conform to the times.
Thus, knowing *yi* yet not knowing the world’s power,
One does not grasp the Dao.
Merely extolling the seven virtues of *yi*,
Without recognizing the shifts of power and strategy,
Cannot avert ruin and downfall—
How could one be truly versed in the Way?

The Five Emperors valued virtue/power,
And ruled by non-action.
The Three Kings upheld *yi*,
And exterminated tyranny to bring peace to the people.
The Five Hegemons relied on strength,
Meaning they depended on the knowledge and force of arms.
Now, applying the methods of the Five Emperors to the age of the Five Hegemons,
Is not the proper Dao.
Thus, the wise vary their actions,
Not because praise is in fashion,
But because their conduct aligns with the times—
Success or failure depends on the left or right.

The times differ, so governance must change.
In the age of the Five Hegemons,
To practice the Dao of the Five Emperors,
Is like binding a pillar to a lute or treating thirst with hemlock—
Truly difficult indeed.

To know Heaven’s will,
To understand humanity’s ways,
Is to possess the means to navigate the world.
Navigating the world is the constant way.
To know Heaven yet not humanity,
Is to lack the means to engage with the common.
To know humanity yet not Heaven,
Is to lack the means to play with the Dao.

Knowing Heaven and humanity,
Knowing the common and the times,
One can govern the world,
And play with the Dao.

To follow one’s true intent and suit one’s nature,
The rigid and strong will oppose you,
And to serve others with one’s body,
The *yin-yang* forces will consume you.
To suit your own intent,
Is to go against their desires—
You must be opposed by the rigid and strong.
To yield to others,
Is to exhaust your body—
Like ice and fire attacking each other.
*Yin-yang* refers to agitation and calmness.

Those who attain the Dao,
Transform outwardly yet remain unaltered within.
Their outward transformation reveals humanity,
Their inner steadfastness preserves the self.
Thus, within they maintain a fixed principle,
While outwardly they bend and stretch,
Adjusting with the world—
Acting in all things without falling into error.
What is prized in the Dao,
Is its *longbian*—
Its boundless adaptability.

Those who attain the Dao,
In motion, they are Heaven itself;
In stillness, they are Earth.
Their motion and stillness suit the times—
Their withdrawal and engagement lie within themselves.
Thus, the common cannot harm them,
And the world cannot ensnare them.
Hence, when Confucius saw the Sage Lao,
Was he not like a dragon?
For his transformations knew no limits.
To uphold one principle,
To extend one method,
Even if success is achieved,
It remains unyielding—
Clinging to petty gains,
Yet obstructing the great Dao.
Once ensnared by one path,
How could one speak of the great Dao?

The Dao is serene and tranquil in its emptiness,
Not bound by action or affected by things.
It does not act upon things for its own sake—
Between self and things, the distinction is naturally dissolved;
In the stillness and serenity, one’s nature is spontaneously divine.

Thus, to undertake actions in accordance with the Dao,
Is not the doing of one who has attained the Dao—
It is the Dao’s own unfolding.
The Dao is fundamentally non-action,
Yet now it speaks of "accordance with the Dao"—
This is action itself.
Action brings about affairs,
Affairs bring about calamities.
Moreover, the Dao has no fixed appearance,
And affairs have no fixed order—
To act against the Dao’s flow,
Is to invite confusion and discord—
Then misfortune will surely arise.
Hence, it is said that this is not the doing of one who has attained the Dao.

*Shi* means to set up—
To establish external rules and measures,
Is the Dao’s ceremonial form,
Not its true substance—
One cannot cling to it.
To cling is to lose it,
To act upon it is to fail.
The principle can be made clear.

Their affliction ever deeper.*

*The ancients savored the Dao without clinging,
The moderns abandon it without tasting.
Not to cling—this is not dwelling.
To savor—this is savoring the Way.*

*The ancients savored the Dao without clinging,
The moderns, lacking the Way, yet boast of themselves.*

*Zhou’s tyrant made a ceremonial cap adorned with elephants,
And used ivory chopsticks—
Yet Ji Zi rejoiced,
For he delighted in its extravagant splendor."*
