chunks.original_text: 天地之所覆载，日月之所照明，阴阳之所煦，雨露之所润，道德之所扶，皆说一和也。 是故能戴大圆者履大方， 谓人戴天履地。 镜太清者视大明， 谓睹日见月也。 立太平者处大堂， 谓在宇宙之间。 能游於冥冥者，与日月同光，无形而生於有形，是故真人托期於灵台，而归初。 反未生也。 视於冥冥，听於无声，冥冥之中，独有晓焉，寂寞之中，独有照焉。 言真人在天地之间，睹日月之光，游乎太平，则何往不适？ 居乎大堂，而无不容於冥冥之中，晓乎无声，而众声应寂寞之内； 照乎无形，而群形见。 则与天地相保，日月同明，寄托灵台，含藏至精，谓之真人也。 其用之乃不用，不用而后能用之也； 其知也乃不知，不知而后知也。 前已释。 道者物之所道也，德者生之所扶也，仁者积恩之证也，义者比於心而合於众适者也。 四者，所用以处世修身，不可失也。 道灭而德兴，德衰而仁义生。 故上世道而不德，中世守德而不怀，下世绳绳而恐失仁义，故君子非义无以生，失义即失其所以生； 小人非利无以活，失利则失其所以活。 故君子惧失义，小人惧失利，观其所惧，祸福异矣。 道丧德衰，七绝义薄。 君子无义，无以全其道，小人无利，无以活其身。 君子惧失义以为祸，小人欲利以为福也。 老子曰； 或欲利之，适足以害之，或欲害之，乃足以利之。 夫病湿而强餐之热，病渴而强饮之寒，此众人之所养也，而良医所以为病也。 快於目，悦於心，愚者之所利，有道者之所避。 圣人者，先在而后合，众人先合而后在，故祸福之门，利害之反，不可不察也。 夫病渴饮之以水，良医以为祸。 贫者取财於不义，君子以为害。 先迕而后合，愚者之所犯； 先合而后迕圣人之所恶。 夫利害相反，祸福相倾，不可不察也。 老子曰：有功离仁义者即见疑，有罪有仁义者必见信。 故仁义者，事之常顺也，天下之尊爵也。 言虽功名已立，而七义不可舍也。 舍之则罪累斯及，顺之则爵禄可尊。 虽谋得计当，虑患解图，国存，其事有离仁义者，其功必不遂也； 言虽无中於策，其计无益於国，而心周於君，合於仁义者，身必存。 故曰：百言百计常不当者，不若舍趋而审仁义也。 为人臣，图国之难、骄主尊己、而功不成者，去仁义故也。 或有良谋不用，奇计不行，戴君尽力，虽不见察，终保仁义，不敢暂忘，而身亦无害也。 老子曰：教本乎君子，小人被其泽，利本乎小人，君子享其功。 使君子小人各得其宜，即通功易食而道达矣。 德泽被乎下，禄利奉於上，则无官而自治，不令而自行，各安其所，道之达也。 人多欲即伤义，多忧即害智， 欲生义夺，忧积智昏。 故治国乐所以存， 守其道也， 虐国乐所以亡。 纵其欲也。 水下流而广大，君下臣而聪明，君不与臣争而治道通，故君根本也，臣枝叶也，根本不美而枝叶茂者，未之有也。 圣人之治者，明四目，达四聪，屏邪慝，任贤能，则上垂拱无为自化，则下尽心而奉职。 岂有交争之理？ 即根本日固，枝叶繁盛也。 老子曰：慈父之爱子者，非求其报，不可内解於心。 圣主之养民，非为己用也，性不能已也，及恃其力，赖其功动，而必穷有以为，即恩不接矣。 父之爱子，君之牧民，岂求所报？
chunks.translated_text:
The heavens and earth cover and load all things,
The sun and moon illuminate and clarify them,
The yin and yang nurture them,
The rain and dew nourish them,
The **Dao** and **virtue** sustain and uphold them—
All are spoken of as **one harmony**.

Hence, he who can bear the Great Circle walks the Great Square—
That is, the person who bears the heavens and walks the earth.
He who gazes upon the Great Clarity beholds the Great Brightness—
That is, the person who sees the sun and moon.
He who establishes the Great Peace dwells in the Great Hall—
That is, the person who abides in the cosmos between.

He who can wander in the **succinct** and **profound** (*suoyin*),
Shares light with the sun and moon,
Gives rise without form to what is formed—
Thus, the **True Person** entrusts himself to the **Spiritual Platform** (*lingtai*), and returns to the origin.
He reverses what has not yet been born.

To gaze upon the **succinct** and **profound** (*suoyin*),
To listen in the **silent** and **void** (*wusheng*),
Within the **succinct** and **profound** (*suoyin*),
Alone there is **awareness** (*xiao*),
Within the **silent** and **void** (*wusheng*),
Alone there is **illumination** (*zhao*).

It is said that the **True Person** amid the heavens and earth,
Beholding the sun and moon’s light,
Wandering in the Great Peace—
Then where does he not find **suitability** (*shi*)?
Dwelling in the Great Hall,
Yet nothing is excluded from the **succinct** and **profound** (*suoyin*) within;
**Awareness** (*xiao*) in the **silent** and **void** (*wusheng*),
And all sounds respond within the **silent** and **void** (*wusheng*);
**Illumination** (*zhao*) in the **formless** (*wuxing*),
Yet all forms appear—
Then he preserves with the heavens and earth,
Shares brightness with the sun and moon,
Deposits himself in the **Spiritual Platform** (*lingtai*),
Encompasses the **ultimate essence** (*zhi jing*),
And is called the **True Person**.

His **use** is to **not use**,
To **not use** is to **then be able to use**;
His **knowing** is to **not know**,
To **not know** is to **then be able to know**—
This has already been expounded.

The **Dao** is the **Way** by which things are guided,
**Virtue** (*de*) is the support by which life is sustained,
**Ren** (*benevolence*) is the **manifestation** of accumulated **en** (*favor/grace*),
**Yi** (*righteousness*) is the **harmonization** of personal **heart** with the **suitable** for all—
These four are the **principles** by which one governs the world and cultivates oneself,
And they must not be lost.

When the **Dao** is extinguished, **virtue** (*de*) flourishes;
When **virtue** (*de*) declines, **ren** and **yi** arise.
Thus, in the **upper ages**, the **Dao** was followed without **virtue** (*de*),
In the **middle ages**, **virtue** (*de*) was upheld without **ren** and **yi**,
In the **lower ages**, **ren** and **yi** were enforced with fear of losing them—
Hence, the **Noble Person** cannot live without **yi** (*righteousness*), for to lose **yi** is to lose the means of living;
The **petty person** cannot survive without **li** (*profit*), for to lose **li** is to lose the means of survival.

The **Noble Person** fears losing **yi** as a **calamity**,
The **petty person** desires **li** as **blessing**—
Observing their fears,
The paths to **calamity** and **blessing** diverge.

When the **Dao** is lost and **virtue** (*de*) declines,
The seven **virtues** (*qi yi*) are slighted and **righteousness** (*yi*) grows thin.
The **Noble Person** without **yi** has no way to preserve his **Dao**,
The **petty person** without **li** has no way to sustain his life.
The **Noble Person** fears losing **yi** as a **calamity**,
The **petty person** seeks **li** as **blessing**.

The **Laozi** said:
Some desire **profit** (*li*) and thereby harm **righteousness** (*yi*),
Some desire to harm **righteousness** (*yi*) and thereby bring **profit** (*li*).
To feed a **disease** of dampness with **heat**,
To quench a **disease** of thirst with **coldness**—
This is how the multitude **nourishes** (*yang*) their **ailments** (*bing*),
Yet the **skilled physician** (*liangyi*) knows this as **causing harm**.

Pleasure to the eyes,
Delight to the heart—
What the **foolish** (*yu*) find **profitable** (*li*),
The **Daoist** (*youdao*) avoids.
The **Sage** governs by **first establishing** and **then harmonizing**,
The multitude by **first harmonizing** and **then establishing**—
Thus, the gates of **calamity** and **blessing**,
The **reversal** of **profit** and **harm**,
Cannot be overlooked.

To quench a **disease** of thirst with **water**,
The **skilled physician** (*liangyi*) knows this as **calamity**.
The **poor** take **wealth** from **unrighteousness** (*buyi*),
The **Noble Person** knows this as **harm**.
**First opposing** and **then harmonizing**—
This is the **error** the **foolish** (*yu*) commit;
**First harmonizing** and **then opposing**—
This is what the **Sage** abhors.

**Profit** and **harm** are contrary,
**Calamity** and **blessing** are inverted—
One must not fail to discern them.

The **Laozi** said:
Those with **achievements** (*gong*) who abandon **ren** and **yi** will be **suspected**,
Those with **guilt** (*zui*) who uphold **ren** and **yi** will be **trusted**.
Hence, **ren** and **yi** are the **constant harmony** of affairs,
And the **most honored** (*zun*) **rank** in the world—
Though **achievements** (*gong*) and **names** (*ming*) are already established,
The seven **virtues** (*qi yi*) must not be forsaken.
To forsake them invites **guilt** to accumulate,
To follow them ensures **rank** and **reward** are honored.

Though one’s **plans** (*mou*) are **correct** and **strategies** (*ji*) are **apt**,
And **worries** (*lü*) are **dispelled** by **schemes** (*tuo*),
If the state is preserved,
Yet one’s affairs **depart** from **ren** and **yi**,
Then one’s **achievements** (*gong*) will surely **not be fulfilled**.

Though one’s **calculations** (*ji*) are **not flawed**,
Yet one’s **strategies** (*ji*) are **no benefit** to the state,
If one’s **heart** is **complete** toward the **lord** (*jun*),
And **harmonizes** with **ren** and **yi**,
Then one’s **life** will surely be **preserved**.

Hence it is said:
A hundred **words** and a hundred **calculations** that are **never apt** (*bu ru bangqi*),
Are not as good as **abandoning** (*she*) them and **tending** (*qu*) to **ren** and **yi**.

As a **minister** to the **lord** (*jun*),
One who **plans** for the state’s **difficulties** (*nan*),
**Exalts** the **lord** and **honors** himself,
Yet **achievements** (*gong*) are **not completed**—
This is due to **abandoning** **ren** and **yi**.

Some have **wise counsel** (*liangmou*) yet it is **not used**,
**Unusual strategies** (*qiji*) yet they **do not proceed**,
They **serve** the **lord** with all their **strength** (*jin*),
Though **not observed** (*bujiancha*),
They **preserve** **ren** and **yi** without **daring** to **forget** them even for a moment,
And thus their **lives** are **without harm**.

The **Laozi** said:
**Teaching** originates with the **Noble Person**,
The **petty person** benefits from its **radiance** (*ze*).
**Profit** originates with the **petty person**,
The **Noble Person** **enjoys** its **achievements** (*gong*).
If the **Noble Person** and **petty person** each **obtain** their **proper place** (*yi*),
Then **achievements** and **rewards** are **shared** (*tonggong yishi*), and the **Dao** is **realized**.

**Virtue’s** (*de*) **radiance** (*ze*) extends downward,
**Rewards** and **profits** are **bestowed** upward—
Then there are **no officials** yet **governance** is **self-regulating**,
No **commands** yet **actions** are **self-executing**,
Each **dwells** in **their proper place** (*an qi suo*),
And this is the **realization** of the **Dao**.

**Desire** in excess **injures** **righteousness** (*yi*),
**Worry** in excess **harms** **wisdom** (*zhi*),
**Desire** gives rise to **righteousness** being **seized** (*yi duo*),
**Worry** accumulates **wisdom** being **obscured** (*zhi hun*).
Hence, a state **delighted** in **profit** (*li*) will **surely** be **preserved**,
A state **delighted** in **harm** (*shang*) will **surely** be **destroyed**—
**Indulging** its **desires** (*zong qi yu*).

Water flows downward and **becomes vast** (*guangda*),
The **lord** (*jun*) **subordinates** himself to the **minister** (*chen*) and **becomes wise** (*congming*),
The **lord** does not **contend** with the **minister**,
And thus the **Way** of **governance** (*treat*) is **unimpeded**—
Hence, the **lord** is the **root and foundation** (*genben*),
The **minister** is the **branches and leaves** (*zhi ye*),
And if the **root and foundation** are **not beautiful** yet the **branches and leaves** flourish—
This has never occurred.

The **Sage’s** (*shengren*) **governance** (*zhi*) is:
To **illuminate** the **four eyes** (*ming si mu*),
To **penetrate** the **four ears** (*da si cong*),
To **exclude** the **wicked** and **depraved** (*ping yie te*),
To **employ** the **virtuous** and **capable** (*ren sheneng*),
Then the **lord** above **hangs** (*chui*) and **does nothing** (*wuwei*) while **transformation** (*hua*) occurs naturally—
And the **ministers** below **exert** their **hearts** (*xin*) fully while **dutifully** (*fengzhi*) **serving**.

How could there be **mutual contention** (*jiaozheng*)?
This is the **root and foundation** **ever-firm** (*ri gu*),
And the **branches and leaves** **prolific** (*fansheng*).

The **Laozi** said:
The **loving father’s** (*ci fu*) **care** for his **son** (*zi*) is,
Not seeking **recompense** (*bao*),
Yet **cannot** be **internally resolved** (*nei jie*) in the **heart**.
The **Sage lord’s** (*sheng zhu*) **nourishment** (*yang*) of the **people** (*min*) is,
Not for **selfish use** (*ji yong*),
Yet **nature** (*xing*) **cannot** be **restrained** (*bu neng yi*).
When one **relies** on their **strength** (*li*),
And **depends** on their **achievements** (*gong*),
Yet **must** **exhaust** (*qiong*) **all** for **reward** (*wei*),
Then **favor** (*en*) **does not reach** (*bu jie*).
The **father’s** **care** for his **son**,
The **lord’s** **shepherding** of the **people**—
How could they **seek** **recompense**?

And affairs have no fixed order—
To act against the Dao’s flow,

chunks.original_text: 自然之分，天道也。 或有君父恃其功力，骄其臣子者，恩惠不接也。 故用众人之所爱，即得众人之力，举众人之所喜，即得众人之心。 故见其所始，即知其所终。 兼爱天下，天下虽大，俱为一家之人； 不爱天下，则匹夫虽微，犹万方之敌。 以此而观，则终始可知，存亡可察也。 老子曰：人以义爱，党以群强，是故德之所施者博，即威之所行者远，义之所加者薄，即武之所制者小。 此谓德泽无私，所附者众，弃义用武，即所存者寡也。 老子曰：以不义而得之，又不布施，患及其身，不能为人，又无以自为，可谓愚人，无以异於枭爱其子。 取之不义，积而不散，所谓养虎自敌，育枭自毙之也。 故持而备之，不如其已，揣而锐之，不可长保。 然局固箱筐，终为大盗之资，安得长有也？ 德之中有道，道之中有德，其化不可极。 有道者必有德。 有德者必有道。 道德充备，与变化无极也。 阳中有阴，阴中有阳，万事尽然，不可胜明，福至祥存，祸至祥先，见祥而为不善，即福不来，见不祥而行善，即祸不至。 利与害同门，祸与福同邻，非神圣莫之能分。 故曰：祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏，孰知其极。 阳中有阴，阴中有阳，言祸中有福，福中有祸。 夫见福而为祥，则知福为祸始； 见祸而遽为善，则知祸为福先。 祸福之来，有如纠缠，自非至圣，莫知其极也。 人之将疾也，必先甘鱼肉之味； 国之将亡也，必先恶忠臣之语。 人病者，甘其口，美其味，必死之征。 国乱者，恶忠言，信邪说，必亡之兆。 故疾之将死者，不可为良医，国之将亡者，不可为忠谋。 人将死者，医虽良而莫救； 国将亡者，忠虽尽而难存。 唯良医忠臣，审必死而不救，察可存而为谋也。 修之身，然后可以治民； 居家理治，然后可移宫长。 故曰：修之身，其德乃真； 修之家，其德乃有余； 修之国，其德乃丰。 以身观彼，自家刑国，其要修身，在於全德。 民之所以生活，衣与食也，事周於衣食则有功，不周於衣食则无功，事无功，德不长。 衣食者，庶民之命； 庶民者，君臣之本。 衣食既周於身，君臣长保於国也。 故随时而不成，无更其刑，顺时而不成，无更而理，时将复起，是谓道纪。 时有兴废，运有休否。 不可以前时之繁政为今世之要理，言刑不可废，理不可易，能知於此，道之纪纲也。 帝王富其民， 敦其本也。
chunks.translated_text:
The **partition of nature** is the **Dao/Way** of **Heaven** (*Tian Dao*).

Should any **lord or father** **rely** on their **strength** (*li*) and **achievements** (*gong*), and **grow arrogant** toward their **subjects or children** (*ci fu*), then **favor** (*en*) **does not reach** (*bu jie*).

Thus, **employing** what the **common people** (*zhong ren*) **love**,
One **gains** the **common people’s** **strength** (*li*),
**Elevating** what the **common people** **delight** in (*ju*),
One **gains** the **common people’s** **heart** (*xin*).
Thus, **seeing** their **beginning** (*shu*),
One **knows** their **end** (*zhong*).
**Compassionately loving** all **under Heaven** (*tian xia*), though **Heaven** be vast (*qian wei*),
All become **members of one family** (*ju wei yi jia*);
**Not loving** all **under Heaven**,
Even the **lowliest individual** (*pi fu*), though **mighty insignificant** (*qian wei*),
Yet **remains** an **enemy** to all **lands** (*wan fang*).
By this **perspective** (*guan*),
Then **end and beginning** may be **known** (*zhi zhong shi ke zhi*),
And **life and death** may be **discerned** (*cun wang ke cha*).

The **Laozi** said:
When **people** **love** with **righteousness** (*yi*),
**Factions** **strengthen** through **group bonds** (*dang yi qun qiang*),
Thus, **where virtue/power** (*de*) **is applied** (*shi*),
If **broad** (*bo*),
Then **where the influence** (*wei*) **of authority** (*zhi*) **extends**,
It **reaches far** (*shi xing zhi yuan*),
If **righteousness** (*yi*) **is bestowed** (*jia*) **sparingly** (*bo*),
Then **what is subdued by force** (*wu zhi zhi xiao*) **remains small** (*shi xiao*).
This **speaks** of **virtue/power’s** **bounty** being **without partiality** (*wu si*),
And **those who adhere** (*fu*) **being many** (*zhi zhong*),
If **righteousness** is **abandoned** and **force** is **employed** (*qi yi yong wu*),
Then **what is preserved** (*zhi cun*) **is few** (*zhi shao*).

This **refers** to **acquiring** without **righteousness** (*yi*),
Yet **not distributing** (*bu shu*),
**Calamity** (*huan*) **will come** to their **person** (*shi*),
**Unable** to **benefit** others (*bu neng wei ren*),
Yet **also unable** to **benefit themselves** (*bu neng zi wei*),
**Such may be called** a **foolish person** (*yu ren*),
**No different** from the **owl** (*xiao*) **loving** its **young** (*zi*).
**Taking** without **righteousness** (*qi yi bu yi*),
**Accumulating** yet **not dispersing** (*ji er bu san*),
This is the **so-called** *"nurturing the tiger only to become its prey"* (*yang hu zi di*) and *"rearing the owl only to meet its doom"* (*yu xiao zi bi*).

Thus, **holding** yet **preparing** (*bei*) **is not as good** as **abandoning** (*zhi ji*),
**Hoarding** yet **sharpening** (*cui*) **cannot long endure** (*bu neng chang bao*).
Yet **even** a **treasure chest** (*ju gu*) or **woven basket** (*xiang lao*),
**Will ultimately** become **the resource** (*zi*) **of great thieves** (*da dao*).
How could it **long persist** (*chang you*)?

**Virtue/power** (*de*) **contains** the **Dao/Way** (*dao*),
The **Dao/Way** (*dao*) **contains** **virtue/power** (*de*),
Its **transformation** (*hua*) **cannot be exhausted** (*ji*).
**Those** with the **Dao/Way** **must** have **virtue/power** (*you dao zhi bi you de*).
**Those** with **virtue/power** **must** have the **Dao/Way** (*you de zhi bi you dao*).
When **virtue/power** and the **Dao/Way** are **fully realized** (*chong bei*),
They **harmonize** with **limitless change** (*yong bian hua wu ji*).

**Yin** contains **Yang** (*yin zhong you yang*),
**Yang** contains **Yin** (*yang zhong you yin*),
All **affairs** (*wan shi*) **thus follow** (*jin ran*),
**Cannot be fully illuminated** (*bu ke sheng ming*).
When **auspicious fortune** (*fu*) **arrives** and **blessing** (*xiang*) **is preserved** (*cun*),
When **calamity** (*huo*) **arrives** and **blessing** (*xiang*) **comes first** (*xian*),
**Seeing** **blessing** yet **acting wickedly** (*wei bu shan*),
Then **auspicious fortune** **will not come** (*fu bu lai*),
**Seeing** **inauspiciousness** (*bu xiang*) yet **acting virtuously** (*xing shan*),
Then **calamity** **will not arrive** (*huo bu zhi*).
**Benefit** and **harm** share the **same gate** (*tong men*),
**Calamity** and **fortune** are **neighbors** (*tong lin*),
**Only** the **divine and sagely** (*shen sheng*) **can distinguish** (*mo zhi neng fen*).
Thus it is said:
**Calamity** (*huo*), **auspicious fortune**’s **leaning** (*fu xiang yi*),
**Auspicious fortune** (*fu*), **calamity**’s **hidden presence** (*huo xiang fu*),
Who **knows** its **limit** (*shi*)?
This **speaks** of **Yin** containing **Yang**,
And **Yang** containing **Yin**,
Meaning **fortune** contains **calamity**,
And **calamity** contains **fortune**.

If one **sees** **fortune** yet **considers** it **auspicious** (*xiang*),
Then one **knows** **fortune** as the **beginning** of **calamity** (*huo shi*).
If one **sees** **calamity** yet **immediately** **considers** it **good** (*shan*),
Then one **knows** **calamity** as the **prelude** to **fortune** (*fu xian*).
The **arrival** of **calamity** and **fortune** (*huo fu zhi lai*),
**Is like** **twining strands** (*jiao chan*),
**Only** the **most sagely** (*zhi sheng*) **can know** their **limit** (*ji*).

When **people** are **about to fall ill** (*jiang ji*),
They **must first** **relish** the **flavor** of **fish and meat** (*gan yu rou zhi wei*).
When a **country** is **about to perish** (*jiang wang*),
They **must first** **abhor** the **words** of **loyal ministers** (*wu zhong chen zhi yu*).
**The sick** (*ren bing*),
**Indulge** their **mouth** (*gan qi kou*),
**Delight** in **tastes** (*mei qi wei*),
**This is a sign** of **certain death** (*bi si zhi zheng*).
**The disordered** (*guo luan*),
**Abhor** **loyal counsel** (*wu zhong yan*),
**Believe** **deceitful speech** (*xin yi shuo*),
**This is a sign** of **certain ruin** (*bi wang zhi zhao*).

Thus, **when one is near death** (*ren jiang si*),
**Even** if the **physician** be **skilled** (*yi shi liang*),
They **cannot** be **saved** (*mo jiu*).
When a **country** is **near ruin** (*guo jiang wang*),
**Even** if the **loyalist** **be thorough** (*zhong jin*),
They **cannot** be **preserved** (*nan cun*).
**Only** the **skilled physician** and **loyal minister** (*wei liang yi zhong chen*),
**Can discern** the **certain death** yet **not treat** (*shen bi si er bu jiu*),
**Can observe** the **preservable** yet **advise** (*cha ke cun er wei mou*).
**Refine** it in **oneself** (*xiu zhi shen*),
Then one **may govern** the **people** (*cai yi zhi min*).
**Rule** the **household** and **govern** the **country** (*ju jia li zhi*),
Then one **may** **transfer** their **care** to the **royal court** (*ke yi yi chang*).

Thus it is said:
**Refine** it in **oneself** (*xiu zhi shen*),
Then their **virtue/power** (*de*) **becomes genuine** (*nai zhen*).
**Refine** it in the **family** (*xiu zhi jia*),
Then their **virtue/power** **has surplus** (*nai you yu*).
**Refine** it in the **country** (*xiu zhi guo*),
Then their **virtue/power** **becomes abundant** (*nai fei yong*).
By **oneself** **observing** others (*yong shen guan bi*),
And **the family** **governing** the **country** (*zi jia xing guo*),
The **essence** lies in **refining oneself** (*zhi yao xiu shen*),
And **preserving virtue/power** (*zai yu quan de*).

**People’s** **means** of **livelihood** (*shi*) **are** **clothing** and **food** (*yi yu shi*).
If **service** (*shi*) **is thorough** in **clothing** and **food** (*zhi yu yi shi*),
Then there **is merit** (*you gong*),
If **service** is **not thorough** (*bu zhou*),
Then there **is no merit** (*wu gong*).
When **service** **lacks merit** (*wu gong*),
Then **virtue/power** **does not endure** (*de bu chang*).
**Clothing** and **food** are the **vitality** (*ming*) of the **common people** (*fu shi zhi ming*).
The **common people** are the **foundation** (*ben*) of **lord and subject** (*jun chen*).
When **clothing** and **food** are **thorough** for **oneself** (*zhi yu yi shi*),
Then **lord and subject** **are long preserved** in the **country** (*chang bao yu guo*).

Thus, **conforming** to the **times** (*su shi*) yet **not succeeding** (*wu cheng*),
**Do not alter** their **laws** (*wu geng qi xing*),
**Following** the **times** (*shun shi*) yet **not succeeding**,
**Do not alter** their **governance** (*wu geng er li*).
When the **times** **will rise again** (*shi jiang fu qi*),
This is called the **principle of the Dao/Way** (*dao ji*).

The **times** have **flourishings** and **declines** (*xing fu shi*),
The **course** has **prosperity** and **adversity** (*yun you xiang pi*).
**One cannot** **use** the **excessive governance** of **past times** (*qian shi zhi fan zhi*) **as** the **essential principles** of the **present age** (*jin shi zhi yao li*).
This **speaks** of **laws** **not being abandoned** (*xing bu ke fei*),
And **governance** **not being altered** (*li bu ke yi*).
If one **can discern** this (*neng zhi yu ci*),
Then they **grasp** the **framework of the Dao/Way** (*dao zhi ji gang*).

The **Emperor** and **King** **enrich** their **people** (*fu qi min*),
This is **strengthening** their **foundation** (*dun qi ben*).

chunks.original_text: 霸王富其地， 务其广也。 危国富其吏， 重敛则困。 治国若不足， 治乱也不足，将乱之征也。 亡国困仓虚。 费用无度，仓廪日虚，君荒民罢，不亡何待？ 故曰上无事而民自富，上无为而民自化。 安其居，乐其业。 起师十万，日费千金，师旅之后，必有凶年。 故兵者不祥之器也，非君子之宝也。 兵革兴之於前，凶荒随之於后，国费万金，民罢烦役。 故知凶器非圣人之所宝。 和大怨必有余怨，奈何其为不善也。 夫和怨者，谓主不明。 黜有功之臣，削有士之君，不忍一朝之忿，以为之患。 君赫怒於上，臣愤骄於下，奈何其为不善以积余怨？ 古者亲近不以言，来远不以言使，近者说，远者来。 近说远来者，在德不在言。 与民同欲即和，与民同守即固，与民同念即知，得民力者富，得民誉者显。 行有召寇，言有致祸，无先人言，后人已，附耳之言， 附传也。 先言后传之於耳。 流闻千里。 言者祸也，舌者机也，出言不当，驷马不追。 寇有所爱者利，祸有所起者言。 然言者无足而走，无翼而飞，白圭之玷，驷马何追？ 言祸之疾也。 昔者中黄子曰：天有五方， 四方中央。 地有五行， 金、木、水、火、土也。 声有五音， 宫、商、角、征、羽也。 物有五味， 甘、苦、辛、酸、咸也。 色有五章， 青、黄、赤、白、黑也。 人有五位， 五脏也。 故天地之间有二十五人也。 二十五等人品，类各差也。 上五有神人、真人、道人、至人、圣人， 变化不测曰神，纯素不杂曰真，通达无碍曰道，心洞玄微曰至，智周万物曰圣。 次五有德人、贤人、智人、善人、辩人， 含畜曰德，人爱曰贤，明慧曰智，通恕曰善，文辞曰辩。 中五有公人、忠人、信人、义人、礼人， 无私曰公，奉君曰忠，不愆曰信，合宜曰义，恭柔曰礼。 次五有士人、工人、虞人、农人、商人， 事上曰士，监器曰工，掌山泽曰虞，治田曰农，通货曰商。 下五有众人、奴人、愚人、肉人、小人 庶类曰众，伏役曰奴，昏昧曰愚，无慧曰肉，无识曰小人也。 上五之与下五，犹人之与牛马也。 言贤愚有差，天地县隔也。 圣人者，以目视，以耳听，以口言，以足行。 在世圣人，六情滞隔，犹有因假。 真人者，不视而明，不听而聪，不行而从，不言而公。 出世圣人，方寸已虚，触涂无隔。 故圣人所以动天下者，真人未尝过焉； 贤人所以矫世俗者，圣人未尝观焉。 治世存真，各尽其分，故唐尧圣德以配天，仲武高亢以矫俗也。 所谓道者，无前无后，无左无右，万物玄同，无是无非。 迎之无前，随之无后，孰能於左？ 谁知其右？ 泯然玄同，强名为道。 通玄真经卷之七竟
chunks.translated_text:
The **Conqueror and King** enrich their **lands**—
This is **pursuing** their **expansion** (*wu qi guang ye*).
A **perilous state** enriches its **officials**—
**Heavy taxation** leads only to **hardship**.
To **govern** a **state** yet **lack sufficiency**,
To **pacify** **chaos** yet **lack sufficiency**—
This is the **omen** of **impending disorder**.
A **doomed state** **empties** its **granaries**.
**Expenditures** **without measure**,
Granaries **daily depleted**,
The **ruler** **impoverished**, the **people** **exhausted**—
What **awaits** it if it does not **perish**?

Thus it is said:
When the **sage-ruler** does **nothing** (*wu wei*),
The **people** **prosper** of themselves;
When the **sage-ruler** **acts not** (*wu wei*),
The **people** **transform** of themselves.
**Settle** their **dwellings**,
**Delight** in their **labors**.
Raise an **army** of **ten thousand**,
**Daily** consuming **a thousand** in **gold**—
After the **campaign’s** end,
**Famine** **must** follow.
Thus **arms** are the **ominous tool**,
Not the **treasure** of the **noble**.

When **warfare** **arises** in **front**,
**Famine** **follows** in **rear**;
The **state** **spends** **ten thousand** in **gold**,
The **people** **exhausted** by **toil**.
Thus it is known:
The **ominous tool** is **not** the **treasure** of the **sage**.

To **conciliate** **great grievances** **must** **leave** **residual grievances**—
How can this be **not evil**?
He who **conciliates grievances** is one whose **ruler** is **unclear**.
To **demote** a **meritorious minister**,
To **diminish** a **virtuous lord**,
To **not endure** a **moment’s anger**,
Yet **make** it a **source of calamity**.
When the **ruler’s wrath** **flares above**,
And the **minister’s pride** **smolders below**—
How can this be **not evil**, **accumulating** **residual grievances**?

In **ancient times**, the **near** were **not** **summoned** by **words**,
The **distant** were **not** **commanded** by **words**.
The **near** **take delight**,
The **distant** **come**.
To **delight the near** and **attract the distant**—
This lies in **virtue**, not in **words**.

To **share desire** with the **people** is to **harmonize**,
To **share defense** with the **people** is to **strengthen**,
To **share thought** with the **people** is to **know** them.
He who **gains the people’s strength** is **rich**,
He who **gains the people’s praise** is **illustrious**.

**Actions** **invite bandits**,
**Words** **bring calamity**.
Do not **speak before others**,
Nor **follow after others** have spoken.
**Whispered words**—
These are **transmitted**.
**Spoken first**, then **repeated** to the **ears**—
**Echoing** a **thousand li**.
**Speech** is **calamity**,
The **tongue** is the **trigger**.
Once **words** are **ill-spoken**,
**Four horses cannot** **retrieve** them.
Bandits **love** what is **loved**,
Calamity **arises** from what is **spoken**.
Yet **speech** **runs** **without feet**,
**Flies** **without wings**—
The **blemish** on **white jade**,
**Four horses cannot** **pursue** it.
Thus **speech’s** **swift calamity**.

In **ancient times**, **Zhonghuangzi** said:
The **Heaven** has **five directions**—
**Four directions** and the **center**.
The **Earth** has **five phases**—
**Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth**.
**Sound** has **five tones**—
**Gong, Shang, Jiao, Zhi, Yu**.
**Flavors** have **five tastes**—
**Sweet, Bitter, Spicy, Sour, Salty**.
**Colors** have **five hues**—
**Blue, Yellow, Red, White, Black**.
**Humans** have **five organs**—
The **five viscera**.

Thus between **Heaven and Earth** there are **twenty-five kinds** of **people**.
Twenty-five **ranks** of **human kind**—
Each **type** **differs**.

The **upper five** are:
**Divine Persons, True Persons, Dao-Persons, Perfect Persons, Sage-Persons**—
**Unfathomable transformation** is called **Divine**,
**Pure and unadulterated** is called **True**,
**Unobstructed penetration** is called **Dao**,
**Piercing the profound mysteries** is called **Perfect**,
**Knowledge encompassing all things** is called **Sage**.

The **next five** are:
**Virtuous Persons, Exemplary Persons, Wise Persons, Benevolent Persons, Eloquent Persons**—
**Nurturing** is called **Virtue**,
**Loved by others** is called **Exemplary**,
**Clear and insightful** is called **Wise**,
**Compassionate and forgiving** is called **Benevolent**,
**Persuasive in speech** is called **Eloquent**.

The **middle five** are:
**Public Persons, Loyal Persons, Trustworthy Persons, Righteous Persons, Ceremonious Persons**—
**Without self-interest** is called **Public**,
**Serving the ruler** is called **Loyal**,
**Without fault** is called **Trustworthy**,
**Appropriate conduct** is called **Righteous**,
**Respectful and yielding** is called **Ceremonious**.

The **next five** are:
**Scholar-Persons, Artisan-Persons, Park-Keepers, Farmers, Merchants**—
**Serving superiors** is the **Scholar**,
**Overseeing tools** is the **Artisan**,
**Managing forests and marshes** is the **Park-Keeper**,
**Cultivating fields** is the **Farmer**,
**Facilitating trade** is the **Merchant**.

The **lower five** are:
**Common Persons, Slave-Persons, Foolish Persons, Sensual Persons, Petty Persons**—
**Multitude** is the **Common**,
**Subjugation** is the **Slave**,
**Obtuse** is the **Foolish**,
**Without wisdom** is the **Sensual**,
**Without discernment** is the **Petty**.

The **upper five** and the **lower five**—
Like **humans** and **oxen/horses**.
**Exemplary and foolish** **differ**—
As **Heaven and Earth** are **separated**.

The **Sage**—
**Sees** with **eyes**,
**Hears** with **ears**,
**Speaks** with **mouth**,
**Acts** with **feet**.
The **Sage in the world**—
**Six senses** **obstructed**,
Yet **still relies** on **artifice**.

The **True Person**—
**Sees without clarity** yet is **clear**,
**Hears without listening** yet is **acute**,
**Moves without action** yet is **followed**,
**Speaks without words** yet is **public**.
The **Sage beyond the world**—
**The heart already emptied**,
**No obstruction in passage**.

Thus the **Sage’s** **movement** through the **world**—
The **True Person** **never exceeds** it;
The **Exemplary’s** **correction** of **customs**—
The **Sage** **never observes** it.

To **govern the age** and **preserve the True**—
Each **fulfills its role**.
Thus **Emperor Yao’s** **sage-virtue** **matched Heaven**,
And **Zhongwu’s** **lofty rectitude** **corrected customs**.

The **Dao**—
**No before, no after**,
**No left, no right**,
**All things** in **profound unity**,
**Neither this nor that**.

**Approach it**—**no before**,
**Follow it**—**no after**,
Who **knows its left**?
Who **knows its right**?
**Erased** in **profound unity**—
**Forcibly named** as **Dao**.

**The *Zhenxuan Zhengjing*** **ends** here.
